1.content:
All around Amadeus the winds tore at the mountainside. Great crags already ripped by centuries upon centuries of wind and snow were finally beginning to collapse, yet the collapse was unnatural, for atop the peaks stood a group of figures that were gray blobs thanks to the snow in the air. All Amadeus could tell was that they were humanoid in shape, and that they had to be standing at least seven feet tall, with arms thick as tree trunks.

"Oh great, as if I haven't gone through enough today," complained Amadeus to himself as he continued to grip the side of the cliff, pulling himself nearly flat as yet another large chunk of the rock above was hurtled down at him by one of the figures. Swearing at the figure Amadeus considered his options, which were limited due to his lower position compared to their's. Tactically they had a sound advantage over him until he could get up to their level.

"Okay then, going up," he said to himself, pulling the bulky fur he wore tight around him. The fur, designed to resemble Fenrir, the great wolf, son of Loki, made his usual 2 meters of human male stand at nearly 2 and a half thanks to the added height of both the fur clad cloak and the metal mesh helmet which was shaped like a wolf's head. Pulling everything around him as tightly as he could Amadeus dug the toes of his boots into the mountain's side and then literally jumped upward, using his feet for power and his arms to guide his flight.

Luckily his strength had been improving for some time now and he was able to just make it over the rim of the outcropping on which the figures stood. Grabbing at the bottom edge of the small jut in the mountain he swung over the edge and was now face to face with the four figures that had been hurling rocks bigger than his torso down at him since he and his team had reached the mountain's foot almost an hour ago.

Looking at the figures now Amadeus could make out the details of his construction, and wasn't very impressed. They were standard Kzinti warriors, though their fur was white with gray stripes rather than the orange with black that was used more common among their kind. The one directly before him was still trying to heft a boulder up over its shoulders when Amadeus rocketed over the edge of the cliff and up to the outcropping.

Unfortunately its neighbor already had a huge rock handy and tossed it directly at Amadeus with the power to crush him like a bug. Calling upon the skills honed through dozens of such encounters Amadeus dove out of the way of the stone, which struck the place where he'd been kneeling with enough force to crack that side of the cliff off and send it hurtling down the mountain to the ground far below.

Amadeus, recovering from his dive rolled until he was in a position with his legs behind him and his right arm holding the ground before him while his left reached behind his back and pulled a large weapon from out of the folds of his fur. The huge thing, crafted shaft and head from a single piece of silverish metal, gleamed even in the dull light of the mountain's storm. Swinging the weapon over his head Amadeus showed the humanoid tigermen his skill with the weapon as well as blowing the stray hairs from his attire off the double headed axe's blade, and then slamming it into his back to force his cloak closed again and cut off the numbing chill that had been seeping in through the gap between the neck and helmet of his suit.

"Okay kitties, let's see what kind of claws you've got," he shouted over the howl of the winds, and though he knew the Kzinti couldn't understand him, the way he said it must have been enough for one as it charged headlong at him. Laughing at the foolishness of his opponent Amadeus waited for a moment as the creature rushed forward claws first. Just before it reached him Amadeus leaped, using his strength to jump over twice his height in the lighter gravity of the mountain, and then coming down with his axe under him so that it drove itself into the kzin's head, sending a spray of blood into his face, and ending the creature's life with a finality the resounded in the noise of the metal meeting rock as his axe literally cut the catman's in two.

"Next," he said to the other kzinti as he swept his blade up in an arc that threw off the majority of the blood covering it right at them. The others, seeing the challenger now as a true warrior dropped the rocks they had been holding and instead took up weapons. One held a fighting nail, a glove with a meter long clawlike blade coming from it, while another held in his hands a bat'leth, its crescent shape and many prongs unmistakable to a veteran fighter like Amadeus. The third pulled out something that very closely resembled Amadeus' own axe, but was almost twice the size.

"Okay boys, let's see which of our toys break first," he said, more to himself than to the tigermen as the wind's howl made anything but a shout impossible to hear. Despite not being able to hear what he said the Kiznti still roared in animalistic fury, and ripped their way through the snow drifts. With the white powder flying before them their vision of Amadeus was obscured, and the human warrior used that to his advantage, ducking down just as they got near him.

The kzin holding the bat'leth was the first to reach Amadeus, and the first to fall as Amadeus literally drove his axe's head into the ground, and just as the kzin reached the spot where he had been standing the catlike humanoid found the ground rise up under his claws. Putting all his strength into it Amadeus literally tossed the kzin over the edge of the precipice, where he would fall for many minutes before slamming into the ground far below.

Their brother's cries alerting them to the human's tricks the two remaining kzinti stopped rushing forward. Where they had planned on overwhelming the pitiful creature with their numbers they now realized they would most likely fall to some kind of trick. Taking more cautious steps they approached the now standing figure of Amadeus, who knew that such tricks were useless against the now wary foes he faced.

The two kzinti came on as one, each brandishing his weapon before him. Amadeus, not one to be outdone by his foes swung his axe at them, forcing the tigermen to keep their distance from his as he worked out a plan. Unable to come up with anything, he decided that his one hope was surprise, and instead of waiting for the kzinti to make their move, he charged forward with a roar of rage that could be heard even over the wail of the storm.

His tactic, as spontaneous as it was, allowed him that one moment of surprise he need, and with a triumphant feeling insde he slammed his foot down on the dull side of the fighting nail worn by the larger of his two foes. The kzin, unable to compensate fast enough for his opponent's new aggressive stance was forced to watch as Amadeus slammed the flat of his blade into the side of the creature's head, causing the nail to break with an echoing snap of metal, and the kzin himself to spin twice in the air before falling to the snow and laying still.

The one remaining warrior, despite the fact that his brothers had fallen, remained unfearful of the human, and showed it by charging at him, taking care to note where the man held his weapon and swinging his axe in an overhead arc to prevent him from leaping up as he had done with the first kzin. The axe, coming down with more force than he could hope to block, forced Amadeus to roll out of the way, and then leap to his feet again only half a meter from where he'd been. By that time though the kzin had recovered from his blow and was already coming around for a horizontal slash, though this time with much less power behind the blow.

Holding his axe in a vertical position Amadeus blocked the blow, parrying it aside with all the grace of a master, and then launching a counter attack which the kzin blocked by spinning his weapon and knocking Amadeus' axe out of its path. So it went fr many minutes as the two axe wielders grappled atop the snowy peak, their blades ringing together and causing sparks that lit the storm darkened mountainside.

To Amadeus, who had seen many battles of this type, it was easy to follow the routine of his opponent, who like most who wielded an axe, relied on the weapon's sheer power to break his foe. Few who used the weapon like that would ever know victory when they came up against a master of it, for like the sword, the axe could be subtle, moving in midswing to fall wherever the user wished it to, and cutting through an enemy's defenses with ease.

Calling upon that skill Amadeus pushed the kzin warrior back, forcing his opponent to adjust to an ever more intricate series of strikes which came ever closer to contact with his flesh, until in a final sweeping blow it pushed the blade of the kzin aside and drove the axe head home into his chest. For a few seconds the kzin just stood still as a statue, staring down in disbelief at the wound in his front that pierced his heart, and then without cry or sound the creature fell to the snow with a dull thud.

With the thrill of battle done with Amadeus wiped his blade on the snow, removing the green streaked blood of the catman from its silver surface so that it shined once more. With his weapon cleaned the warrior returned it to its resting place on his back and walked to the edge of the precipice, to look and see if the rest of his party had caught up yet. Gazing over into the infinite darkness he did not hear the crunch of snow as a figure rose from beneath a layer of powder, and walked with feline grace until it was right behind him, prepared to push him to his doom.

"Look out, Deus!" shouted a female voice from below, and then, out of the darkness a gout of blue fire shot. Rolling aside Deus spun on his heel to find the kzin with the broken fighting nail standing right behind where he had been. Surprised by the voice as well as his targets sudden movement the kzin was caught off guard as the flame hit him and began to burn his white fur in its heat. Before it could recover from the shock of the hit Amadeus ran beside it and smacked the catman with the side of his axe, sending it over the edge to join both the rocks it had been throwing as well as it brother whom Amadeus had knocked over the edge earlier.

"Well now, that was a fine mess you got yourself into," said the female voice again, this time coming from above this time. Looking around Amadeus found the source of the voice easily, as the woman it belonged to hovered over him riding her staff which sent a jet of blue flame below her.

"I was gonna dodge him," lied Amadeus, and obviously the girl knew it was a lie as she clicked her tongue at him while slowly descending to his level.

"Oh, come on Deus. You didn't even know he was there. Without me you'd be the one falling to your doom," said the blue flame witch, her attire seeming to be much lighter than Amadeus' own considering the temperature of where they were.

"Maybe, but I would of caught myself. Jazz, you know me," responded Amadeus, already walking over to the cliff and beginning to search for handholds.

"Deus, wait. Thee others will be here in a few minutes, and then we can go up together and get the Yggdrasil planet from the dragon," protested Jasmine as she placed her hand on Amadeus' shoulder. Sighing thee man in furs turned to the scantily clad which and looked down at her, his form towering over her one and a half meters.

"Jasmine, I can't wait. I have to go in a few minutes and I really want to win this time," he told her.

"Yeah well you aren't going to be able to beat a dragon of Asgard alone. If I remember correctly it ate you last time," she responded to him, bringing up memories of the last time they'd played this particular game.

"You say it ate me, I say I was trying to attack it from within," he said, turning away and back towards the cliff. Just as he reached it though the whole world seemed to freeze in place as a new layer of gray passed over it, this time due to static rather than the snow fall. When the world reset he was now laying face down in the snow with Jasmine hefting him up.

"Deus, what happened?" she demanded as he slowly picked himself back up.

"I don't know, some kind of sync error, let me check," he told her, pushing at something on his arm and causing a screen to appear in front of him. Looking at the red blinking warning he screamed in frustration and turned back towards Jasmine, forcing himself to calm down despite his agitation.

"Looks like I gotta go. There's something wrong with my Terminal. Same time tomorrow Jazz?" he asked.

"Sorry, I've got duty tomorrow. Maybe next week," she responded, waving goodbye. Amadeus returned her wave before touching a part of the screen before him that caused the whole world to shift again, this time going from a ful environment to something like a flat picture painted on the inside of a globe which he now floated in the center of. Feeling disoriented Amadeus watched as squares of the picture began to go dark, and his view of the globe shifted as the Terminal set him right side up.

Sighing again he felt bad that he'd left Jasmine alone on the side of the mountain with their party far below, but he was confident that she would get them all to the top safely, though beating the dragon might be beyond their skills. Another battle which he should be at, but wouldn't be.

"Damn," swore Amadeus, both at the circumstances of his life, and at the return to Dedros gravity. The Terminal which he had been playing on had kept hm at about .97 grav during the game, but as the Terminal shut down the local gravity of 3.28 reasserted itself, causing him to fall to his knees in surprise. He had defiantly been playing too long, and was already imaging a nice peaceful slumber when he began to curse again.

Around him the normally bright street was dark. Above the skyscrapers, which should have been abuzz with the nightly comings and goings of their occupants were black. Looking at his Terminal Amadeus realized that some kind of power surge must have hit his city, which caused the sync error in the game he had been playing.

"Oh well, the mechanics will fix it tomorrow," he said to himself, pulling at his furry garments so that they would allow air into them. It was a hot night, and though Amadeus was used to walking home in odd raiments due to his late night gaming habit he still hadn't that he was sweating so profusely, and that he would now have to get sweat and blood out of the suit before he could play in it again. Looking down at it he observed that the kzinti's blood, which had splattered on the front of the suit, was already growing hard.

"You know, I might just leave that in," he told himself, feeling that the green blood added to the look of a Norse warrior. It was at that moment that he felt a slight tug at his person, and he instantly dropped down into a fighter's stance, placing his hand at the belt he wore under his furs and on the butt of the pistol holstered to it. A quick scan of his surroundings showed nothing pulling at him though and he relaxed a bit, before he felt another tug, this time hard enough to tell where it was coming from.

"What in the stars?" he swore as he looked up to behold lightning streaking across a clear sky, and not more than a few yards from where he stood. The bolts were so close that he could feel the hairs on his arms raising in response to them, and then with a thunderous concussion several of the bolts struck together, forming a hole in the sky.

"Oh, crap!" he yelled as the tug he'd been feeling became many times greater. His hands acted out of instinct, grasping for anything to hold him down, but they found nothing on the smooth ground of side walk. Scream obscenities Amadeus rose slowly into the vortex, and the moment he made contact a flash of light could be seen. When it cleared Amadeus and the vortex had both vanished.
____________________________________
On another world a hole in the sky was ripped open for a moment, belching forth a single figure before quickly sealing shut again. This figure, clad in furs fell to the ground three meters below screaming out curses at the various gods he knew the names of, and several ones he was making up on the spot. His stream of foul language was cut off suddenly when he slammed into the ground in a beautiful face plant that left him sitting still for several minutes before rising to his feet somewhat woozily. Placing his hand on his fore head to steady himself he looked around, gauging his surroundings.

"I have got to get a new travel agent," he said to himself as he found himself....

11.content:
His body feeling like he'd just taken it through a blender set to obliterate, Amadeus looked at the pristine, if somewhat creepy forest that surrounded him. Not finding much of interest he began to look over his body, checking for obvious signs of interdimensional travel stress. Finding nothing wrong with his body that didn't have to do with the abrupt landing, Amadeus decided to count his blessings and not voice a complaint about the fact that his body felt like dren and stared off into the darkness which stretched before him.

"Hello?" he said, not really loudly enough to be heard except by himself. He realized his foolishness a moment later and nearly hit himself for being such an idiot. After all he was in the middle of the woods, even if he shouted it was not likely there would be anyone around to hear him, or if they did it would be just another animal noise unless he was close enough for the Translator Collar to kick in and put his words into a language they would understand while it did the same to their words for him.

Having already confirmed that his body was still human Amadeus began checking his possessions for any sign of alteration. Pulling the axe out of its sheath on his back he looked it over and found it to be just as shiny as ever, if a bit cold due to temperature difference between the snowy mountains from before and the forest where he now stood. Slipping the axe back into place beneath the fur cloak he was glad to feel its weight, which reassured him that he was not helpless.

The next thing he checked was the skin tight suit he wore. Pulling open the front of his cloak we was relieved by the sight of the dull gray mesh weave of his suit, which if what the ads said was true would keep him safe and at a comfortable temperature in almost any environment, though he doubted the makers of the suit had intended on the user to be wearing a fur overcoat on top of it, which caused him to sweat in the balmy air of the forest.

Changing his view from the suit to his belt he looked down to find that the holster was intact, and drawing his Startec pistol he found it to still be in working order, at least according to its scans of itself. A test firing at low power created a small tongue of flames in a dried out bit of grass, proving that the gun was operational, though according to the read out it was at twenty-five percent power, mostly because he hadn't bothered to fill its hydrogen chamber in a week. Looking around he tasted the air and was pleased to note a hint of water in it.

"At least I can fill it up when I need to," he said to himself, putting the weapon away until a need for its power arose. Hopefully he could get some help without having to pull a gun, but it was always better to have something and not need it, than to not have something and die from a lack of it. Satisfied at the pistol he put his hand on the pouch on the other side of the belt, finding the weight of his various knickknacks to still be there.

With all the gear intact, if not fully charged, Amadeus placed his hand behind his back, and pulled something off the very rear of the belt. In the darkness of the overcast nighttime forest it was hard to see what he held in his hand, though it wouldn't have been an impressive sight at all in the state it was in now. The thing, which looked like a PDA, was chirping oddly, sometimes a word or two breaking through the static.

"Zee, you in there? I could really use some help here," said Amadeus to the small computer. The response was a few blaring noises followed by cut off words which he took to mean Zee was not functioning right at the moment, a theory that proved correct as the static filled screen blazed blue and a small clock icon appeared in front of Amadeus.

"Logic circuits scrambled. Recompile will take approximately 1.2 cycles," said a mechanical, female voice, before the screen went dark. Swearing again Amadeus struck the side of the device with his palm.

"Come on Zee. Don't do this to me now. I need you," he told the device, striking it twice more before giving up on it and placing the small computer behind his back again.

"Ok so Zee's gone bye-bye for now, and I'm all alone on an unknown planet," he told himself assessing the situation. He looked around, and finding no one around to see him he jumped up and down several times before stopping.

"Gravity appears to be about 1 grav, though I'd need Zee to know the exact measurement," he said, going through each bit of the Combine's guide for interplanetary travel in turn. His next action was to take a deep sniff of the air, drawing in several deep breathes through his nose and then breathing them out through his mouth.

"Atmosphere is at about seventy percent nitrogen and twenty percent oxygen, with trace elements added in. Carbon content is less than one percent, indicating a pre-industrial society if any," he said, and then stopped, taking another wiff of the local air.

"Oddly there seems to be a large ethanol fume content. Naturally this is not unheard of, but within a forest?" he told himself questioningly, filing away each bit of data inside his memory for future reference. He knew that even the tiniest bit of info could come in handy in an E.T. event, where he encountered a sentient species while visiting a planet, and even if there was no sentient race he might find another use for the data.

Finding nothing more to study n the immediate area Amadeus was faced with a choice. He could stay where he was in the clearing and wait for Zee to reboot so the little computer could tell him where he was, or he could leave the clearing by any one of the three paths he could see. Looking up provided no clue as to where he was asa thick layer of clouds obscured the sky, making it so that he couldn't even tell if the planet had moons or not. Facing forward he designated the way he stood to be 12 o'clock, with the paths at the positions of two, five, and nine. Looking around he decides...
11.title: A strange new world

111.content:
Sitting down on the ground Amadeus began to hum an old tune as he waited for Zee to reboot. Until his companion was operational again Amadeus didn't feel like getting himself lost on the planet's surface, because there was always the possibility, however small, that the phenomenon that had dragged him from Dedros to this strange forest would reopen and send him back.

The forest air hung still and quite all around him, giving Amadeus a chance to think over the game he'd been playing, and finally come to the realization that Jasmine had been right, he should have waited on the ledge for the others, as the dragon had beaten him twice, one of those times using his digestive tract, which had oddly been an arousing experience. He would have to have a psych profile done later to analyze why, and maybe get a hypnotic reprogramming to get rid of that personality quirk.

"Zee would probably just tell me I was being a human," commented Amadeus to himself remembering the CAP's opinion that all humans were in some way mentally ill, though he felt that was an improvement over the other races he'd met, who all seemed dull when compared to humans, who's reactions were as random as that of two free flying electrons.

Sitting alone in the darkness Amadeus felt himself drifting off to sleep, probably because he'd been up the last five days straight in the Game, finding clues that had led them to the mountain path which would lead eventually to the dragon's lair and the Yggdrasil treeling within. The point of the Game was to get the treeling back to Asgard so Odin could grant it new life so it could replace the failing World Tree, though in five play throughs they had yet to even make it up the mountain, let alone back to Asgard.

A sound alerted Amadeus to company, but before he could react something slammed into his back, sending him forward to the ground. Feeling stupid for being caught in a daydream Amadeus tried to move, but found his body refused to cooperate, remaining frozen despite his will to move. Searching his memory he realized the blow had connected with the base of his neck on the back, probably shattering part of his spine, rendering him unable to move.

"Is he down?" asked a voice, oddly enough in a language that Amadeus could understand. Moving his eyes he looked over towards the place where he thought the words had come from and saw two figures moving in the darkness, though he couldn't make out anything other than vague outlines of two humanoid shapes, one possessing a tail. The tail whipped from side to side as the two figures approached, and Amadeus realized that he was caught be some kind of enemy, and that he was probably going to be dead within the next few moments.

A trained warrior of the Combine Amadeus did not panic. His skills had not availed him, and he had no intention of allowing whoever it was who had slain him to get away with it. Waiting he allowed the two figures to slowly approach him, and just as they entered range he pushed on one of his molars with his tongue, revealing a small panel, and then he bit down as hard as he could, hearing a satisfying crack as the tooth broke in half, and then everything went white hot as he and everything within a dozen feet were consumed by an azure orb of light. Never would Amadeus know where he was, or who had killed him, but his actions ended the life of two villains, and that was enough for him.
111.title: Death in the woods

112.content:
The path at nine o'clock looks just a like more traveled than the other two, and thus the most likely to lead somewhere, if only a cave for the local animal population. With that thought firmly in hand Amadeus began his trek through the alien woods, his destination an unknown to him, though he had a good hope that he would find something that might help him at the path's end. After only a few dozen meters Amadeus was forced to stop and tug at his left leg, whose boot had gotten tangled in the underbrush of the area due to the fact that it was supposed to be used in mountain climbing and not forest walking.

"I really hope whoever runs this planet has a decent pair of shoes that I can borrow," he said to himself as the root on which his spiked boot had become caught broke with a great cracking sound. Shaking his leg to get the loose bit of root of the tip of the spikes he continued on down the path, looking at the forest floor beneath his feet for other hazards that might catch on his boots.

The path went in a straight and unerring path through the woods, which told him it had to have been made by sentients, due to the fact that like electrons, animals typically followed the path of least resistance when running, meaning a trail made by an animal would follow meandering route through the woods, walked around any steep inclines rather than going straight through them which his current path did.

"Well at least I know there's a sentient race on this world," commented Amadeus as he broke through the path's last piece and into another clear area of the forest, this one defiantly unnatural as it had a long, smooth asphalt road running off into the distance two different ways. Amadeus, a xeno-history buff had ben taught that the greatest indication of a civilization was not the cities or towers it built, but rather its roads, for the better kept the roads, the more travel they had put up with, and thus the more movement of a population.

Feeling better about the sight of a road, Amadeus began looking left and right for some sign of a car or lights which might indicate the way to the local population's city or town, but oddly he could see nothing in any direction, meaning two things. Either the local population was nocturnal, and thus required no light even in the darkness of the starless night, or that they were without power for some reason, which ranged from a local blackout to a nuclear war. Willing to take either risk Amadeus found neither way to be that inviting so he pulled an old coin out of his pocket.

"Knowledge I go left, sight I go right," he said, looking at the coin, which was decorated with an ankh representing knowledge on one side and an eye representing sight on the other. With a sigh he flipped the coin into the air and caught it in his flat palm, looking down it landed with the...
112.title: Flipping a coin

1122.content:
"Knowledge lead me home," he said, placing the coin back into the pouch with the other objects he was satisfied that its choice was as unbiased as he would get for now, though he hoped that when Zee came back online he could identify the planet he was on and with any luck find a nearby Combine consulate who would speed him on his way home.

Walking on the paved road proved only slightly easier than the forest path, as the spiked toes of his climbing boots forced him to set each foot down flat before him or risk the spikes catching in the asphalt and sending him flailing forward. With a grace and ease built up by dozens of years of training as well as personal experience Amadeus walked forward at a steady clip, and was surprised to find that he saw not one car or vehicle making its way down the road, though he felt that he should have as the road seemed very well used.

"Maybe it's some kind of holiday," he observed, thinking of reasons for traffic to stop. If it was indeed a holiday than he would have to be on his toes when he found a local, as holidays on most worlds tended to make any insult ten times worse than it usually was, causing the person insulted to tackle the insulter even if the insulter had no idea what he'd just said.

With that charming thought in mind Amadeus began to look around the highway for any light or other sign of the civilization which had built the roadway. Finding only darkness and woods he was feeling more and more that he should have taken the other path when he suddenly saw something that made him do a double take.

One of the trees suddenly blossomed with light out of what looked like a window. Not believing his eyes he rubbed them and then looked again. This time the tree was dark, and he could no longer make out a window of any kind. Believing that he might be seeing thing he began to walk on when two light came on, this time clearly outlining bipedal humanoid forms in their glow, which was soft like the light shed by a fire.

"Candles?" he asked himself questioningly, not knowing why a culture that had roads would be using candles for a light source at night. Shaking off his feelings of unease he decided it was best not to question fortune's grace, and ran across the highway towards the tree which he now knew was a home to some form of intelligent life. Looking at the tree from the road he was surprised to find that no way lead to it, but as he moved off the road he realized that the tree had to be quite large, and thus was much farther away than it had appeared at first.

No stranger to work he closed the distance quite fast considering his footwear was designed for climbing mountains, and seemed to catch on every root or loose rock that stood between him and the tree. Still his headlong flight did not slow, as his goal was so close and he wanted to make contact with the locals as soon as possible. Coming up on the house's driveway he saw a sight that filled him with a sense of hope, a mailbox marked with strange letters.

Just as he slowed his run to a brisk walk and began going up the drive something clicked in his mind. The strange letters on the side of the mailbox, he could read them. For a moment he stood frozen to the spot, not sure what he was seeing, but turning back and running his fingers over the letters he recognized them as the old English alphabet, specifically spelling out the name Dewclaw.

"What the neutron?" he swore, making sure that he wasn't seeing things by raising his helmet and rubbing his eyes. Despite this the letters stayed the same, and he was forced to admit that he was looking at a language he knew, which should have been impossible. Shaking his head against the thoughts that threatened to overwhelm him he decided that for now making contact was important. He'd figure out the mailbox later.

Banishing the mailbox from his mind he fingered the collar around his neck, making sure that it felt warm and was active. The device felt pleasingly warm to his touch, showing that it was still functional and would translate any speech sent his way into something he could understand, while at the same time translating his speech into something the other person would be able to comprehend. Even if the letters of this world were in an old human language that didn't mean spoken speech was. Sighing he walked up the rest of the drive to the door of the house.

"Try not to seem like an outsider," he told himself, looking for a doorbell. Finding none he decided to knock with his mailed fist, which made a very nice boom as he struck the wooden door. Hoping that knocking really was a universal thing like his old xenopsyc teacher had told him he waited for a moment before the door opened up to reveal...
1122.title: Knocking on destiny's door

choices: Stay and try to get help
11221.content:
"Yes, can I help you?" asked the delicate sounding voice of the young female, or so he assumed from her dress. It took Amadeus only a moment to recover from the shock of hearing English being spoken at him, which was something the mailbox had indicated. He wondered for a moment how long he'd have been standing in front of the female looking like an idiot if he hadn't noticed the writing on the mailbox. Shrugging off those thoughts he looked down at the smaller figure and smiled under his helmet.

"You might be able to. My car broke down a bit up the road and I was wondering if you could let me use you phone?" he asked the rabbit woman, trying to speak her language as best he could as he fingered the collar at his neck and deactivated it.

"Well, I'm sorry to tell you this but our phones went out with the power. I don't think Kevin's house fared any better but you can try," she told him, opening the door all the way. Now in the dim light of a candle she could see him in his entirety, and for the first time since seeing the house Amadeus remembered he was still in a blood soaked fur coat with a helmet, which probably explained the odd look the woman was giving him as her eyes went up and down his body.

"You wouldn't happened to be related to Kell by any chance?" she asked him after a few moments of awkward silence between the two.

"No, but do you have a place where I can hang this stuff up?" answered Amadeus, pulling the cloak off of himself and then reaching up to grab the helmet as well. Tugging at the heavy metal mesh covering he was able to rip it off with one great exertion and finally stood before the rabbit woman wearing only the skintight polymer weave body suit which was standard issue for Combine Gamers, though the boots ruined the look thanks to the fact that they were designed to go with the cloak.

Shaking his head to get rid of the sweat that had built up in his hair he opened his eyes to find the rabbit woman pointing behind him, a look of horror in her eyes. Turning, he expected to be facing some kind of monster, but seeing nothing he turned back with a raised eyebrow and took only a moment to realized that the woman was pointing to him, not behind him, and her breathes were coming in deep shallow gasps.

"You're a...You're a.. You're a...You're a.. You're a.. human," she said haltingly, shaking all the while, and then as the word human left her lips her eyes rolled back into her head. Dropping the metal helmet on the floor in made a clinking sound that echoed through the darkened house, though Amadeus was too busy catching the rabbit woman in his arms before she could hit the floor.

"Yes, I'm a human. Now wake up lady. Come on, wake up," he said to her, shaking her slightly. She had identified him as human, and that meant she might now where he could find a Combine Consulate, and a ride home. Focused on the woman as he was he barely perceived the entrance of another figure into the room, this one not carrying a candle, but outlined in the light of the one the rabbit woman had dropped Amadeus could tell the figure had lupine origins and very sharp teeth.
11221.title: Recognized

112212.content:
Setting the rabbit woman as gently as he could on the floor, Amadeus looked at lupine form standing in the doorway into the entrance room of the odd tree/home before bolting out the door. He had no idea what kind of connection the two creatures had to each other, but he was not going to stick around and try and find out either. Jolting upward to his feet he rushed out the door as fast as he could into the night, abandoning the fur cloak and helmet, which would have been an encumbrance in a flight like his anyway.

Back in the entrance hall George Fennec rushed to the door to see that the man who had been holding his wife's limp form in his hands was already almost half a kilometer away, and getting farther all the time. Looking at where he'd been standing George could see some kind of metal head covering in the shape of a wolf's head which had probably been the source of the sound that had attracted him to the door. Kneeling over his wife, he slapped her face lightly with his left hand and trying to wake her up.

"Come on, Danielle, wake up. You can't die on me again," he said because her chest was moving in erratic patterns, and her breathe was coming shallow and grave. Looking into her face memories of losing her before flooded his mind, and he felt tears welling up, but they were quickly dried when she took a deep breathe again, her eyes opening to find her fox husband standing over her, his ears twitching noticeably in the wane light of her candle which had fallen to the floor beside her.

"George," she wheezed out, pointing towards the door with a slightly panicked look in her eyes.

"It's okay, Danielle. Whoever it was is gone," he said, stroking her hair back behind her ears and getting it out of her face.

"No George, that's not it. That man, he was human," she said, getting up and hurriedly grabbing for the fur cloak which the man had dropped, noticing for the first time the odd smell which came from the green wet stuff on it. Oddly it smelled kind of like blood, but none she'd ever smelled.

"He was human, George. Like I used to be, but still looked like it," she told him, taking a deep sniff of the coat's odor, searching for the man's scent.

"What? Impossible. The birds sealed up the portals, and besides when things come through them they change. You just had a traumatic experience. Come on, we'll get Kevin to give you some carrot juice to settle you down," said George, putting his arm around her and trying to lead her away from the door, but just as he reached the door into the house a wolf woman blocked his path holding a candle in her left hand and looking at the two with a worried eye.

"Is everything okay? Who was at the door?" she asked of the fox and rabbit.

"It was noth-" began George, but was cut off by Danielle as she pushed his arm off her and offered the cloak to Kell.

"It was a human Kell. You know, what I used to be, but I can't get his scent out of these furs, can you?" she asked the wolf woman.

"What?" responded Kell, taking the offered furs and looking at them closely. She too saw the blood stain, but unlike Danielle she knew without a doubt that it was blood, despite the fact that it was green and smelled odd. Bringing the garment closer to her nose she tried to weed through the scents of wolf fur and kzin blood for any odd scent, but unfortunately finding none.

"I'm sorry Danielle, but I don't smell anything. Are you sure it was a human?" she asked, looking questioningly at the rabbit. Danielle's breathing slowed as she considered what she'd seen. Maybe it was just a hallucination brought on by the odd power outage which seemed to have effected the whole town as well as the cars. After a moment she turned back to Kell and said...
112212.title: Hallucination of a human?

1122121.content:
"Well then let's go see what we can find," said Kell, stepping around a stuttering George, who looked after the two females with a face that showed utter defeat. Shaking his head he went back through the door which Kell had entered, intending on informing the rest of the house of this supposed human. Outside the rabbit and wolf women were looking at the drive for any sign of the man's passage, and at the end of the drive they found something that confirmed that something odd had come up it just a moment ago, the tread print of a boot.

"What is this?" asked Kell, looking at the strange print which she didn't recognize at all.

"It's a shoe print. That proves it. No one on this entire planet wears shoes. That man was a human," proclaimed Danielle, looking off into the distance where the man had to have run. By now most of the extended family was in the door looking at the two women. Leaning down Kell got as good a scent as she could on the man's trail, following it up the drive before taking off into the woods. She found two separate trails dividing only a few meters out, and was quick to follow the one that lacked the wolf overtones the man had, had when he'd been wearing the furs.

"This way," she told Danielle, though everyone followed her as she sprinted off after the smell.

Meanwhile Amadeus, having run as fast as he could manage over the uneven forest floor in his climbing boots, which was still pretty fast. He covered over three kilometers of ground before he finally had to stop to catch his breathe. Leaning against one of the taller trees he scanned the local area, searching for something that might indicate pursuit, but found none from his current level on the ground. Wanting to see more he realized that he could climb the tree, which seem taller than most of the ones around it, and look from atop it's branches for anything that meant he was being followed.

Digging the toes of the boots into the tree he felt an odd vibration, as if the tree were reacting to being bit into by the sharp points, but a moment later it subsided, and two test kicks found no vibration so he decided it was safe to ascend. Like a cat he made his way up, using the tree branches for hand holds, in combination with the boots to make it to the top only seconds after he'd started up. Looking down fro his new perch he was able to see a long ways off, and was disappointed to find that a small procession of figures was being led towards him by the rabbit woman as well as another lupine figure, though he didn't think it was the one from before.

"Oh great, the bunny girl has other dog friends," he told himself.

"Oh they're not friends, they're family," said a voice that seemed to come from all around him. Putting his hand securely on the branch he lt his gaze dart around looking for the source of the new voice which seemed female in tone, but he could find nothing close enough to explain it.

"Who said that?" he asked, spinning his head around hoping to find the speaker if she responded.

"I did. Now if you don't mind, could you please get out of my branches. You aren't very light," said the voice again, this time he could tell it was coming from everywhere as he watched the branches around him vibrate and rub in almost the same way a vocal cord does. Surprised by this he was caught off guard when the branch he was sitting on suddenly gave way and he began tumbling down towards the ground many meters below.

Luckily the tree, if it was the tree that had been talking, didn't seem to want to hurt him, and branches shifted position so that he hit many on the way down, keeping him from building up the momentum to cause a serious injury when he hit the ground, though with the many bumps and bruises that now dotted his body he almost wished the tree had just let him drop straight and take his chances. Slowly rolling off his back and then rising to his feet again Amadeus brushed off the dirt which had gotten into his suit and then put his hands behind his back and pulled, causing a loud cracking sound as his spine popped back into its accustomed place.

"Oh my aching everything," he complained, trying to get his bearings back. Above him the tree now looked like any other tree in the forest, if a little larger, but after a second of observation he found the tree was least of his worries as he was now surrounded by an odd mishmash of humanoid creatures. Not planning on going down without a fight Amadeus dropped into a fighter's stance and drew the Startec pistol with his right hand and his axe, which was still strapped to his back, with his left.

"Okay then, let's see what you guys have got," he said, intending on doing battle against the mysterious group of onlookers, but he was quick to notice that though they backed off a bit, none of them seemed to be making a threatening move. After a few seconds of silence a familiar figure stepped forward from the group.

"Excuse me, but we're not here to fight you. We just want to talk," said the bunny woman in a kindly voice. Amadeus, having survived on alien planets before did not lower his weapons, but he did rise from his crouching stance to stare the woman in the face.

"You identified me as human, so all I need to know is where the nearest Combine consulate is and then we can go our separate ways," said Amadeus to the woman. The others in the group were clearly at a loss and turned to the woman, who though she seemed composed, was obviously not enjoying the spot light.

"I'm afraid there are no human consulates on this world, from this Combine place or any other nation for that matter. Listen, you've been transported to another planet, maybe even another dimension, so you are understandably agitated. I was too when it happened to me," said the rabbit woman, motioning to him and then to herself in an a gesture meant to show him that they were in some way similar.

"You got sucked through a vortex too?" asked Amadeus, not sure if he believed the woman or not.

"Well no. Mine was more of a time/space hole thing, but I was dragged here without my permission. My name used to be Danielle Kendall, and I worked for the IRS in the United States of America," she told Amadeus proudly. Mulling over what he'd just heard Amadeus searched his memory for what IRS stood for. He remembered the United States, after all Jasmine had gotten him interested in the ancient history of Earth, specifically the twentieth and twenty-first centuries, just before Exodus, but IRS didn't ring any bells until he searched the back of his memory.

"Internal Revenue Service?" he said questioningly, thinking back to a lecture on the hypercomplex tax system of that area and period.

"Yes, the IRS," she said confidently.

"But that's impossible," he said in disbelief, wondering how the woman could ever believe her claim of coming from some organization in a nation that existed tens of thousands of Earth Years ago on the lost Homeworld.

"I know it sounds crazy, but it's true. You're in some parallel universe," she told him, and it clicked in his mind. She didn't have to be from his Earth, from Old Home Terra. After all a lot of humans in other dimensions named their homeworld Earth, a fact which had baffled xenoarcheologist since they first began to catalogue the various dimensions.

Realizing that the woman thought he was from her home he looked again at her eyes, and saw no hint of deception in them, though he did see something just as important, a gap in the circle that surrounded him. He was faced again with a choice. He could try to run again, making for the break in the trap in which he was caught, or he could put his weapons away and listen to what the bunny woman had to say.
1122121.title: Caught

choices: One of the others speaks first
11221211.content:
"Trust is something that is hard to earn," he said, crouching down farther, as if he were ready to pounce and strike at those who had entrapped him.

"However, in order to gain, sometimes it is necessary to give," he said Spinning the gun on his finger he slipped it effortlessly back into its holster, and then he reached behind his back to return the axe to its sheath as well, before rising and standing unarmed before the mixed group of individuals, most of what seemed human in the darkness of the overcast night, though he caught scents from them that were most decidedly not.

"I trust you, Danielle," he told her, and the tension in the air evaporated a bit, though some still hung, as if the group expected the human to at any moment whip out his weapons again and commence fighting.

"So, can we go back home now?" asked one f the figures, which looked to be about the size of a young male, though even in the darkness his lupine form was easily distinguishable from a human. After his rather bold statement one of the forms next to him slapped him on the back of his head, both moving the hat he was wearing in front of his eyes, and causing him to grip the back of his head in pain.

"Shut it, Rudy," said the figure, this one with a very odd hairdo of spikes, though one that could easily have been worn by a human woman, if not for the fact that some of it seemed to be jutting straight out of her back.

"Actually, I think going home would be a good idea. At least there we can talk privately with our new acquaintance about his situation, and maybe hear the specifics about how he got here," said one of the larger figures, this one also lupine and possibly related to the smaller one who'd spoken out a moment before. Amadeus, not really up on what to do in a situation where primitives are aware of humans, decided to follow without question and at least get some answers about where he was.

The little parade of various figures moved through the darkness without attracting much attention, mostly because whatever knocked out the power in the local area must have caused every animal and plant to go into a kind of stasis mode. It was like everything in the night were holding it's breathe, waiting for something glorious or horrible to happen. Of course by now Amadeus could see that many homes were lit by candle light, and he realized that his entrance to this world had probably caused a massive EMP that overloaded every circuit on the planet.

It took the procession a while to arrive back at the tree/home where Amadeus had first encountered the rabbit woman, much longer than it had when Amadeus had been running away and they had been running after him. Since they walked back and had to stop twice when Amadeus' boots got caught in debris that littered the path, their time was not surprising.

"Does anyone know where I can find a decent pair of walking shoes?" asked Amadeus when he hit a third root and was forced to stop and yank at his leg to get it loose. He got some very odd stares from the other members of his group before Danielle walked up to his side and spoke in his ear.

"Uh, padded soles make shoes kind of irrelevant on this planet. I'm sure we can figure something out later though," she told him, and Amadeus looked down at the feet of the various forms to find that they were indeed barefoot.

"Ok," he said in acquiescence, accepting that a world where the major races had natural padding on their feet had little need for footwear of any sort. The rest of the trip back, barring the point where the younger lupine walked behind him and sniffed at his butt before being pulled away by the larger, maternal lupine, was uneventful. All in all it would have been a pleasant hike which he would have enjoyed making with Jasmine or Zee, though his present company was more than interesting enough to keep him from being bored.

Arriving at the tree/home where his flight had begun he was surprised to find that they'd left the door open and unlocked. On most prim worlds he'd visited you wouldn't do that under any circumstances, though it really didn't matter as anyone who would check to see if the door was locked would be just as likely to break the door down as to be turned away by the minor obstacle. Still he had to admit that it was convenient that they didn't have to fiddle with a lock and key before going inside.

Once inside most of the party stopped eyeing him for the moment as they began to take seats in what Amadeus took to be the living room, which was laid out along the lines of similar dwelling places he'd seen on a dozen different worlds, with many chairs facing the odd box which would display pictures when it received unique waves through the air that contained imaging data. This model had buttons, which usually indicated the ability to handle colored images using a system of mixing red, blue, and green, though since the majority of his party were canine, and most canines were color blind, he wondered why they bothered.

"Ah it's good to be home," said one of the larger figures as he lit a candle and placed it in the center of the room, and his rabbit like form was outlined by its light. Still, the dim candle was emitting barely enough light for Amadeus to make out anything, and he squinted in the darkness at his hosts before Danielle obviously remembered the human focus on vision and lit another candle, placing it with its brother and amplifying the light of the two.

"Better?" she asked him, to the obvious puzzlement of the others.

"Much, thank you, Danielle," responded Amadeus as pleasantly as he could. For a moment the figures studied their latest addition as the latest addition studied them back. Before Amadeus was an odd mixture of various creatures, each with human form basics, but some features that just screamed animals. The most prevalent species were wolves, the young male who had aroused the ire of the spike haired figure before stood between two others, a male and a female, to whom Amadeus could see he bore at least some resemblance, though more towards the female than the male.

Behind those three stood another trio of figures, one gripping the older male wolf on his shoulders, though she appeared to be descended from some form of fox. Next to her stood another wolf female, this one far older looking that the one sitting down, though he thought she carried her years with grace and stamina, and finally standing behind the young male wolf was another fox, who might have been related to the female fox, though her ears were much larger.

On another sofa sat a literal bat boy and next to him the spike haired figure who'd hit the young wolf boy. Now in the light he could see the spikes were actually quills, and that the young woman was some form of porcupine or hedgehog. Beside that pair sat the large bunny man who'd lit the first candle, his eyes on the human even as he wove his arms protectively around a young baby sized rabbit he had sitting on his knee.

On the final sofa in the house sat the bunny girl from before and her fox husband, whom Amadeus assumed was the one who he'd seen in the entrance hall just before running off. The two made an odd looking couple to the human, though not the oddest he'd ever seen. After all one did not ply the spaceways without finding some very odd matches that seemed so wrong, yet were stronger than even the old Romeo and Juliet bond had been. Taking a moment Amadeus realized they'd been siting in silence for awhile, and he felt it needed to be broken, though he wasn't sure if he was allowed to speak now, being the guest, or what.
11221211.title: Shoes, home, and silence

choices: He talks about the Combine, the sweeping human govenrment
The lights come on, interrupting him
112212111.content:
"So then, where am I?" asked Amadeus, breaking the silence that had settled over the room. The others, who had been intently studying him, all turned to one another as if looking for answers, but it was the hedgehog who spoke up first.

"Your in our home, in the town of Domain, that's the best we can give you," she said simply, and after considering things for a moment the others in the group nodded.

"Well, at least I have a planet name, even if it is a common one. So Danielle, how about you tell me how an IRS agent got from the United States of America to this place?" asked Amadeus.

"Why don't you tell us how you got here first? Or better yet how about your name and where you came from?" responded the male fox beside Danielle. The others looked at him sharply, but the fox stood his ground, obviously trying to protect what Amadeus assumed to be his wife.

"Trust again. Okay then, my name is Amadeus Orman, and I'm from the planet Dedros in the Sarnok Galaxy's sector Foxtrot Hotel India, or FHI. I live on the southern landmass in a small city that has no name at the current time though I think the locals are petitioning that it be named Bob in honor of some old explorer, and I'm not sure how I got here specifically, so I was hoping the young lady could tell me how see can claim to be human, and yet clearly not be, and that might answer my own question about the how of my being here, and more importantly the how of me getting home," he told them matter-of-factly, and it seemed to stun them all into silence for a few moments before the hedgehog spoke again.

"You mean, you're not from Earth?" she asked.

"No, I'm not. I don't know of anyone who is, and I don't even believe that, that world exists, Mrs.?" he said questioningly, holding out his hand towards the hedgehog girl.

"Oh, I forgot, you don't know our names. I'm Lindesfare," she said pointing towards herself and then motioning towards the batboy beside her, "and this is Fenton"

"Over there is Kell, my step mom, and her brother Ralph and their mother. Beside her is Rudy, her son and my step brother, as well as his girlfriend Fiona, who's mother is behind her and is married to Ralph," she said pointing towards the lupine sofa, each figure bowing in turn as they were named.

"This large guy here is my dad, Kevin, and on his knee is his and Kell's child Coney," she said, motioning towards the bunny with his baby. Looking back over at the wolf woman he can just begin to see the similarity in her eyes and those of the young rabbit when Lindesfare turned his attention back towards her by motioning towards the last couch.

"And that is George, Fiona's father, and you already heard Danielle's name," she said. Nodding his head at each figure proved a bit dizzying for Amadeus, but he did so anyway and put up with the slight discomfort.

"It is a pleasure to meet all of you. As duly recognized Combine representative I have the honor of first contact with you world," he told the gathering, to some very odd glances from all concerned, most especially Danielle.

"Well then, now that that's out of the way, what is this Combine you keep talking about. You were asking about their consulate earlier?" asked Danielle, and Amadeus considered what he could tell them. They were obviously not ready to hear everything about the Combine and its history, and nor was he the right one to tell a grand sweeping story of that nature, but he also didn't want to offend them by remaining silent on the subject.
112212111.title: Introductions

1122121111.content:
"The Combine is exactly what you think it is, a government of the people, for the people, and by the people," he told them, looking for their reaction. Seeing the blank looks on their faces Amadeus reached behind his head and scratched it, trying to rake out of his addled mind the words in English which he knew by heart in Combine Basic.

"Okay, how about this, the Combine is a loose alliance of humans which rules about, well I have to think for a minute," he said, scratching his chin as he sat back in his chair.

"What was that number again?" he muttered to himself, tapping his head with his fist.

"Oh forget it," he said eventually, rising up from his leaning position to look the gathering straight on again.

"It rules approximately 10*10^50632 power systems totally, as well as bits and pieces of other various star systems. All in all we control only three galaxies completely, but we have spread out into so many others I can't keep track anymore," Amadeus told them, and he could see that both Lindesfare and Danielle were taken aback by the number, while some of the others obviously didn't understand what he'd just told them, or were simply incapable of comprehending a number with that many zeroes.

"That's a lot of systems," commented Lindesfare at last.

"I guess it is. We've yet to encounter anyone bigger," said Amadeus, then looking around at his hosts, some of whom probably outweighed him by a few kilos he thought about what he'd just said and add, "Astronomically speaking of course."

"Big deal," said Rudy, getting a glare of hatred from his step-sister.

"Actually, Rudy, it's like multiplying this planet millions of times and then doing that again, and probably again," said Lindesfare, and Rudy considered that for a moment, recalling how big his planet really was from his venture into space, and then getting a blank look on his face when it occurred to him just how big a number that was.

"Woah," he said at last, and Lindesfare smiled at Amadeus.

"Woah is a pretty good way to describe it," responded Amadeus, returning the hedgehog girl's smile.

"So you said loose alliance, what do you mean by that?" asked Danielle, intrigued to hear anything that had to do with humans.

"Well, we humans have never been that good at grouping together as other races. Get more than two humans in a single place and you usually have fist fights within minutes," he told them, and Danielle got a few looks from the gathering, as they silently asked her if this was true. Thinking back to her own world for a moment Danielle was forced to admit that violence was second nature to humans, and that Amadeus' words rang true.

"Yeah, I guess that's true," she said sheepishly.

"More than true. We humans are quite competitive compared to most of the races we've encountered, and our competitions seem to have a knack for finding ways of becoming deadly," added Amadeus.

"The Combine is basically a government that's not a government. It allows the individual to do as they please, so long as they don't try and interfere in the affairs of the other individuals. That seems kind of counter productive to a society, but we have certain technologies that help make it work," said Amadeus, stopping to consider just how much he was allowed to tell the group before him about Combine technology, and just how much they could understand even if he did tell them.

Whatever he was going to say about the tech, and whatever questions they were going to ask were cut off as the lights in the room snapped back to life, forcing everyone to cover their eyes for a moment as they adjusted from the dim candle light to the overhead ceiling light which now shone brightly from above.

"Well, at least we've got power again. Maybe we should continue this tomorrow after those of us who aren't used to staying up all night have had a bit of a nap," said Danielle, getting up from her seat and turning down the brightness of the overhead light to make it easier to see.

"I guess it might be a good ide-" began Kevin, before being interrupted by an odd sound. The ringing sound attracted every eye in the room as it came from...
1122121111.title: A bit about the Combine

11221211112.content:
"That's me," said Amadeus. Reaching behind his back Amadeus pulled a small catch on the side of his belt's back pouch, and pulled the flap of the pouch up to reveal a small handheld device that looked like a palm top computer, though there seemed to be no physical interface for the device.

"Zee, buddy, are you online again yet?" he asked of the small device, and the screen blossomed into animated life as a series of colored rings flowed outwards from the center of the screen, slowly filling it with the image of a human face.

"Exor nabasihi ertos," said a human voice that came from the small device, and the face in the screen was obviously the one making the strange words.

"Osto normkan zyta," responded Amadeus, annoyance present in the tone of his voice.

"Zyta orvika?" asked the small device.

"Yes, now start speaking in that language before I rip out your logic string and floss with it, bit brain," said Amadeus, and the device chirp something out in a kind of machine language which set Amadeus to striking it with his palm.

"There are ladies and a baby present, so none of that now," he told the device, before setting in on the ground in front of his chair.

"Watch this everyone. Zee, you can come out of your box now," said Amadeus, and the little pad on the ground began to beep again, though this time in a lower pitched key. For a moment the beeping was relentless, and then without any warning at all it stopped, and the little pad leaped into the air, floating before the assembled group, most of which jumped back in surprise, to Amadeus' amusement.

After hanging in the air and spinning for a few seconds the little device began to emit a new sound, and as the group looked on the sound was soon accompanied by what looked to be a bubble that formed on the skin of the device and slowly pushed outward. The bubble, a perfect sphere at first glance, was soon dotted with lumps which grew larger as the bubble expanded outward, and within moments the bubble was now in the shape of a human male, an outline without form or substance.

Slowly again the bubble began to fill. Small squares of color and form began to appear on the clear outline of the man, giving him flesh and clothes that matched Amadeus, though he face was slightly different in shape. After a few seconds of filling in the man who had been an empty bubble a moment ago took in a breathe and opened his eyes, which were bright green in the soft glow of the ceiling light overhead. Looking around at the assembled group the man born of the strange device turned back to Amadeus and looked at him angrily.

"Do you have any idea how annoying it is to be woken up from a restful sleep because you got lost again?" asked the man of Amadeus.

"No, but then again, I'm the one getting lost," he responded, smiling at the man, who was obviously annoyed even more by Amadeus' lack of compassion for his circumstances.

"You know, I have half a byte to leave you and go back into sleep mode," said the man, waving his finger warningly in Amadeus' face.

"But you won't," responded Amadeus, and the man was about to yell at him again when he froze in mid gesture and just stared into Amadeus' eyes.

"You're right. I won't, but only because I'll get blamed if you get yourself killed, and I hate being blames for slag like that. So where are we anyway?" asked the man, looking around again at the varied group in which he and Amadeus found themselves.

"Well, our spiked friend says this is the town of Domain, and this s specifically the home of the Dewclaw family," said Amadeus.

"Anything more general, like how about what galaxy this is?" asked the man.

"Nope, but you should be able to find out pretty quick. Danielle said this is an alternate dimension, so how about starting there first. Do a quantum pulse and see where we are," Amadeus told the man, who nodded gravely and then went rigid where he stood, closing his eyes to the world around him. For a moment he was frozen where he stood, like a statue, and then he opened his eyelids to reveal that his eyes had been replaced by green lit numbers that flashed across the space where they had been.

"This could take a few minutes," commented Amadeus as he leaned back in his chair. The others, still surprised by the forming of their latest member from a small handheld computer were staring at the man with unadulterated interest. After a while Danielle finally looked over to Amadeus and gestured towrds the man.

"Who is this?" she asked Amadeus point blank, and Amadeus chuckled a bit before leaning forward again and facing everyone, who were all staring at him again waiting for an answer.

"His name is Zee, he's a CAP, or Cyber Assistant Program. He's kind of my guardian, and he helps me to find my way home when I get sucked through interdimensional wormholes. Hopefully he's able to figure out where this planet is in relation to the Combine and we get gone before we interfere to much with your culture," said Amadeus. Rudy, looking over at the man and then at his CAP. Leaning forward slightly the young wolf boy stuck his finger into Zee's skin, and was surprised to find that it felt real.

"Woah," he said, mimicking almost exactly the tone he'd had earlier when he'd realized how big the Combine was.

"Yeah, Zee is a piece of work. Great fighter too, once he gets into the battle, but don't tell him I said that," Amadeus told them, and before anyone could say anything else Zee closed his eyelids again, and opened them to reveal the green eyes he'd had before.

"Boss, you're not gonna like this," said Zee, turning to face Amadeus.

"What is it Zee? Are we in an unknown dimension?" asked Amadeus of Zee.

"That's part of the good news in all this. We're in a known dimension, one the Combine's explored, well, after all it is the home dimension of the Combine itself," said Zee.

"You mean?" asked Amadeus.

"Yes, we're currently 27 along the Tau, 36 along the Teh, and one along the Tec axis of time, which is home," said Zee, staring Amadeus in the eye.

"Well then what's the problem? Just contact the Combine and get us a ride home," said Amadeus, not understanding why Zee hadn't already done this.

"That's the part you aren't gonna like. We may still be in the home dimension, but I have no idea where we are in it. My gravimet array can't ID any of the local galaxies" said Zee.

"What are you talking about? If we're home you should be able to find at least one reference point, unless your gravimet is busted," responded Amadeus.

"I thought of that, but I ran all three system checks, and they confirm that it's operational at one-hundred over one-hundred efficiency. My sensors are perfect, but we aren't anywhere near the explored parts of this universe," said Zee defensively to Amadeus.

"How is that possible?" demanded Amadeus.

"Well we've only explored about nineteen percent of the universe, so we're just in one of those pieces we haven't been to ye-ugh!" Zee, who had been standing tall and straight gripped his head in pain and went to his knees. Immediately Amadeus was at his side, staring with great concern at the form of Zee, which wavered, becoming a hollow bubble again before regaining it's solidity.

"Zee, what is it?" asked Amadeus.

"I don't know, some kind of massive data stream. I was searching for something to try and help find out where we are and I synced with it for a second," said Zee, his face pale with weakness as Amadeus helped him to his feet again.

"Let me, try again, this time, I'll connect slower," Zee told Amadeus, and he went rigid again, though this time he did not close his eyes, which stayed human looking. It was many moments before Zee moved again, and when he did he had a wide eyed look that bespoke of wonder.

"Amadeus, I know where we are," he told his human companion breathlessly.

"Well, that's some good news. What was it you connected with that told you where we are?" asked Amadeus.

"The Archive, boss," said Zee, as if that explained everything, though even Amadeus eyed the CAP after his statement.

"Okay then, if you can connect t an Archive then you can get us a ride home," said Amadeus, not understanding why connecting to an Archive, one of the huge databases the Combine used, would cause Zee to go into a fit.

"Boss, I don't mean an Archive. I mean The Archive," said Zee, putting an emphasis on the word ‘The'. For a moment the room was silent as the group tried to figure out what The Archive was, but Amadeus was mouthing wordlessly a thousand questions that popped into his mind at the statement that Zee had just made.

"Wait a minute, you mean The THE Archive?" he asked, and Zee nodded at him silently.

"That The Archive, the one on Earth?" he asked again, his own voice sounding weak as he asked the question.

"Yes, that one," declared Zee, excitement obvious on his face.

"Impossible. Now I know your malfunctioning. There is no way in the stars that what you just said is correct," Amadeus told him, and Zee shook his head.

"But it is Deus. It is," stated Zee simply.

"No. No way. Play the last message then. That will prove this isn't the Archive," said Amadeus, and Zee complied, sticking his hands out palms forward. An instant later streams of light shot from the flats of his palms, and together they slowly formed the image of a human woman with dark skin, and deep set eyes. Her features were those of someone who'd been fighting too many battles, and losing them more often than not. Sighing she faced the camera which was recording her and stared into the future from the distant past.

"Hello there. I'm not sure who is seeing this message, or even if you can understand me. Not that it matters. After all the way they designed this system it's doubtful anyone will ever even know it exists, or be able to access it," said the three dimensional image of the woman, which looked fake, especially when compared to Zee.

"My name is Alice, and I have the sad duty to record this message for the future visitors to our once beautiful world of Earth. I am called the Secretary General of the United Nations by my people, which is an office that has in recent years grown in power to being near ruler of our world, or at least the closest we've ever had," she told whoever it was who was seeing the message in the far distant future.

"This is my last day on Earth. Most of our people boarded the Ark ships days ago, and left to find new worlds to inhabit, because we have so messed up this one. It is our hope that you who are viewing this are the descendants of those of us who travel to the stars, and that you have returned to help heal the damage we wrought on our mother earth, though I doubt we will ever return. After all, our past attempts to heal have only caused that much more hurt," said the woman, looking away from the camera, shame evident in her face.

"Whatever the case, be you our descendants or some race which he cannot fathom, know that you now stand on Earth, the birthplace of humanity. We hope that you treat her more kindly than we have," said the woman simply, before the message cut off. Everyone in the room was silent as the light vanished back into Zee's hands and every eye turned towards Amadeus, who looked at his feet with an expression of pain on his face. Before anyone could react or say anything Amadeus bolted up from where he sat and rushed for the door. Slamming it open he rushed into the night.
11221211112.title: Meeting Zee

112212111121.content:
Danielle sat still for only a moment after Amadeus' rush out the door before bolting after him, pursuing him into the darkness outside. George, with reflexes of a hunter, made to go after her, but was surprised to find that the instant his wife was out the door it shut again, and he was unable to open it. Looking down he saw that a hand was holding it shut, and that the hand was attached to a now many meter arm that eventually led back to Zee.

"Let go of the door!" he demanded, and Zee shook his head.

"Listen George, those two need a bit of alone time right now," said Zee, and George was about to argue when a thought occurred to him.

"How do you know my name?" he asked, realizing that the computer entity had never been told the names of those in their group.

"Amadeus told me through telink. Basically he linked his mind with my processor and we had a very long discussion about you guys, and where he thought we were. When you saw us arguing in Combine Basic we were establishing a connection, and then after that, when I emitted a low pitched tone we linked and he told me your names. Or at least the names he knows," added Zee as an after thought, realizing that three of the individuals in the group had been given as relations, not names.

"Alright then, now how about letting go of the door so I can go after my wife?" asked George, who had been trying to open the door all through Zee's explanation.

"No, I won't, for the reason that right now Danielle and Amadeus have something very important in common," said Zee, who motioned for George to take his seat. Unable to open the door against the surprising strength of the hologram George did so and stared with venom in his gaze at Zee.

"What do you mean they have something very important in common? That they're human?" he asked, trying to understand why the computer wouldn't let him go after the two.

"No way. If that was all they had in common I'd go after them myself to keep them from killing each other. No what they have in common is that they both lost their homes, and have very little chance of going back," said Zee, and everyone was forced to remember that Danielle came from another world, and though she had given it up by choice, she still missed it.

"But I'm her husband," protested George.

"What? Are you worried that Amadeus will try to get between you two? Don't worry about it. If he even thought about something like that Jasmine, his only real friend back home, would skin him, and then I myself would rub salt in his wounds," responded Zee, though his words didn't seem to be that much comfort to George, who continued to stare at the door like he was going to make a break for it.

"Well, why aren't you as upset as he obviously is by being stranded here?" asked George, trying to distract Zee.

"Because this is Earth we're stranded on," he said as it that was explanation enough, but everyone's looks told him it wasn't.

"Listen, Earth is the homeworld for humans, and of course those like me born from humans. Its location has been lost for a very long time, and now, we find it. I doubt you can ever understand the significance of that, but to me and to a lot of people back home, this is a great day. Eventually I'll be able to get home, if only by building a beacon and sending out a call for help, but boss. Well humans only live so long, just like all biologics. Humanity has been searching for this planet for thousands of years, and there is a good chance that even with a beacon to guide them they won't find it for millennia yet," said Zee, looking out the window by the door, which now had a few stars staring through it as the clouds over head were finally blown away.

Outside, racing through the underbrush, Danielle followed the scent of Amadeus towards the west. Amadeus, used to a higher gravity, was making good time even in his climbing shoes, but Danielle had been living on the world for months, and had learned the area around the Dewclaw's home well enough to find easier paths through the woods. It wasn't long before she caught up with Amadeus, who stood in front of a babbling brook, gazing at his reflection in the water.

"You know, hearing about this world in the history books I expected it to still be covered waste deep in slime and muck," said Amadeus to her, without turning.
