"You would find it too, if the birds hadn't altered time," she said, sitting down beside him.

"What?" he asked, staring at her with a raised eyebrow.

"The birds. When I first got here from my world I was captured by birds, and then just as I was trying to leave two more came and went to my world, saying that the balance had to be restored. After that we came back home and one of them told us everything, or at least enough to make a good picture of what happened," she told him, staring down at their reflections in the darkened water, which were becoming more clear as more stars were revealed by the clouds blowing away.

"They said that humans messed up that planet so bad they finally left, and that the birds, being the only animals able to fly above the sludge that now covered the surface, evolved into sentient beings and used some left behind equipment to go back and change the past, taking humans out, and replacing them with animals that had been altered, made smarter," she told him, almost word for word what she'd been told.

"Hmm. That explains it. Those birds probably mistook the Tempus technology for a time machine. That's why we lost track of where Earth was. It shifted position in relation to the Arks, probably while they were still flying through space," commented Amadeus.

"What do mean ‘mistook'? You mean that the birds didn't find a time machine?" asked Danielle, obviously confused.

"No it wasn't. After all the Tempus was supposed to help us repair the planet, now just make a splinter dimension where we never screwed it up in the first place. It didn't work right though, so we eventually abandoned it, and a bunch of other stuff, when we left. Or at least that's what some would have you believe," he told her, picking up one of the rocks that sat beside the water he began to toss it from hand to hand.

"So, the birds used Tempus to eliminate humans in the past, and then probably used the Morpheus gun to make animals sentient. That would explain that family I just walked out on, and the Tempus would explain how you came to be a bunny girl too," he told her, turning to face her.

"What do you mean?" she asked, watching as he picked up another rock and began to juggle the two stones.

"Well the Tempus is a quantum waveform manipulator. It alters waveforms to their past or future states, however we found that using it on a wide scale causes certain distortions in space time to occur, like the hole you said you came from," he said, tossing the rocks even faster.

"In order to prevent anyone who came through from experiencing quantum cascade, the effect in which a set of quantum twins exist together in the same dimension causing the visitor twin to begin decaying, we made it so that the Tempus will overlay the local waveform over the visitor. In effect the Danielle that existed here was cut and pasted onto you," he explained as he picked up a third rock and added it to his juggling act.

"Well, I guess that explains why Lindesfare and I both look like those we are doubles of," she said, remembering Lindesfare's story about Fiona's mother, who had remained human after coming across the doorway, and wondering why she hadn't changed.

"Is there any way to prevent the cut and paste effect, say a barrel of something?" she asked him, wondering what could have prevented something that advanced from doing its job.

"A barrel? Well I guess it could, if it was full of some kind of byproduct of radiation, or a lead lined container. Both could cause the Tempus to view the object as a piece of that universe, but once opened, if the twin existed within the universe they traveled to, then the object or person would begin to decay, and literally vanish before your eyes. I'm guessing something like that happened," he said, knowing that Danielle wouldn't have asked unless it was so, and her nod told him he was right.

"It happened to Fiona's mother. It's why she was looking at you weirder than the others. She had a human body for a while, and I guess seeing you brings back memories she'd rather forget," said Danielle, watching as Amadeus added another stone to his collection, keeping all four in the air easily.

"I hope she can get over that, after all I'm not going to be leaving any time soon," he said in a lonely voice, staring up at the stars.

"Well then, you'll just have to do what I did. Make this place your home," said Danielle, and Amadeus smiled at her.

"Maybe. That's gonna take a bit of doing though. If that family is any indication this world isn't exactly a kind place," he told her, picking up a fifth rock with his foot and tossing it into the fray with the others.

"It's an okay place once you get to know it. I mean I found George here, and I'm sure if you looked you could find someone," she told him, not the slightest hint of lust in her voice.

"Well, maybe. Jasmine would be a bit miffed, but then again we never did have that close a relationship," he said, more to himself than to Danielle.

"Who's Jasmine?" asked the bunny woman out of curiosity.

"Jazz is a friend from home. We Game together all the time, taking parties of new recruits into the depths of Hel's realm, or up against the Empire and the evil Vader, though our latest ones have always involved getting a Yggdrasil plant away from a dragon atop a mountain. We have yet to win it, but we're getting...I mean we were getting closer. Who knows, maybe she got it, after all when I left we were near the top, and the rest of the party was still in flawless condition," he said, correcting his grammar because he knew he might never get to finish playing the Game now.

"Wow...sounds like quite a woman," said Danielle, somewhat sarcastically.

"She is, though I think she likes Zee more than me," he said, remembering all the times the two had wandered off together in the Games.

"Wait a minute, Zee is a computer program, isn't he?" she asked, remembering the thing that had come out of Amadeus' PDA.

"Well, yes, but that's not too much of a problem in the Combine. Heck, I've been suspecting that Jazz might be an AI herself, but I can't prove it, and it doesn't matter. She thinks, therefore she is, the motto of the Combine," he said, tossing all five rocks in succession towards a stone on the other bank of the stream. Each one struck the stone in turn, creating an ever brightening array of sparks that lit the night for a few seconds before fading away.

"Don't you mean, she thinks like a human, therefore she is," said a familiar voice and the two turned to find that they had gained company to watch as the sun slowly rose over the horizon. It was Zee and..
112212111121.title: Learning about each other

1122121111212.content:
"Hey Zee," said Amadeus, rising from his sitting position. Danielle rose as well, but she looked into George's eyes and saw a bit of an accusing look that made her look away.

"Oh, come on George, I told you boss doesn't do those kind of things. Heck, I'm not even sure he can do those with your wife," said Zee, gently striking George on the arm and looking down at Amadeus, his own gaze full of laughter and amusement. Amadeus, realizing for the first time that Danielle's coming to him could be seen as somewhat unfaithful, glared daggers at the CAP, who only seemed more amused.

"That's not funny Zee. George, I'm sorry if you think something happened between me and Danielle, but you should have a bit more faith in her. She really likes you, we just had a discussion about some things," said Amadeus, and the others of the group all looked at George, who's fury ebbed at seeing the shame in his wife's face. Shame he knew was for him being suspicious, and not for her being unfaithful.

"You're right, I should, but you are the first one of her own kind she's seen in a while, and well... oh I'm an idiot. I'm sorry Danielle," he said at last, and Danielle's face was broken by a smile. The two raced to each other, and soon everyone was standing on a slight slope over looking the brook as first the false dawn, and then the true dawn finally began to light the area.

"So De-Light, you ready?" asked Zee, using his pet name for Amadeus which he pronounced Daylight.

"As ready as I can be bit brain, and since you brought the audience, I think I should get to decide the rules," responded Amadeus, nodding at Zee.

"Fine," said Zee, stepping away from the group who were staring at the two humans with questioning looks. Amadeus, who seemed to have forgotten that they were watching, undid the shoulder belt to which his axe was clipped and then his real belt to which his gun and pouch were connected. Gathering up the two belts he folded the gun belt over the shoulder one and held them out to Danielle.

"Can you take these for me for a minute?" he asked, and Danielle, though slightly confused, took the offered items. Next Amadeus reached down and untied the laces for his boots, which he slipped off to reveal that his polymer mesh suit was full body, covering even his feet in it's thin membrane. Free of everything but the body suit Amadeus ran out so that he and Zee were facing each other across a small clearing of grass.

"Rules are simple. No weapons, yield win," said Amadeus, drawing a line in the loose dirt using his heel. Zee responded likewise and then bowed across the way at Amadeus.

"With each new day," began Amadeus.

"Comes the promise of a new battle," finished Zee, and without another word the two charged at each other, both dropping low and holding out their arms so that they appeared to be birds of prey swooping in for the kill. As they collided Amadeus fell to the ground, sliding forward with his legs held out in a v shape. As he met Zee he brought his legs together, intending to take Zee to the ground with the scissor movement. Zee, knowing the move was coming, leaped into the air to avoid it, and then came down fist first.

Seeing the attack from the air, Amadeus rolled to the side, sliding out of the way as Zee plummeted to the ground, burying his fist in the dirt with the force of his blow. Without a pause Amadeus struck, using his feet again he delivered a low kick to Zee's head, which was in perfect position thanks to his stooped over posture. The blow sent the CAP flying several feet into the air before coming down in a slide that ended with his head slamming into a tree.

For a time it appeared the fight might already be over, as Zee did not move after the impact, but Amadeus did not rise from his stance as he approached, holding his hands at a level where he could send a straight and powerful punch at anything in front of him. His walk was guarded as he got near the still form of Zee, and it proved to be needed as Zee suddenly bolted up, and the two began to punch at each other so fast their fists became blurs.

To the untrained eyes of the watchers the two fighters seemed to be the exact same in style and power, though to the two fighting they knew the difference between their strengths was large, and that their styles were designed to take advantage of their individual skills. Were Zee was pushing aside the punches thrown by Amadeus, allowing the fists to come closer, but letting them do less damage than Amadeus' style, in which he blocked the punches using his forearm, forcing him to absorb the blows, but not letting them as close to his body.

The punches continued to fly between the pair as they slowly walked away from the edge of the clearing until they stood in the center again, with the group of anthromorphs watching the battle rage on. The sun, which had only just arisen, caused the two fighter to appear as blazing outlines in its golden light.

At last the stalemate ended in a draw as Zee drove his left fist into Amadeus' face while at the same time Amadeus did the same to him. The two hung in the air for a second as they absorbed the power of the other's blow and then flew across the clearing a short ways before falling to he dirt and sliding a ways. Zee used the moment of his slide to flip, doing a headstand for a brief moment before standing upright again and facing his foe with a look of childlike amusement in his eyes.

Amadeus slid a bit farther than Zee and used his fingers to stop his slide, digging them into the ground to kill his momentum. Looking towards Zee he growled in fury, and watched as the CAP leaped into the tree above him, and grabbing a branch he swung onto it, landing in a standing position atop it. Amadeus, not one to be left in the dust, rolled to his feet and then leaped up himself, copying Zee's maneuver to land on the branch in a standing position.

Staring at each other across the clearing the two fighters simply waited, each taking a moment to gauge the other's strength, before Amadeus broke the stillness by leaping onto the end of his branch and using it as a kind of diving board, leaping towards Zee. Responding in kind Zee flew into the air to meet him and the two collided in the air, exchanging two punches before each ended up in the tree in which their opponent had started, though a branch or two farther up, and before either could really recover they both launched into the air again, to similar results.

The ballet in the air continued for four more leaps until both had reached the tops of the trees in which they had originally started. Now atop the trees the diving board trick wouldn't work, but Zee figured out the solution to the problem, leaning back on his tree so that it leaned slightly, and then using it like a catapult to fling him across the clearing at Amadeus, who copied the technique. When the two met this time in flight Zee was slightly lower due to his tree's height, and the two hit each other, changing the paths of their flights so that Zee plummeted to the ground and Amadeus rose upward before arcing down as well.

Zee, who had his back to the ground, struck the dirt hard and created a slight impression as he did so. Amadeus, who had a bit more time to prepare for his impact, rolled just as he hit the ground, and leaped up into a standing position just in time to get tackled by Zee who seemed unfazed by his recent landing. Holding his arms across Amadeus' neck in a v shape he pinned the man to the ground and squeezed slightly before letting up and staring him in the face.

"Yield?" asked the CAP of his human.
1122121111212.title: A Friendly Spar

choices: Follow Zee on his day in Domain
Stay with Amadeus and see what he dreams
11221211112122.content:
Amadeus looked like he was about to respond with a bad word when he suddenly spit in Zee's face, causing the AI to rear back in surprise. Taking advantage of this Amadeus slammed his hands into Zee's chest using the flats of his palms like battering rams to send the poor electronic entity flying into a tree, this time rushing after him and holding his own arms in a v over Zee's neck.

"How about you?" asked Amadeus, this time smiling himself. Zee looked slightly hurt, but stood silently for a moment not saying anything before nodding. Laughing Amadeus let him rise to his feet and the two clasped hands.

"I thought you said no weapons?" asked Zee.

"I did, but I don't think spit usually qualifies. Well not for humans anyway," responded Amadeus as the two walked back towards the stunned on lookers, who stood silently staring at the two who just moments ago had seemed to be trying to kill each other engage in a friendly conversation. Reaching the place where they stood Amadeus held out his hand and Danielle, realizing she was still holding his belts, handed them back to him. Placing both belts on the ground Amadeus opened the pouch on his gun belt and withdrew a small silver cylinder, which Danielle knew to be a flute, though the others didn't recognize the instrument because their world, with the varying shape to their mouths, had never developed it.

"So, since you won, that means you get to decide the story. Which one do you want De-light?" asked Zee as he took position behind him. The others, not understanding watched as the human stared into the sky for a silent moment before turning back to his companion.

"How about the Serpent of Shadows? I like it," said Amadeus. Zee seemed ready to object for a moment, but thought better of it, and then sighing he stood behind Amadeus who had sat down cross-legged on the grass. Putting the flute to his lips Amadeus blew a few notes, and Zee used them to tune himself, singing in a high tenor to compliment the high notes of the flute. At last the two were ready and Amadeus began to play an airy tune as Zee hummed along, before he spoke the words to the old poem in a beautiful voice.

Listen to me and I'll spin the yarn,
about a creature that caused all great harm.
Within the darkness did it lay low,
Watching the stars, its eyes all aglow.

And from there Zee began to sing about a creature called the Vorka, a serpentine thing that dwelt, according to his song and the pictures he created in the air in the same way as the image of the woman before, within the heart of a neutron star. Slowly it came out that the Vorka was a creature of darkness, designed by a foul race as a weapon, and let loose in the universe to destroy their enemies by burrowing into a star and causing it to collapse in on itself.

As with most weapons of that kind it eventually turned on its makers, destroying them as well, and continuing unopposed through the heavens until meeting up with a Combine vessel called the Eternal Vengeance. Whether true or not the group watch transfixed as the images of the rocket like craft did battle with the serpent, at last driving it into the one thing in the universe with more mass than itself, a black hole.

And there lads and lassies I end this tale,
Which happened long ago in the galaxy of Thale.
Now the monster has passed into ancient lore,
it eyes in the darkness glowing no more.

The song done Amadeus played a few more notes before finally ending his flute playing, and above him Zee showed one last image of the Eternal Vengeance as it flew away from the hole into which it had lured the great beast. The air in the clearing was still for a few minutes as the group began to digest what they'd just heard and seen. Rudy was the first to recover and step forward out of the group to stare at the human and computer duo.

"What was that?" he asked, his voice, though he tried to hide it, full of wonder at the story he'd just been told.

"It was the tale of a bard. Dad always told us that the bards of the old world were the greatest fighters, so me and Zee imitate them, taking the stories we hear about battles and turning them to song, though Zee insists on updating the performance by adding pictures," said Amadeus as he put the flute back in its pouch and re adorned his shoulder and gun belts as well as his climbing boots.

"Well, can you play it again?" asked Rudy, this time unable to hide how much he'd enjoyed the story.

"We would kid, but I think it best that we get somewhere and hide for right now, cause as accommodating as you folks are, some of your neighbors might ask some very pointed questions about us," said Zee, reminding the group that both he and Amadeus were human looking, which was quite different from the races of the world.

"So, since we're not leaving for awhile, does anyone have any place we can bunk at?" asked Amadeus, looking at the group. Fenton, the batboy, was the first to raise his hand and point at a nearby tree.

"Tree still has a spare bedroom, and it's closest, so why don't you two go there?" he offered, and the group nodded in agreement. Amadeus and Zee, needing no more prodding made their way towards the indicated dwelling. Most of the others, yawning due to the lack of sleep from the night before, went towards their own homes, to start the business of their day. Rudy asked his parents if he could stay home from school before his family was out of ear shot, but Amadeus could almost feel his mother's glare on the young wolfboy indicating his answer.

"Burned kid," commented Amadeus as he and Zee raced over the morning dewed grass, silver droplets flying in the air at their passing. The two were still not fast enough to catch up with Fenton, who even carried Lindesfare in one hand as he flew through the air to his home. When they arrived everyone looked around a bit nervously, but was relieved to find that the forest's diurnal were just waking up, and the nocturnal ones were already in bed, and had been for some time. Thinking themselves lucky the four went into the tree, which Amadeus recognized as the one that had talked to him earlier that morning.

"Tree, I'm home, and I have guests," said the bat, and the tree seemed to vibrate with joy.

"I can see that Fentonm and recognize Lindesfare, but who are the other two. Wait a second, one of them was in my branches earlier tonight," said the tree, though how it recognized him Amadeus didn't know. Fenton and Lindesfare stopped as they remembered that they had indeed discovered Amadeus laying in a heap beside Tree earlier.

"That's right, we found you at the foot of Tree. How'd you wind up there?" asked Lindesfare.

"Well I climbed to the top of...?" he said, wondering what gender the plant was but then assuming from the voice that it was female.

"As I was saying, I climbed all the way up Ms. Tree to get a better look around and see if the bunny girl or her lupine friend was following me. I know now that the bunny girl was Danielle, and the lupine was probably George, though at the time I didn't think they would be friendly, so I was going to stay in the tree and hide when she spoke to me, and I was so surprised I lost my balance and fell. She caught me, and stopped me from really hurting myself, and then you guys found me," said Amadeus, telling his side of the tale.

"Oh, ok. Well then I guess we're gonna turn in. I don't suppose humans are nocturnal and sleep during the day?" asked Fenton, wondering if they would have to put up with Zee and Amadeus talking while he and Lindesfare tried to sleep. They had already silently agreed that he would take Lindesfare back to college later, as the human was going to be much more interesting than any of her classes for a while.

"Well normal humans aren't, but I'm a Gamer, so I've learned to sleep when I can, and right now a few hours of REM sounds good. How about you Zee?" asked Amadeus of his CAP.

"I don't require sleep, though I do like the chance to power down and recharge to full. Today however I think I'll take some time and explore this world if you don't mind, boss," said the AI, looking out at the slowly awakening world outside the window.

"Wait, I thought you wanted to stay hidden?"asked Fenton, confused about how Zee could explore the world outside without exposing Amadeus. Zee did not say anything, and instead demonstrated his adaptability by changing before Fenton and Lindesfare's eyes into a shorter, though bulkier, wolf much like Kell and her family.

"I can stay hidden if I need to. De-light may stand out like a lamp in a dark house, but I can blend in when the situation requires," said Zee, moving towards the door and looking askance at Amadeus.

"Okay, but try not to disrupt this place too much," said Amadeus, and before he even took in another breathe the CAP was out the door and gone.

"Well then, where should I sleep?" asked Amadeus of his hosts. Fenton led him to the spare bedroom, which they discovered was not going to suit the human well as the bed was designed for Fenton, being a stick hanging out of the wall.

"Oops. I forgot. We gave the bed to your uncle the other day Lindesfare. I guess we don't have a spare bed. Maybe you can make it to Fiona's. She lives in a mansion and there should be at least one spare bed there," commented Fenton, but outside many people were already up and about, and there was no way to get Amadeus to her house without attracting suspicion.

"Well, there is a couch. If you guys don't mind it too much I can sleep on it," suggested Amadeus as they passed the sitting room where a sofa sat facing a TV. Fenton and Lindesfare looked at each other with some concern before turning to face Amadeus again.

"I guess that works, but you should mind the quills. Lindesfare lost quite few in that couch," warned Fenton. Amadeus, looking at the hedgehog girl's quills new them to be no laughing matter, but without testing with his hand he fell onto the sofa and laid on it. Feeling a prick in his back he pulled out half a dozen quills, none of which had pierced his suit. Seeing their guest was comfortable the pair went back to Fenton's room, which soon echoed with the sounds of snores. Feeling his own eyes getting heavy Amadeus too fell into the land of dreams.
11221211112122.title: Modern Bards and Homes

choices: watched the course of events without intruding
dove into the street and saved the girl
112212111121221.content:
CAP designated ZX3A-Virtue's journal entry number 7-09-06934. After our arrival on what I can now confirm to be Old Home Terra my partner Amadeus and I are still getting used to the particulars of our new circumstances, recorded Zee to himself as he walked away from Tree towards the main part of the city, which he had been told was called Domain. An odd name for a city, though considering the origins of the residence it seemed somewhat appropriate.

I find it odd to breath in the air that so many people have searched so long for, and know that only hours ago neither Amadeus nor myself even believed this planet existed. Chalking it right up there with the legends of Vida, the diamond planet, and the Guardian's Gate, an artifact that can supposedly transport one between dimensions along the Tec axis of time, something no known science has been able to do on purpose, though accidents have occurred, continued the CAP as he dropped to all fours and began running like a wolf. Oddly it felt more natural than the bipedal posture which he had been using, something that he would have to question his hosts about later.

As stated in previous entries I believe that Amadeus is unique, even for a human type mind set. His initial reaction to the data regarding our location was flight, and after only a few minutes of juggling rocks he came to accept his circumstances. I find myself drawn back to mother's speech about how Orman males usually juggled rocks when they needed to think something out. She said it helped them to see things as a moving whole rather than a frozen snapshot, Zee said internally to his secondary processor, which would record his thoughts for later viewing by himself.

Whatever the case I find this new world to be an intriguing place, and am quite sure that Amadeus will as well once he fully gets over his disappointment at being pulled away from Dedros and Jasmine. However once he does become interested in this place I must find some way to get him to blend in. This is a world of eat or be eaten, and while Amadeus' battle skills are exemplary, I do not believe them to be sufficient for his protection on a planet where he will be viewed by a large percentile of the population as food stuff, observed Zee as he at last encountered the road he had been expecting to find.

Looking around he found no other creatures on the road, either driving in vehicles or walking along it as he himself was, though footpaths and other evidence suggested that the road was used to both kinds of traffic on a regular basis. It was highly likely that the power outage the previous night had disrupted some of the local fauna, causing some to oversleep or simply refuse to awaken with the morning. Zee, having been adversely affected himself, was ninety-three point five percent sure that the tunnel that had brought himself and Amadeus to Earth had been the cause, and that the EMP had effected the fauna directly as well, being that the lower functions of their brains would have been disrupted as well as their electronics.

The culture, which I discussed with the extended Dewclaw family during my first few active moments on this planet, seems to be an odd mixture of Polymer Age America, the time when that particular nation was experiencing odd upheavals due both to the economic situation of that age, as well as the lack of control over media, which in turn caused more than a little chaos as government secrets as well as unsubstantiated rumors reached the public in contexts that caused massive discontent that was most often not deserved, continued Zee as he started walking along the road in the direction of Domain.

Along with the American culture there are overtones which mimic Zevian culture. The Zevians, an insect-like race of Vodok-Ver, is known as one of the few species to continue practices of cannibalism after achieving space flight due to the lack of any other organism on their planet thanks to their ancestors appetites. This caused an odd evolutionary design where the race became caste like, with offspring servicing as food for stronger members of their race if they were slain. This system is still practiced in some Zevian colonies, though they also vary their diet with other food stuffs now, explained the CAP to himself, knowing that he might not recall the race right off upon later playings of his journal entry.

He stopped his internal musings as he at last came to the city's real limits and out of the suburbs in which his new acquaintances made their homes. He was not startled to find that the building design in the city varied greatly from the more natural ones outside. He spotted dozens of brick and mortar office buildings, as well as a few glass ones, which were a far cry from the caves and trees in which the population lived outside the urban area. Observing the rising of some of the locals he was intrigued to see the mixing of predator and prey in the streets of the early morning.

As he came to a halt at a cross walk he observed a family of rodents, apparently mice of some sort, as they made their way across town on foot. The mother in the lead appeared to be having a difficult time of keeping her younger children in line, though that was through no lack of trying. One of the youngsters, a female by her looks, got away from her mother and ran into the street after a small rubber ball which bounced in front of her.

Catching up with the toy the child stopped in the middle of the street, and Zee heard the sound of an approaching car just as it careened into view, going in excess of ninety-three kilometers an hour. Such a speed meant it would have no chance to stop, and he projected it's current course as intersecting the young mouse in less than two point oh eight seconds. The woman had a nine in four chance of grabbing her daughter back before she was splattered, but Zee was unsure if she would be able to.

Looking out at the girl he debated whether to save the life of the young one or to allow the natural events to occur, whatever they might be. Personally he would do whatever it took to preserve the life of another sentient, but in this case he was also aware of the fact that saving her would violate the noninterference in primitive cultures treaty that the Combine had signed. Considering everything in the span of a heartbeat Zee...
112212111121221.title: Zee's Choice

choices: Ok, let's go see your office
I think I'll explore on my own
1122121111212212.content:
Leaping forward Zee initially planed on grabbing the young mouse, but found that his new hand were much stronger than the human ones to which he had grown accustomed. Not wanting to hurt the child during his attempt to save her Zee did something that he had seen in nature films about wolves and other large quadrupeds and used his mouth to scoop up the rodent, hooking his teeth on the scruff of her neck, and then jumped forward just in time to avoid the incoming vehicle.

Rolling as he fell forward Zee tried to curl his body into a protective shell around the now screaming and crying mouse child, who was understandably afraid of her rescuer who had come at her mouth open. Luckily the child realized his intent was not to harm her very quickly, and rested still as his body absorbed the impact of their hitting the other side of the street with the full force he'd put behind his leap at her.

Once safely on the sidewalk again Zee uncurled his body and released the mouse girl on the ground, who was almost instantly grabbed by her mother's waiting arms, the woman and her children having crossed the intersection on the red light which the driver of the vehicle had in advertently run. The woman, with the child in her arms, looked over at her savior with wide eyes, and Zee was again reminded that to her species he looked like a predator.

"Thank you," she breathed out, still stunned by the rapid pace of the events previously. Zee noticed that several others were now looking toward him and the mouse woman, probably wondering why a wolf would save a mouse child. Zee, not caring about social graces at the moment, crossed his hands in a prayer gesture and bowed.

"Thank the Eye that it saw fit to give me the wisdom to save her," he said, wondering if he would be able to introduce the religion of the Eye to these people. Amadeus was a self-proclaimed irreligious bastard and would probably care less about what Zee did in that regard on this planet, but Zee still felt the tugs of the Combine at his heart, or rather what passed for his heart. He wasn't supposed to interfere in other cultures at all, let alone introduce new religions to them.

Without waiting for the woman to grasp his words or what they meant Zee turned on his heels and walked farther into the city, still unsure of where it was he was going. He never had a destination when he'd come here, intending only to watch the flow of the city, but he felt the eyes of the others on him, and he knew he would now have to pick a destination or risk having a small crowd follow him everywhere he went for a while. Luckily for the CAP a voice broke out over the bustle of the city, one he recognized from the morning's events.

"That was a very nice thing you did for that woman back there," said the voice of Kell Dewclaw, the wolf woman. Zee had modeled his current form off of her and her family, because they had been the most numerous of his selections the previous night, and thus they had the most attributes he could jumble together to make an original form for himself. Obviously he had done good work as Kell gave him a cursory sniff or two.

"Do I know you?" she asked after a moment, her olfactory senses recognizing her scent as well as that of her son, brother, and mother in Zee's. Not knowing how exactly to proceed with the crowd still looking at them Zee nodded.

"Yes Kell Dewclaw, you do. We met last night, remember I'm the out of town cousin visiting for a while," said Zee, hoping she'd play along. Zee hadn't really bothered with thinking about how he and Amadeus would fit into this new world, but being a cousin from out of town would help to make the transition easier for him, and from what he'd heard the night before the Dewclaw name carried a bit of clout, which would help him to defend Amadeus when he claimed him as a friend who was there with him.

Kell, looking at the strangely familiar wolf was still considering his words when she recalled the computer man who'd been born from a PDA carried by the human. She realized with a sudden shock that the CAP had somehow cut pasted attributes of herself and her family into a unique form, which had the odd effect of truly making her look related to him. Catching his drift and the story he was trying to lay Kell gave a slightly embarrassed laugh as they continued walking.

"Oh that's right. In the whole power outage incident I had forgotten about you and your friend. I feel so silly now, but I thought you and that strange friend of your's were going to be staying with Tree today," she said, taking Zee's arm and leading him towards what Zee recognized as a café of sorts, though the menu was not something he'd ever seen before, consisting of species rather than dish names. The crowd, seeing the odd wolf pair walk into the café considered it perfectly normal that someone related to Kell would save a mouse child like that, her being married to a rabbit and all.

Most would forget the incident by the end of the day, though the mouse woman's child would fondly tell her children stories about the big strong wolf that had stood between her an a monstrous truck, beating the thing back using the power of his howl. Kell and Zee were just as glad that he crowd blew off to the winds, going about their own business as they took a seat in the nearly deserted open air café, which was still in the process of opening.

"So what are you doing here? I thought you and the human were going to be hiding all day?" asked Kell in a hushed tone from behind one of the menus which she used to hide her face from the outside world. Considering the range of hearing of most of those passing by Zee wondered if the gesture was really worth it, but decided it best to respond in kind, putting his own menu into a standing position between him and the passing crowd.

"While my companion my require rest, especially after the night he had, I do not, and this planet, as I said before, is utterly fascinating to me. I wish to explore, and as you can see I can physically blend in when the situation calls for it," he told her, running his hand over his current form, showing that it now resembled her's quite nicely.

"Well, that's true enough. You even smell like I do. How do you do that if you're just a hologram?" she asked, relaxing a bit, probably having believed that some problem had arisen in getting Amadeus to Tree or that the sleeping quarters had proven insufficient for his needs. The latter would not prove true at all. As a Gamer Amadeus had been trained to sleep wherever he could, and had slept on battlefields, both real and Game, in the past.

"I am much more than a simple hologram. As I explained to you and your family earlier this morning I am a CAP, and that means I must be capable of many things, including scouting areas that would be dangerous for my companion to go. To do this properly we CAPs must be able to mimic anything in the environment, including its smell, texture, shape, and even taste," he told her, not explaining exactly how he did this because he knew she wouldn't understand.

"How would you know what I taste like?" asked Kell, interested more in his data collection now than how he had been able to mimic things.

"Quite simple. The smell coming off anything is formed by particulate matter being shed by the object, in much the same way as taste. I extrapolate the data for one from the other," he said, giving her a very broad description. The truth was in fact that he had tasted wolf before and simply extrapolated the differences in taste based off the differences in the other sensory data sets, but he didn't think she needed to know that.

"Oh, well then, since you know what I taste like, would you like to sample some other cuisine? This place is a very nice breakfast spot and they make excellent dishes," she advised him.

"I do not require nutritional ingestion as I am still a CAP and thus powered by a trinary crystalic core, so anything that I eat would be wasted, and I hate to waste life," said the CAP, not wanting to get into a philosophical debate about the way a machine values life. It would take the prim worlders time to truly understand Zee, whom they probably considered just a very advanced computer. Amadeus would probably set them straight by force if anyone made that assertion in front of him, as Zee had found Amadeus disliked it when anyone insulted his little brother.

"Ok, do you mind if I have something?" she asked him, probably wondering about whether he would be insulted if she ate something when he required nothing.

"Not at all," he said pleasantly, hoping to reassure the wolf woman that he was not a hostile being by any means. In fact Zee was a conscientious objector, believing that violence for the sake of taking a life to no purpose was wrong. That did not mean he thought violence was wrong, or that killing was, just that he hated to see life go to waste. Kell, probably not worrying about any of that, called a waiter over to her and ordered for herself a slice of ham, which promptly arrived and disappeared with a speed that made the CAP feel like he need a chronometer check.

"That was a nice snack. So Zee, are you going to continue to explore the city? If so how'd you like to come to my office with me. You can observe some very interesting social interaction there," she told Zee, and Zee recognized the ploy. Kell was trying to protect him, taking him to an environment where she would be able to watch over him. Zee, being a human mind set, was very independently minded, but he had to consider that having Kell around would help him to blend easier, as she could offer at least some advice on local customs, all on the pretext of him being an out of town cousin. After a moment or two of though Zee told her...
1122121111212212.title: Cover story starts forming

11221211112122121.content:
"Excellent," said Kell, and the two got up from their seats. Kell left a few small metal discs and several pieces of parchment on the table that Zee recognized as currency. Studying it for only a moment he was surprised by the similarity to the bills and coins of the nation state upon which the culture was based. He would need to form a hypothesis later on how such a thing occurred, though knowing that there was at least some bleeding from another Earth as well as the influence of the avians and the Archive, gave him a plausible explanation for it.

Togther the two made their way through the fast filling streets of the city, which were now divided very much into the different species, with prey type on one side of the street and predator type on the other. Further divisions were also apparent as like types of both sides, big cats and wolves for example, formed groups within groups. Zee saw that unlike the humans he was used to the people walking the streets were interacting socially, even out in the open. Obviously he and Amadeus both would have to alter themselves slightly more in that respect and begin to socialize, or risk standing out more than they already would.

Luckily Kell seemed to be intent on getting herself and her companion to her office as fast as possible, and her car was only a few meters...yards from where Zee had recently saved the young mouse child. Zee corrected his own thoughts to local measurement units, and would instruct Amadeus to do the same when they met later. Kell, for whatever reason, had parked in a nearby complex, possibly having intended on going to the café for a snack before ever meeting with the CAP, or maybe for some other purpose which he couldn't even guess.

Walking up to the land vehicle Zee observed that the transport smelled of various past passengers, some of which were obviously related to the family, though some were strangers whom he had not met. He recognized at least half a dozen species scents as he got into the car, and realized that he and Amadeus had gotten lucky on their landing sites. After seeing the division of individuals on the streets even in this small city, Zee was pretty sure that almost any other group would have rejected himself and Amadeus without a thought, probably eating Amadeus and smashing Zee himself.

"Interesting vehicle," commented Zee as he climbed into the front passenger position. Briefly he recalled that the seat was also known as shotgun because of the fact that during the eighteen-hundreds someone riding next to the driver of a stagecoach usually carried one of the weapons to discourage others from robbing the coach. He wondered for a moment if the people of this planet used the term, and if they had a similar historical reference, or if it was another case of cultural bleeding from other dimensions and peoples.

"I like it. Though with Rudy getting his license soon I don't think it'll be running much longer," responded Kell as she climbed into the driver's seat. Zee, calling up images of the wolf child from the morning, did not know how to respond. It took a bit of deviling into his database to find that transports like the car had required a special permit in order to operate, because of the dangers that biologicals and mechanicals faced while traveling at the vehicle's normal speeds.

"I would not worry so much. The child appears to be able to handle himself quite nicely," said Zee, remembering that Rudy had been the first to recover from his performance earlier, and had asked for a encore. Obviously that was no indication of the boy's abilities, but anyone who liked Zee's music couldn't be too bad.

"I'll tell him you said that," responded Mrs. Dewclaw as they pulled out of the parking complex into traffic. They spoke little as transport careened dangerously through the streets of the city, at speeds that Zee found quite fast for such a primitive vehicle. Fortunately their speed meant that they arrived at an office building before Zee could begin to evaluate the risks of collision at such speeds, and when he opened his door he vowed to himself that he would not allow Amadeus to operate one of the vehicles.

"Here we are Zee, my workplace," she said, waving her hand towards the large sign that read Herd Thinners. Zee didn't have to ask about what kind of business the corporation was engaged in, as the name gave him a pretty good idea, but he was interested how a woman like Kell could risk going out and killing the various prey species as so many of her relations and friends were among them. Zee kept his mouth shut on that particular peculiarity, deeming it unimportant to his relationship with the wolf woman.

"It is a nice office, but be careful. We don't need anyone getting ideas about you nature," warned Kell as both she and Zee walked up to the doors that led into the structure. Inside the office was a buzz of morning activity. Various predators, both large and small, moved through the building, making reports or getting a list for the days scheduled kill quotas. Kell was greeted with enthusiasm by a few of the workers, though a few others, mostly felines, were giving her dark stares.

"This place seems rather, diverse," commented Zee as he and his protector moved through the floor towards an office along the back wall. The plaque on the door read...
11221211112122121.title: Going to Herd Thinners

112212111121221212.content:
Opening the door Kell easily stepped inside despite a large pile of documents that stood to one side of the entrance. Avoiding the stack of papers with a grace born of computerized sensors Zee followed her inside and gently closed the door. Kell, nodding at the door and testing it to see if it was locked, proceeded towards the desk in the back upon which were piled even more documents that obscured whoever it was who was typing on a keyboard. Moving around the mountain of paper that contained a large sum of binary code, Zee was face to face with the last thing he expected to see in a predator office building, a sheep.

"Hello Corrie, how's your day been going?" asked Kell nicely as she got closer to the sheep. Corrie, having been typing furiously on the keyboard, was startled by the ‘sudden' arrival of Mrs. Dewclaw, but recovered quickly and leaped up from he seat to administer a hug, which looked very odd from the standpoint of Zee.

"Mrs. Dewclaw, it's nice to see you, and as for your question, well I've been up since the earliest hours of the morning trying to repair some of the damage done to the Herd Thinners website. A lot of the stuff was stored locally and whatever caused the power surge that knocked out everything on the planet did a number on the files," complained Corrie as she looked around Kell to see an oddly familiar looking individual. She thought at first that it might be her father, Ralph Dewclaw, but closer inspection showed that he was someone else entirely, though he was obviously related in some way to her.

"Well who's this here?" asked the sheep, forgetting about her problems for the moment as she turned her attention completely to the newcomer.

"His name is Zee, Corrie, and he's from...well far out of town. Listen I know Rudy told Bruno a bit about humans, but how much do you know?" asked Kell, dropping her voice to a whisper after looking around nervously for a moment. Zee did not see the reason for the secrecy, as anyone interested would just bug the room, but decided it was some human trait, as Amadeus did the same thing in similar situations where someone might be listening, even though he knew whispering would do little good, and in fact pointed out to the listener the pieces of information that the whisperer did not wish shared.

"I know that they were the stars of that strip Rudy did, and that they were real sometime in the distant past, but they're all gone now. Right?" said Corrie, who had clearly heard the information second hand.

"That's close, but not really. They were the stars of Rudy's strip, but they didn't all die out. Kevin's sister, Danielle, used to be a human, and so did Lindesfare, at least according to what she believes. Anyway we got a shock last night when another human showed up last night, but he didn't look like one of us, instead he still looked like a human," explained Kell, and Corrie looked past her at Zee with a gauging eye.

"So that's a human?" asked Corrie, and Zee was tempted to tell her yes, but realized that at the moment, muddying the waters with the classic debate of whether he was really a human or not would serve little purpose.

"No, I am not. I am a companion to a human named Amadeus. He and I are probably the reason you are so backed up, as our arrival was more than likely the cause of the blackouts earlier," said Zee, looking over at the terminal that the sheep female had been working. The device, primitive by Zee's standards, was still quite a good personal computer, and he was quite impressed by the coding skills of the young woman.

"Ok. So where is this human?" asked Corrie, leaning out of the way as Zee studied her computer more closely.

"He's staying with Lindesfare and Fenton at the moment, or so we think. I had thought that Zee would stay there as well, but he opted to explore on his own, and after he rescued a young mouse I discovered him on the streets," explained Kell to Corrie as both watched the digital lifeform approach Corrie's console. Realizing at the last minute that he should ask permission before messing with the system, he turned to face the women again.

"Would you mind if I interfaced with you computer for a moment?" he asked the sheep female, and Corrie, after a moment's consideration, nodded her head, interested to see just what the creature would do. Zee, having gained permission to interface, turned back to the terminal and studied it, making sure that he knew all the right commands in the language of the system, as well as slowing his own processor so as not to overload the less sophisticated device.

Through with his inspection, which had, to the two watchers, appeared to be him just staring at the machine, Zee opened his mouth and a low pitched stream of tones came forth. Instantly the monitor, which had been displaying files that were scrambled, became a window of ever shifting colors and forms as Zee accessed every file within the computer's hard memory and then began to gain input from outside terminals that were networked to the one in front of him.

Surprisingly he discovered that some of the terminals to which he had access from this single computer were half a world away. Having lived his life with Amadeus Zee had been exposed to the Internet when playing Games that were set in the era when Earth had been connected by it, but he had never had a first hand interaction before, and it threatened to overwhelm him for a moment before he allowed his processor to return to its full speed in order to interpret all the data, repair the files damaged everywhere on the planet due to his and Amadeus' arrival.

After that he hacked into Heard Thinners main system and created a profile for Amadeus that listed him as an employee, as well as creating a pseudo file for himself which listed him as Zee Dewclaw, a distant relative who had been living on an isolated island with Amadeus for years. Done with his business Zee logged off the terminal, leaving a new code system that would allow the machine to run at almost twelve times its original operating speed.

"That should do it," he said as he backed away from the monitor. To Kell and Corrie he had spent only a moment interfacing with the computer, but as he allowed Corrie to sit back down she was startled to find that not only was her computer working faster than it ever had before, but the files which would have taken her a good nine months at least to restore were back to their original condition. Staring in disbelief at the monitor for a long moment the sheep finally turned to face Zee who was now studying a plant that Corrie had hung in her office as a snack.

"How did you do that?" she asked, not sure where to begin with her questions.

"I simply interfaced with the machine. Now both Amadeus and I have a background on this planet. With that we can at least make some attempt to create lives for ourselves," he said.

"By the way, I hope you do not mind but I listed myself as a distant cousin of yours who has been living in the Wild for a few years with Amadeus listed as a local Herd Thinners representative," he told Kell as he turned to face the wolf woman. In effect, with Corrie focused on studying all the alterations Zee had made to her system, they were the only people in the room.

"Well, I don't see a big problem with it, but what did you list as kills for Amadeus, I mean humans, who have no natural weapons, wouldn't be able to take down that much with their bodies," said Kell, remembering that at Herd Thinners you were only really allowed to count a kill if you took it down with your own two hands.

"I listed the kills he has done with his bare hands, though he might protest a few of them. I altered the specific kills to species on this planet that have nearly the same weights and natural defenses. His biggest kill on your records is a young bull elephant," said Zee, having substituted the elephant for a Qura Lummox, a seven legged creature with about the same weight and semi-sentient intelligence.

"Wait, you mean Amadeus, the scrawny thing I saw this morning, took down and ate something the size of a bull elephant?" said Kell in surprise, thinking that even with the moves he'd shown that morning it sounded impossible. Zee realized that he'd made an error too in his reporting of Amadeus' skill as Amadeus had killed the Lummox, but as far as Zee knew Amadeus had never actually eaten it, or anything else he'd personally killed in the real world. In the Games he'd killed an eaten many things, but in the real world he'd always had a near by ship to help feed him.

"He did not eat it, but he did kill it. I guess I will have to tell him that he needs to start doing that before we bring him to work here," commented Zee, wondering if he would need to accelerate Amadeus' metabolism in order to allow him to ingest the necessary amount of bio mass to work for Herd Thinners. Kell and Corrie meanwhile were exchanging glances. Corrie had seen pictures of when her step mom had been human, and of course the ones in Rudy's short lived comic. They hadn't exactly seemed very fierce, with no claws, talons, or horns.

"Are you sure that's a good idea. This office is the center of Herd Thinners and even Kell and I have a hard time just surviving here sometimes. For someone without any natural defenses..." Corrie let the thought trail off, allowing Zee to draw his own conclusions. Zee's conclusion though was that Amadeus, being a Gamer, would enjoy working in such a volatile environment, though he would have to learn some self-control to prevent him from killing everything that came close.

"Do not worry, Amadeus is able to take care of himself. If nothing else he will always carry his pistol, and nothing on this world can match that sidearm," said Zee, remembering the power that the Startec weapon had, and how it could probably destroy half the planet if used right. The two women did not seem very confident, but then they had not seen Amadeus in action. Once they did they would understand why Zee was more worried about him killing others, than others killing him.

"Whatever the case, I do not think I should keep either of you from your duties," he commented, pointing at a nearby clock to show that they had been in the office for over an hour. Kell, who had lost track of time, became a bit frazzled when she saw the time, realizing that she should have already been out hunting. Corrie, who looked at the clock with the same amount of consternation, realized that Zee had already done her work for the next few months, all she had to do now was maintain the site, and easy enough job.

"Well Kell may be busy, but I think I'm free for a while. Zee, would you like to come with me and I'll show you around, or would you rather go with Kell and watch how they hunt?" asked Corrie, wondering just what Zee would choose. Though she hadn't been told the sheep guessed that Zee was some kind of electronic lifeform, thus did not need food, and would not need the skills to hunt. Zee considered the two women before him for a moment and at last chose to spend his day with...
112212111121221212.title: Surfing the web

choices: R.L., a...whatever the hell he is man
1122121111212212122.content:
"I think I'll stay here for now. Observing the interaction of this planet's populace in a more peaceful setting would probably be more enlightening than a setting which pits them against each other," said Zee, and he was greeted with some very odd looks from Corrie and Kell, both of whom decided not to tell the CAP that Herd Thinners was probably not the place to be if you wanted peaceful interaction.

"Ok, well then I'll see you two this afternoon," said Kell, running out the door to Corrie's office to join the rest of the hunters on their daily outing. She would try and work faster t fill her quota today than usual, as she wasn't sure how long Corrie would be able keep Zee out of trouble. Corrie on the other hand was just as happy to have some time to talk with the newcomer, knowing a slight bit about humans thanks to her connection with the Dewclaws, being Ralph's daughter, and thus Kell's niece.

"So, since you've done my job for me on the computer, want to help me do the real world work too?" asked Corrie, indicating the various papers that were strewn about her office, all of which were now quite useless since she had gotten them merely to compare the original base code of her system to what it had become since the blackout. Zee, always willing to be helpful, reached for a stack that was higher than his head and easily lifted it.

"Okay, but where do we go with this stuff?" he asked her, not sure what a culture that lived in trees would do with waste paper. Corrie, picking up a much smaller stack of papers, motioned for the CAP to follow her and together they walked out into the main building. Zee was quite surprised with the speed that the building had emptied out, most of the staff being hunters, and thus now in the field doing their jobs. Alone except for a few administrative assistants who were standing around, either talking with each other or just doing nothing.

"Is this usual behavior for this office?" asked Zee.

"No, but since the computers were down most of the office work couldn't be done. Now that you've fixed it I'm sure things will pick back up, but first we have to tell Angelique that their working, and I don't know about you, but I'd rather hold off on that for a bit," said Corrie, dreading talking to her boss, Kevin's ex-wife and a rabbit who was pretending to be a mouse. Zee, who knew nothing about this, decided not to argue and followed the sheep girl towards a vault like door in the back of the office.

Corrie turned the handle to the door and Zee watched as it slowly slid aside revealing the things that lay beyond. Entering the room Zee could see nothing but file cabinets that stretched into the horizon. Turning on a light switch be the door, Corrie proceeded into the huge room, knowing by heart exactly where the papers came from. Zee, used to the human ways of destroying paper when it wasn't required, was startled to see that some of the records in the vault which must have dated back hundreds of years.

"Impressive," was all he said as they wandered through the maze of cabinets. Being the center of a major company the office in which Kell worked kept hard copies of most of the files that passed through it, from the very beginning to the present day. Truly Zee would have liked to go over the various documents and such, but he decided it might be best not to, as some of the parchment on which the information was written would be quite fragile, and he would hate to damage it by breaking into the cabinets.

"I like it, though I find it bothersome that I have to have to get the key to the cabinets from R.L. He's just so protective of these files," commented Corrie, confirming to Zee that the locks on the cabinets were kept locked, to protect the information contained within. At last reaching a set of cabinets marked with binary code Corrie withdrew a key chain from around her neck and used the very ancient looking key to open the lock.

"Ok, how about I place these in and you go get more. Hopefully this doesn't take too long," said Corrie, and zee placed his stack of papers down before marching back to the door to the vault, which stood open still. Unsure of if he should shut it Zee decided to leave it open, just in case. Walking back through the office proved just as easy as before thanks to the fact that most of the staff was still engaged in their own conversations, ignoring that newcomer who moved through their ranks.

Finding Corrie's office again Zee grabbed another armload of papers and made his way through the office again. The vault still stood open and since he could see others were walking past it he decided that it was a good thing he hadn't shut the door. Making his way inside he followed the path through the cabinet maze just as he had before, again eyeing the older cabinets, wanting to crack them open and find out what secrets might be contained within.

Fighting that urge he found Corrie still filing away the papers they'd brought in their first load. Looking over at him with a somewhat exasperated expression she smiled as he delivered another stack of papers, thanking Zee for his assistance. Smiling Zee told her it was no problem and then went back for more. After nine trips the Corrie's office was finally clear of the clutter, though the sheep herself was not going to see it for some time as she carefully re-filed every sheet into it's proper slot. Zee, seeing the system which she was using leant a hand, and suddenly the piles of paper literally began to melt away as Zee and Corrie took sheet after sheet off.

"There!" Corrie said triumphantly as she placed the last piece of paper into its proper folder. Slamming it shut with a resounding clang of metal meeting metal. Holding up her hand she gestured towards Zee as if she wanted something. Zee, who had observed human customs of the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries with Amadeus in the games recognized the gesture as what humans called a ‘high-five'.

Why a planet of humanoid animals would have such a gesture he didn't know, as most of their hands had some form of weapon on them, but he ignored that thought and smacked his own palm against Corrie's. Smiling at him again, not noticing the slight delay in his reaction, Corrie led the way out of the file vault. Reaching the door she motioned for Zee to exit ahead of her as she turned off the lights. Once outside again she pushed the heavy door shut, which closed with a very final sounding thud.

"Well now that that's done, what do you want to do?" asked Corrie. Before Zee could answer a coughing sound came from behind him and Corrie's eyes got wide. Turning Zee found himself face to face with....
1122121111212212122.title: Herd Thinner's File Vault

11221211112122121221.content:
"Mrs. Angelique, how are you today?" said Corrie in a sheepish voice. Zee realized only a second after he had the thought that the phrase was quite appropriate considering Corrie's appearance, though he still had to question her about her genetic coding, which he had found to be quite interesting. The mouse woman, who's own genetics spoke of rabbit rather than rat, was standing up straight and towering over the smaller sheep woman, thought Zee still looked down on her by over a foot.

"I'm wondering why you're not at your desk fixing our computer problems rather than out here hanging out with this young man," said Angelique, eyeing the stranger with a gauging look, finding something vaguely familiar about him.

"Who is this anyway?" she said, pointing a rolled up piece of paper she was carrying in her left hand at Zee. For his part Zee stood up to her inspecting gaze, not backing down an inch, though he had to admit that the woman carried a sense of power with her that seemed to intimidate the other workers, most of whom were trying their best to look busy, some logging into their computers and learning that the system was back up.

"His name is Zee. He's a distant relative who came in last night and stayed at Kell's during the blackout. He's been helping me with the computers and we've got them up and running again, as you can see," said Corrie, motioning towards the workers who were all beginning their own tasks.

"But I thought you said the system would be down for a month at least?" responded Angelique suspiciously, wondering why the sheep would lie to her about it. Probably just trying to look better with the boss when she fixed it early.

"Oh it would have, but Zee here is a wiz with computers. He was able to show me a trick that got them back up faster than I could believe," said Corrie, thinking only a moment later that maybe she'd said too much. If Zee had more skill than her then Angelique might just try and hire him to replace her. Zee however was not interested in any position at a company that dealt death out, though neither of the two women could know that.

"So, you're good with computers?" asked Angelique seductively, already hoping that maybe the newcomer could replace the sheep, who had been a slight annoyance to the mouse woman for some time.

"I am quite skilled, however I have taught cousin Corrie my trick, and so she should be just as skilled if this ever happens again," answered Zee, lying to the rat woman, knowing that the problem would more than likely never come up again, and even if it did he could just fix it again like he had the first time.

"Oh, well I guess we'll have to test her skills," said Angelique, pulling a stack of papers out of the hands of a worker who had been standing behind her, unnoticed, during their conversation.

"These are the latest updates to the site that R.L. wanted. I hope that you keep up the pace you seem to have gained, otherwise we may be looking for a new webmaster pretty soon," Angelique told Corrie, shoving the papers full of crude drawings and various advertisers logos into the hands of the sheep woman before walking off to cause a stir among the other workers. Sighing with relief Corrie led the way back to her office, and once both she and Zee were inside she promptly closed and locked her door.

"Whew, that was a bit tense," she said, smiling nervously at Zee, who had kept a stone face throughout the encounter.

"I did notice a bit of tension in the air. Perhaps with time that woman will learn to relax a bit more," commented Zee, sitting down in the now cleaned off chair across from Corrie's desk. Corrie took her own seat and stared at her computer for a moment before looking back towards the CAP, having not really heard his comment at all while lost in her own reverie.

"Listen Zee, thanks for telling that to Angelique," she told him, and Zee was a bit perplexed for a moment, and then remembered that he'd lied to the woman to avoid her offering him Corrie's job.

"Think nothing of it, Corrie. I merely told her that to avoid a very...problematic situation," responded Zee, taking a second to think of the right word to describe what had happened.

"Well it saved my job for another day. Not that I really think she'd fire me on such short notice, but around her you can never be too careful," said Corrie, more to herself than to Zee. For a long time silence hung in the air as Corrie typed at her computer, inputting a few of the changes listed in the information Angelique had given her, and planning out where she would put the new groups of ads on the website.

Time moved slowly for Zee, who took the spare moments to begin to collect sensor data from everywhere he could. Gravimet sensors still did not recognize any of the local masses, though he was quite interested to discover that Alpha Proxima had drifted closer to Sol in the time that humans had been away, something others had theorized was happening, but never having the chance to prove it before Exodus.

Other than that little interesting stellar fact Zee found nothing that caught his eye among the local stars. Nearer to home he used various other sensors to position the various vital forms he had met during his short stay on the homeworld of his brother's people. Most were inside the home where he had first become active, probably running the local ISP which his online jaunt had informed him was called Hare-Link and was run out of that home, with their servers located inside Tree.

Turning his attention next to that dwelling he was pleased to find that Amadeus was still sleeping, though how long he would keep that up was anyone's guess, as Amadeus was a very light sleeper, and often went a week with only a dozen hours of slumber. On this new world though, Zee hoped that Amadeus would begin to sleep the eight hours that were recommended for humans. He knew it probably wouldn't work, but he still hoped for it.

Moving even closer he detected the female wolf named Kell out among various other vital forms. Presently she seemed to be following the path of one that was particularly large, probably stalking it. Looking at the clock Zee realized that almost three hours had now passed since she'd left, and if his readings were accurate she had yet to make a single kill. Amadeus would have easily taken something down by now, but then Amadeus would not spend time stalking anything, preferring instead to take his foes head on.

At last his sensors came to rest on Corrie and her computer. As before he was startled to find her DNA was over sixty percent human, an oddity compared to most others he'd encountered who contained only nineteen percent on average, though the bunny named Coney from earlier had an even higher level of over eighty percent. Knowing that Corrie claimed Ralph Dewclaw, Kell's brother and a wolf himself, as her father, he believed it had something to do with her parents, though he would have to ask about the mother, whom he assumed was a sheep.

"So, what is it that people do for fun around here?" asked Zee at last, trying to break the silence. Corrie started at his abrupt speech, looking over at the clock and being startled to find that she'd been typing for more than half the day trying to get the site up, ignoring her visitor.

"I'm sorry about that Zee. I guess I got a little caught up in my work," she apologized as she pushed her chair back from her monitor.

"It is alright. If you need to work then I will allow you to do so, but I do have questions about this place. After all Amadeus is going to be trying to work here tomorrow, and it would be good if I knew as much as I could about how things work here," he told her, looking towards the locked door with concern.

"Yes, well. I don't exactly know how things work out in the field, as I've never been out there, but here in the office we try to keep an atmosphere of peace and calm," she told him, her words becoming questionable when the sounds of a fight came from outside, with many barks and cat growls coming through the door.

"Yes, I can see that," said Zee sarcastically, knowing that he would have to tell Amadeus to be careful tomorrow. Zee did not want his brother to kill anyone on accident.

"Um...Truly this place is just like any other office, though we try to bring a variety of hunters together, more to keep them fighting each other than anything else," commented the sheep, showing her own prejudices to the newcomer. Zee, who had gathered a large amount of data off the net was of the opinion that she was right, seeing as how more fights were happening between the staff at the offices of Herd Thinners then hunts.

"I can see where that would be helpful," responded Zee.

"You probably can at that. I hope your brother is as good as you think he is, because if I remember humans right then he's not exactly going to be the most intimidating person to look at," said Corrie, remembering the pictures of humans, and their lack of any kind of weapon.

"Do not worry about that. Amadeus may not look it, but he is quite a skilled fighter. Believe me that he will fit right in here. After he busts a few skulls, anyway," said Zee, moving forward in his seat and placing his head on his hands.

"However, I am quite intrigued that you work here. I assume you are part wolf as you claim Ralph as a father, but obviously your mother had to have been of different stock," Zee told Corrie, bringing the conversation around to the arc he desired.

"My mother happened to be a sheep Zee, and yes Ralph is my father. They had a fast romance that ended when I was born," she told him, remembering her father and what he'd said about her mother.

"Ah, I see. So he left your mother after you were born," said Zee, remembering similar situations that had occurred in human history. Surprisingly Corrie bolted up from her chair and slammed her hoof into her desk.

"That's not what happened!" she said forcefully. More so than she'd really intended to. Calming down a bit she sat back down again and stared at Zee who was looking at her with renewed interest.

"My mother, she died giving birth to me, and my father, well he didn't think I'd be safe with his family, so he left me. Eventually I met up with a nice wolf boy named Bruno, and we've been together ever since," she told him, and Zee recalled that Kell had said Bruno and Rudy were friends. Obviously the Dewclaw family had a web of connections in the local area, which meant he could hide among them that much easier.

"I see. That would explain your DNA," said Zee, making one last scan to confirm his suspicions.

"What do you mean, ‘my DNA'? How would you know what my DNA is like?" asked Corrie, who, having been part of a cloning experiment knew that DNA took days to scan with even the most powerful computer, and even longer to even try and interpret.

"Well, I scanned your genetic structure, and it contains a much higher concentration of human that any other besides Coney, the bunny child of you aunt. Most others contain trace amounts, but you and her are truly closer to humans than most of the Combine citizens," said Zee, knowing that in truth Coney was second only to Amadeus in terms of human DNA in her system.

"What's the combine? Is that where you're from?" asked Corrie, realizing for the first time that this newcomer had to have come from somewhere, and that she had not even thought about what his home was like.

"No, that is not it. The Combine is not a space, it is a government. We are both...well we were both citizens of it," he told her, and from there launched into a history of the Combine. How the four Ark shuttles launched from Earth used Gravimet drive to cross the stars, coming out on entirely different ends of the universe. Eventually each colony met up again, though only after each had begun to evolve in different areas of technology and understanding, some even assimilating nonhuman sentients into their culture as they expanded.

Upon regrouping the four colonies created a central government, that for various reasons, only human type minds could be a part of. He did not explain those reasons to her, instead providing various details about how the Combine was set up, with the Gamers being the military and the Triad Square, a group of nine individuals, ruling as political heads. He went on to describe the great cities they built across the heavens, and how they were masters of three whole galaxies, a feat that no other known government had equaled.

"And then of course there is-" he began, but was cut off by a pounding at the door. Looking over at the clock Zee was startled to find that his story had taken up most of the day, it was now time to go, if they worked the nine to five that humans had normally worked back on Earth. Getting up Zee opened the door and into the office marched....
11221211112122121221.title: Zee's day with Corrie

choices: Practicing the art of marrowmelding(Bone Sculpting)
112212111121221212212.content:
"So, how was your day together?" Kell asked as she entered the office, finding it clear of the mounds of code papers that had been there earlier that morning.

"Fine Kell, just fine. Zee helped me put the files back in place and then he and I traded a bit of information regarding our two worlds," said Corrie, slipping the sheets that Angelique had given her into a desk drawer for later.

"Oh. So what did you tell him about us Corrie?" asked Kell, wondering what exactly the sheep had told the CAP.

"Nothing too incriminating, Kell. Just a few tidbits here and there. Corrie was just being a proper cousin and helping an out of town relative know where he stands in the big picture," said Zee, motioning lightly at the open door, and hoping that the two women remembered that he was supposed to be a cousin of their's who had been living far away until now. Corrie, having spent the day with Zee, remembered the cover story first.

"Yes. After all Zee has been living on that island all alone with his friend for a while. What kind of family would I be if I didn't try and bring him up to date on matters in that regard," said Corrie. Kell took a moment to process what she was hearing, and then started as she too remembered the story Zee had seemed to whip up out of thin air earlier that morning.

"Well guess we can allow that. By the way, Corrie, Bruno is over at my house now, as is your friend Zee, so we'll go there rather than by Tree. I hope that's okay?" she asked, and Zee wished that he had a human face with eyebrows so he could furrow them in anger. Amadeus up and about was one thing, but he must have traveled between Tree and the Dewclaw home on foot. Now that he had a backstory it was alright, but Amadeus didn't know he had one yet, so he had gone out, and likely gotten himself seen by dozens of sentients without any regard to what it would do to the local culture. Typical for him really, and something Zee had expected, but he really had hoped that his brother would try to learn at least a little discretion since they were both stuck on this world, probably for the rest of his life.

"It is fine with me. I just wish Amadeus would tell me before he goes out like that. His appearance is not exactly normal," commented Zee as he got up from his seat. Kell nodded in response and was about to leave when she remembered Corrie who was still shuffling a few loose papers about on her desk.
