Zee, seeing his odd mix of both high tech clothing and old world armor laughed at the image it created, pointing it out to Lindesfare and Fenton, neither of whom seemed to get the joke, making the CAP cough nervously and place his hands in the pockets of the jeans he was wearing.

"So, what is the night life around this area usually like? Last night it seemed pretty dead, but now I can sense over a hundred vital forms in motion," commented Zee, pointing at a pair of glowing eyes in the bushes, obviously belonging to some form of feline.

"It comes and goes depending on the season, but it's normally pretty active. Fenton and I used to be part of the local night life, until we started going to Beige, now we're only here some of the time," commented Lindesfare, waving at the cat in the bushes, getting a return wave before the gray cat streaked off after what looked like a mouse. Amadeus, with his human sense of sight, couldn't see what was going on, but he could hear things just fine, and he smelled a hint of blood in the air, indicating that somewhere in the distance the cat had caught her prey.

"Who was that?" asked Zee, pointing after the cat.

"Oh, that was Abby, dad's newest neighbor. She's nice enough, for a cat, and she and Kell get along great," said Lindesfare like that last bit was something special, and Amadeus was left to wonder why. The major separations on the planet seemed to be based off diet rather than looks, so Amadeus had no idea why the lupine Kell would have any problems associating with the feline Abby.

"I see," said Zee, who remembered that on Earth felines and canines had never been exactly known for association. Amadeus, being of a more universal in his views, knew that the feline Amerians, humanoid cat anthromorphs, and the canine Veraxan, humanoid dog anthromorphs, were known to be allies stronger than most.

"Well good for them. I wonder if I can make any friends here," said Amadeus without thinking, and then realizing that what he said could be considered dismissive of the kindness that the Dewclaws had shown him so far he added, "I mean it's nice to talk to you and your family Lindesfare, but to you I'm a bit of a curiosity. I'll probably be that to others to, but no where near as much."

"I understand. I remember how Danielle felt when she first got here. She was worried all the time about fitting in, but after a while she just sort of accepted it, and she and George are regulars at certain spots now. I don't know if she thinks of the people she knows there as friends, but I do know they helped her to get through her transition," said Lindesfare, remembering her discussions with the human turned anthromorphic rabbit.

"She's still a bit of curiosity herself though. People will still sometimes stare at her when she orders meat at a restaurant," commented Fenton, his own memory of one of the gatherings they'd all attended coming crystal clear in his mind. He chuckled a bit at the image of some of the carnivores looking over at the bunny eating a burger with big, bug eyes.

"Yeah, but I think with Coney as a niece they accept it a bit easier. After all an omnivore rabbit is nothing compared to some of the rest of our family," responded Lindesfare.

"I should think not. After what I observed on the Internet your relatives have many things that lift them above the mediocre," said Zee as he recalled all the articles regarding his hosts that he'd copied from his exploration of the net. While Amadeus would not approve of the side track to his primary mission, Zee had felt it necessary to understand those who had helped them in their earliest times on this new world, hoping to find some way to repay them for their kindness. Lindesfare seemed to be slightly disturbed by the CAP's observation though, and stopped in her tracks to turn and face him.

"What did you find on the net about us? More rumors and slander?" she asked, not accusing Zee of anything, but really wondering if anything they didn't already know about might be floating on around the world wide web about her family and relations.

"Some of it yes, but the majority of files I procured from an avian database mark your family as this words first step towards a new age. Specifically it makes mention of young Coney's enhanced tele abilities, as well as the friendships your mother has formed with species that are normally enemies of her own," said Zee matter-of-factly, though the information he shared seemed to cause Lindesfare even more concern than had he told her slander.

"Wait. The bird that moved into Ms. Aura's house said something like that, but he didn't say that Coney was telepathic. Is she really?" asked Lindesfare, wondering if Zee might have some way to test for it. Oddly it was Amadeus who stepped forward and answered the question.

"Not exactly telepathic. She can't rip the thoughts out of your head, if that's what you're thinking. She is simply a bit more human than you are and thus able to tap into a part of her mind called the Collective Unconscious more than you are, to the effect that she can communicate with open minds like those of young children through thought," he told them, having had a short conversation with the bunny child earlier that day when he'd asked her if he could borrow some of her bones for his marrowmelding.

"Actually Amadeus, to them it is close to telepathy. She reads the thoughts of what are expected of her, and draws from the experiences of those around her. It is quite a good thing she is unaware of the true nature of her abilities as she could very well cause another instinct loss event if she were to try and form a conscious link with someone," said Zee in an off hand way.

"You mean Coney was responsible for the world wide loss of instinct?" asked Fenton, who had suffered in that incident himself.

"No. The first case, when Rudy was publishing his little comic about humans, was caused by the fact that your people, being infused with human DNA, also have the parts of the mind that are given over to the Collective Unconscious. In your case though that space is taken up by instincts, something which humans have little of. When Rudy's comic was disseminated it activated that part of the mind of a few individuals who naturally tried to form links with others, erasing the information contained within that portion of the minds of those they tried to link with," explained the CAP in a low tone, looking over his shoulder and scanning around them to find that luckily no one around them showed any interest in their discussion.

"After he stopped publishing that strip the individuals ceased to... think like humans, I guess is the best way to put it and eventually this world achieved an equilibrium again, with others literally giving copies of the instinct to those who lost them, allowing them to function again, if with a bit of a learning curve now due to the transplanted information's incompatibility with their own systems," said the CAP his pace increasing as he led the way back to Tree.

"The second incident was simply the same thing, but this time on a much wider scale as real humans were present, minds that were used to the Collective Unconscious, and thus knew how it was supposed to go. Though she did not do it on purpose Danielle and various others, including the avians themselves, were attempting to reach out and grab onto the minds of others, forging a new link. It was only by sending the strongest of the minds through to another world that the network collapsed, however in that particular case the result would have been something much different than what the birds believe," said Zee.

"What do you mean?" asked Lindesfare, wondering what else Ms. Aura's people might be hiding from them.

"Well, the birds thought that the forming of the link would overwrite all instincts on the planet, leading to a major sociological shift that you just are not ready for at this time. However my data indicates that more likely the new link would have encompassed the data as well, which would had led to changes, but not the ones the birds though," said the CAP, getting blank looks from everyone in the group, including Amadeus.

"Okay, the birds thought that the instincts would go away, leaving this world reeling in chaos as everyone basically forgot how to do what they were supposed to do. What I believe would have happed though is that the instincts of all the races would have been accessible by any individual, leading to a world where... well where wolves knew how to hide like rabbits, and rabbits knew how to stalk like wolves," explained Zee as best he could, and he saw in her eyes that Lindesfare understood him, while both Amadeus and Fenton seemed lost.

"It is not really that important, as neither scenario is possible now. Amadeus, unlike Danielle, is able to control that part of his mind, and will not try to form a link with anyone. Still I wish I could have discussed this with Aura, she seems like a smart woman," said the CAP, a bit of regret coming into his voice as the group at last reached Tree. Without waiting for the others, and still scanning everywhere Zee opened the door and ushered everyone inside, closing and locking the door behind them before breathing a sigh of relief.

"Okay, so who was following us?" asked Amadeus, startling Fenton and Lindesfare, who looked back towards the door nervously.

"No one, Amadeus, at least not anyone I could sense, but I do not think that subjects like the one we were discussing are fit for the open air. The birds lost the Vault Techs, but that does not mean they are not dangerous, and there were some oddities in the data flows of the net which I cannot account for," said Zee, looking at Amadeus intently, freezing his brother in his gaze as the human had made ready to grab his pistol.

"Then you lied earlier," sated Amadeus. It was not a question, it was a statement of fact for him, and Zee was forced to look down at the floor ashamed that he had bent the truth even slightly.

"No. I said the Vault Techs were gone, and that is the truth. These data flows though sparked my interest, and yet I have not been able to crack them. Something bad could possibly be going on here Amadeus, something neither you nor I are qualified to handle alone," said Zee, still looking towards Amadeus with a gaze that bespoke of what he would do if the human dared to draw his weapon.

Off to the side both Lindesfare and Fenton were staring at the pair of visitors, confused by the strange change that had overtaken them. Zee hadn't changed that much, those his eyes looked less bright and more focused than they had before. Amadeus though had changed drastically, his voice going from soft and kind to something hard and unbending, while his eyes changed into something that reminded Lindesfare of Kell when she was on the hunt. Oddly enough his scent too had changed, as if he had become an entirely different person as he stared at Zee accusingly. For many minutes the staring contest continued until at last Amadeus set his hand on his belt, and then looking over at Lindesfare and Fenton he...
11221211112122121221222112121112.title: Conspiracies

112212111121221212212221121211121.content:
"I guess you're more than a little confused by this aren't you?" asked Amadeus, smiling warmly. His eyes had returned to the soft state that Lindesfare and Fenton remembered, and his scent was slowly edging back towards what it had been before. His voice retained a slight edge of hardness, but even that seemed to fade as he leaned back against the wall behind him, and then motioned for Lindesfare and Fenton to have a seat on the couch while he stood in front of it. The two complied with his silent request, not sure what they were in for.

"Ok, where to begin, where to begin," said Amadeus to himself, drumming on his chin with his left index finger. At last he looked towards Zee and motioned for the CAP to stand beside him, as if Zee would play some part in what he was about to tell Lindesfare and Fenton.

"Listen, I don't know what the avians told you about humans, or about the history of this planet, and our leaving, but trust me, at least half of it was either a lie or wrong due to their own lack of knowledge," he said, trying to begin his tale by erasing whatever it was that the birds had told the two about his people. He'd spoken earlier with the family about what they knew about the history of humans on Earth, and found it to be more than a little biased against humans.

"First off, Earth wasn't trashed by humans. Not as badly as Kevin and Danielle seemed to think anyway. I mean they did clear cut the rainforest and do dozens of other horrible things, but for everything one human did wrong, a dozen others tried to do right, and usually they achieved a precarious balance of creation and destruction," he explained, moving his hands like those of a scale.

"However, when my ancestors came to a certain point they began to expand their technology in a new way, one that dealt with life itself, and in the end that caused a bunch of problems, namely the creation of nonhuman sentients, and several other kinds. These other sentients at first acted docile and non threatening but many would turn on humanity, and begin what was known as the Gaia Conflict," he said, trying to remember everything he could about the legendary battle between man and what had seemed like the planet itself at many points.

"Eventually humans would come out on top of the Conflict, after much bloodshed and heartache. The planet suffered greatly from the battles fought using the very lifeblood of her, namely a silver, glowing liquid that is called Genesis, the basis of the technologies that caused the evolution of the nonhuman sentients," he said, skipping over the details which in truth he didn't know. Zee, who probably did know the details, stood beside him, not wanting to add the gory particulars of what was one of the worst periods in recorded history.

"Many technologies that came out of he war were then turned to the purpose of resurrect what was fast becoming a dead world, but in the end all the plans would fail, many creating worse enemies than the ones from the war. At that time too was developed the Morpheus Ray, which would accelerate the formation of neural networks, basically increasing the intelligence of anything it hit," he told them, gesturing at the walls around them.

"It is my guess that Tree is a subject of that very weapon, though exactly what it did to her I don't know, I just know that it works on any living creature, which included the first avians which were granted sentience in an attempt to get them to help revitalize the planet. As you can probably guess that didn't work either, and after that we were hit with two more severe set backs, the Green Brain and Foulmess, the first being a living mass of neural fiber that literally took control of the forests and turned them into armies that tried ‘purify' the planet of everything that wasn't flora, and the second being creatures the were born of a kind of filter that removed impurities in Genesis energy, but unfortunately shoved the impurities together until they became living creatures of darkness and rot," he said, remembering some of the games he'd played that had involved fighting those same creatures.

"After so many set backs and battles the human race gave up on this planet. They just couldn't live here anymore and decided to pack up and leave, but rather than take the techs which had caused the problem with them the humans of the past decided to lock them away in a device known as a vector cage, which was...well it was a device that created space where there really wasn't any," he explained, searching for right words to describe the vector cage. Getting blank looks from his audience, who still didn't understand where the explanation was leading, Amadeus turned to Zee and motioned for him to try his hand at explaining.

"You never were a good teacher Amadeus," complained the CAP as he stepped forward, this time forgoing the projections he just spoke directly to the two listeners.

"The vector cage is a type of spacial warp, wherein certain forces, specifically those involving gravimetrics, create an area where false space exist. In effect a vector cage can hold an ocean in a space the size of a syringe," he said, stepping back so that Amadeus could finish his history lesson.

"Thanks, Zee. Now into the vector cage, which was code named The Vault, the humans of that age placed techs which they would leave on Earth for whatever reason. Had I been them I would have simply destroyed the stuff, but my ancestors had a thing for knowledge. Even when they didn't want it they felt that they should preserve it in some way," he told Lindesfare and Fenton, who still had no real idea of where the lecture was going.

"The rest is history, as the saying goes. Eventually the humans would go out in four arks, which were themselves shuttles equipped with gravimet drive systems and vector cages. After landing on the four colonies and evolving for several years the scattered remnants of Earth would reunite and form the Combine," he said, getting at last to the point he had been trying to reach.

"Now upon forming the Combine began searching for the home that the humans had left behind, but thanks to certain events which we have never understood the beacon left on Earth which had vanished. We assumed the worst of course that Earth had been destroyed in some unknown way. However just because we assumed that it was gone didn't mean we were willing to just write off the dangerous techs we'd left in The Vault," he said, and Lindesfare gasped slightly. It dawned on her where this speech would be leading and why the two visitors had seemed so intense a moment ago.

"You want the technology the birds used destroyed, don't you?" she asked, and Fenton looked at her in shock. He knew that according to the bird who'd explained some of the situation that the techs were supposedly gone, sent into the future using a time machine, but of course the human visitor wouldn't have known that, and may have made plans to acquire and destroy those items which would have involved a confrontation with the birds.

"Yes. Standing Order number four of the Triad Square states that any member of the Combine military who is put into a position to destroy the techs should do so by any means necessary. In my case those means involved causing an overload in my pistol's hydrogen sounding chamber that would have created a small proto star. Once the gun's chamber burst open the star would then ignite the atmosphere, destroying the techs no matter where they were on the planet," he said, his hand dropping to his belt and withdrawing the pistol from its holster. Lindesfare seemed more disturbed by the new information that Fenton, as the bat truly did not grasp what Amadeus had just said.

"So you were going to destroy the whole planet, just to eradicate a few trinkets?" asked Lindesfare, disbelief in her voice. Fenton, hearing her words, put two and two together and realized that that was exactly what Amadeus had just told him. For a moment shock was evident on his face, but it was fast replaced by a smouldering anger directed at the human.

"A few trinkets? The techs in The Vault had the capability of destroying the entire cosmos if misused. Even the Combine today couldn't fight some of the things contained within those walls, and that is why were are supposed to make sure they're gone. Zee convinced me earlier that they were, and I believed him. I still do really, but these anomalous data flows may be just as dangerous," he said, a forlorn look in his eye as he gazed out a nearby window at the starry sky outside.

"I don't know if you will believe me, but I didn't want to hurt you, or anyone else on this planet. I mean this is Earth. This is where my people began, but my wonder at this place has to come second. A soldier has to follow his orders, even when he doesn't agree with them. Can you understand that?" he asked of the two, and Fenton still stared at him with anger in his eyes, realizing what the human was admitting to nearly doing. Next to him though Lindesfare's expression was much different. Her shock at his statement was tempered by her thoughts about Rudy, who had been looking at joining the service recently. As Amadeus had said, if Rudy joined then he would be required to follow his orders, even if he didn't agree with them.

"I do," she said at last, to Fenton's surprise. He turned his gaze from Amadeus to her, and then back again, the anger giving why to shock again as he saw the softness in the gaze of the woman he loved directed at a man who had almost killed them all.

"Good. I would still understand if you chose to hate me, and if that is the case please tell me now, and I will leave. It would be best if I left soon if you hate me, as I do not wish to cause you any undo concern. I would even be willing to leave a piece of my weapon in your hands, to prove that I would not take such actions in the future," offered the human, pulling at the gun in his hand and popping off the small orb at the back. Holding out his hand he passed the sphere to Lindesfare who rolled it in her palm for several minutes before...
112212111121221212212221121211121.title: An admission of guilt

choices: No, I don't think you should
1122121111212212122122211212111211.content:
Lindesfare rolled the small metallic sphere around in her hand for a few minutes, studying it and wondering how such a small device, that was smaller than a baseball, could be such a large threat to her world. After everything she'd seen and done, she knew that little things could cause trouble on a global scale, and that this tiny orb had been made by a people who had many times her own people's time to develop weapons. Staring into the depths of the chrome finish she at last held her hand out to Amadeus and then let it roll from her palm into his.

"You should keep it. I don't think we're ready for this," she said at last, and Fenton looked at her in disbelief. Amadeus though, nodded as he replaced the sphere back onto the butt of his gun, causing it to click into place followed by a small whine that quickly ended. Spinning the pistol twice on his index finger the Combine soldier slid the weapon back into the holster at his waist and then faced the one who had just handed back such an awesome power.

"No one is ever ready for that kind of power, but you have my word that as long as I wield it, this power shall never be used against this world or those on it," swore Amadeus, crossing his hands before him to form an S and then bowing at Lindesfare. Fenton, who had been sitting beside Lindesfare leaped up from his couch and pointed an accusing finger at the human before him.

"And do you think we trust your word? I mean you just admitted that a couple of hours ago you were willing to kill everyone just to get rid of a few pieces of junk your people left behind eons ago," he said to the human, and before anyone had a chance to react, Lindesfare leapt up and stood between the human and her boyfriend.

"Fenton, you just gave us at least one good reason to trust him in that sentence, and you don't even realize it," she told him, and the bat stared at her blankly.

"He told us Fenton. He didn't have to. He could have just acted like it was nothing, and we would have believed him, but he didn't He was willing to take our judgement for his actions on himself. Not only that but he didn't do it, and he was willing to give up that power to us. He gave us a chance Fenton, a chance to live, and I think we should be willing to do the same," she told him, he voice full of emotion. Silence hung in the air for several moments as everyone digested what Lindesfare had just said, a silence that was broken when a slight coughing sound came from one of the speakers in the room.

"I don't know if my opinion is really valued in this instance, but I have to agree with Lindesfare, Fenton. No matter what he was told to do by his superiors, Amadeus didn't do it, and that means that he's on our side. I think," interjected Tree, and Fenton slowly fell back into the couch. Upon landing he let out a startled yelp and flew back up, a quill stuck to his butt. Again silence hung in the air, but this time it was broken by the sound of laughter as Fenton pulled the quill out of his posterior and set it into a dish on a nearby table that was full of them.

"I should be more careful," he commented as he resumed his seat, looking towards the three sets of eyes that were staring at him. He smiled as best he could, which solicited a hug from Lindesfare before the four figures were again seated in their two pairs, both facing each other across a small gap. Amadeus and Zee seemed to be back to their normal selves completely now, with Amadeus having lost that hard edge he'd had mere moments before.

"So then, about these data flows. What is it you find odd about them Zee?" asked Lindesfare, interested as to what an alien computer mind might find odd on the Internet, if for no other reason than casual interest.

"Well...not odd per say, just a little off. As most people in computers know code is written by a single programer and then later expanded on by others. In most cases the code comes to take on a kind of life that helps you ID the programer who made it through what is known as a FIST," he said, and Fenton, Lindesfare, and Amadeus nodded, all three familiar with the principle.

"The thing is I cannot ID these programs. Everything on the net had some kind of identifying trait to it that let me at least know the species of the programer through what I know about behavioral patterns, but these things just do not fit any of the patterns I know," he explained.

"Well could you just not have patterns for the species that made the code?" asked Fenton, his own interest in the situation sparked by self-preservation as he still didn't trust Amadeus not to blow the world to kingdom come if he thought that the flows represented a threat.

"I though of that, but even if the patterns did not fit I should have been able to follow the flows back to some source, and I could not. They just sort of vanished whenever I tried," he said, shrugging his elbows in a defeated gesture.

"Could the code segments have been immature EIs? I mean it isn't unknown for a linked computer network to begin forming the complex codes that can form EIs," said Amadeus, and Zee considered the question for a moment before nodding his head.

"It is possible, but I still should have been able to ID the code in that case, as even EIs take part of their code from basic programs before forming a coherent logic string," he said, shaking his head in defeat again. His mind was racked with possibilities as to the origins of the odd flows, but he had no concrete data on them.

"Well then, when you're helping with Hare-Link tomorrow try and find out some more. Now that the unpleasant business of SO4 has been dealt with we can focus on the more sociological oriented stuff. Hey it could be nothing more than trash code that clumped together," purposed Amadeus, but neither he nor Zee looked to confident. Shaking his head and trying to dismiss the disturbing news about odd data flows Amadeus turned back to Fenton.

"Now that we are going to be staying here, by the way, I wanted to ask if Zee and I could make some modifications to the guestroom, and also if I could borrow some of the metal shell plates left over from the server installation," said Amadeus, shifting the conversation towards a less serious path.

"Well, we'll have to ask Tree about any modifications to her, but as for the plates I see no reason why you can't have them. What are you planning on doing with them though?" asked Fenton, wondering what the human could do with a few pieces of EM shielding.

"Since I'm stuck here I can't get to any place with high gee training equipment, so I figured that I'd build some for myself," said Amadeus, looking over at Zee and tapping him on the shoulder before rising. He led the way through the house and back to the room where the servers were humming away. Walking carefully over the cables on the ground he made his way past the machines and then emerged from the labyrinth of technology a moment later holding a panel of sheet metal about a foot square and a cm deep.

"Would this work for gravimet plating Zee?" asked Amadeus as he handed the piece of metal to his companion. Looking at the thing with a gauging eye Zee turned it over and over again before at last holding it flat before him. Then placing on hand under it he placed the other atop it and as all three of the watchers looked on his hand began to flow into the sheet, spreading out like water. After a second or two his melted hand had completely covered the sheet and then he withdrew it like a magician whipping a table cloth off a table full of fine china. Instead of leaving the pieces of expensive glass standing though Zee revealed that the surface of the plate on his palm was now covered with circuits.

"They are sufficient. However does this not violate rule two of our current situation?" asked Zee as he handed the altered piece of metal back to Amadeus.

"Well, kinda, but as long as I keep it for personal use only it should be okay. That precedent was set back in five-oh-eight(508) when a Combine trooper crashed on a world of proto humans. He made a few things for his personal use, like a gun, that the people couldn't make. He didn't get hit because he didn't introduce the tech to anyone," responded Amadeus as he studied the new sheet, before nodding at it.

"Now to the bigger obstacle," he said resignedly, turning to face one of the speakers that allowed communication with Tree.

"Tree, I want to make some small alterations to your interior. Would that be alright?" he asked, wondering if puppydog eyes worked on something without sight.

"Well, um...what sort of alterations?" asked Tree slightly nervous at the prospect of altering her insides, though still wanting Amadeus and Zee to stay.

"Nothing drastic, if that's what you're thinking. I just want to build a place where I can work out. All I'm really going to do is make a big, room sized, metal box inside you. It shouldn't hurt," he said, and he could feel Tree's agitation at the idea, even with his assurances.

"But don't feel that you have to do this. I'm not going to force this on you," he said, not wanting to try and coerce anyone into anything they didn't want. Thinking about it from Tree's perspective he knew he wouldn't want anyone to build a small metal box on his insides. Tree considered the same thoughts for a few moments before responding that...
1122121111212212122122211212111211.title: Renovation Plans

11221211112122121221222112121112111.content:
"You can do it if you want too, but are you sure this won't hurt me?" asked Tree with a hint of nervousness.

"Positive," said Amadeus, but a look from Zee caused him to scratch the back of his head and face a nearby speaker.

"Well, I can say that building the box won't hurt you, but once it's built it might cause a bit of discomfort. Nothing too big, mind you, just a feeling of dizziness that comes from two competing gravitational fields," admitted Amadeus.

"I have never heard of the field affecting the surrounding structure too adversely, however my memory contains at least half a dozen records of living vessels complaining about disorientation. It is unlikely that you will even feel these effects, but I am not willing to say that as an absolute," added Zee as he came out of the computer room carrying a stack of the metal sheets.

"See, even Bit-Brain says you'll be fine. Now let's get to building," said Amadeus, walking towards the guestroom without looking at the other three. Lindesfare and Fenton both seemed as nervous as Tree at the prospect of Amadeus doing any construction, while Zee was shaking his head and sighing at his brother's back. They still followed him though, if for no other reason than Amadeus seemed to draw them after him. His pace was such that even Zee had a bit of a problem keeping up.

Having told Fenton and Lindesfare about his near destruction of their planet had lifted his mood for whatever reason, and Amadeus walked with a spring in his step, nearly bouncing with each footfall, before he finally entered the guestroom and came face to face with the first problem in his construction efforts. It was true that the room was bare of furnishings, as he'd remembered, but what he'd forgotten was the small perch that stuck out of the far wall.

"Ok, so maybe I should have thought of this earlier," he commented to himself, scratching the back of his head again and turning to find the other three coming up behind him.

"Hey Zee, I think we might have a bit of a problem," he said to the CAP as it entered the room, pointing towards the protrusion from the wall. Zee took a moment to study the branch, before turning back to face Amadeus.

"I am surprised at you brother. You act like I cannot work around something like this," Zee told the human, setting the plates he'd been carrying down before grabbing the top one and holding it in front of him as he'd done with the one he altered. As before his hand was placed palm flat atop the thin sheet of metal, but this time when he withdrew it a small strip came with it, until he had enough that it formed a mold of the perch with more than a few extra inches to spare.

"Have I told you lately that I think you're brilliant," said Amadeus as he took the sheet from Zee.

"Not lately, but then you and I have been a bit busy today," responded the CAP, picking up another sheet off the stack and altering it as he'd done with the first one, again creating a thin sheet that was covered in oddly glowing circuits. Amadeus set two of the altered plates side by side on the floor in front of him, and then drew his gun, an action which caused his two hosts a bit of consternation, but then they noticed that he played with a dial on the weapons side, causing the end to spark brightly like a welding torch.

"This is the tricky part. I have to bond the plates, merging the circuit paths. If I make a single centimeter mistake then the paths don't meet up and the plates becomes useless," he explained to them as he pushed the two plates closer together, and then delicately, with the same deft hand which he had applied to the marrowmeld sculpture he touched the tip of the gun to the plates getting a small stream of smoke. When he at last pulled back the circuits linked perfectly, and they seemed to be glowing brighter than they had separately.

"Perfect," he commented, grabbing the third plate and placing it beside one of the two joined plates. Again he placed the tip of his gun on the metal, bonding the plate to its brothers, and causing the circuits to glow brighter still. As he took up the forth plate Amadeus began to hum softly to himself, to a tune that sounded oddly familiar to Lindesfare, though not as much to Fenton. Slowly the words to the song began to fall from his lips, barely audible to the two despite their hearing.

Well they say a man is made out of mud,
a poor man's made out of muscle and blood.
Muscle and blood and skin and bones,
a mind that's weak, but a back that's strong.

You load sixteen tons and what do ya get?
Another day older and a deeper in debt,
Saint Peter don't you call me cause I can't go,
I owe my soul to the company store.

"Oh not that old bawl again," complained Zee as he passed Amadeus another plate, causing the human to look up from his task.

"It's a good working song Zee, and this is work," he told the CAP, gesturing at the plate.

"Oh come on. You have never worked a coal mine in your life, or anything even close to that difficult," commented the CAP, before turning as he felt a small tap on his shoulder. Looking back he found that Lindesfare had stepped up behind him, her face inquisitive as it usually was.

"Excuse me, but what song is that he's singing? I seem to remember hearing it somewhere before," she asked, and the two extraterrestrials looked at each other for support, before Amadeus turned back to his welding, still humming the tune, forcing Zee to explain it to his hosts.

"The song is titled Sixteen Tons, and it is a folk song dating back to a period about one hundred years prior to the one your world is currently at. It is a description of the life of coal miners of that era who felt like they were born mining and died mining, all while working for corrupt mine bosses. Now in truth these were accurate reads of their situation, but the song itself was a bit of fantasy based on the estimate that in their lifetime each miner moved roughly sixteen tons of coal," explained Zee.

"The first line of the song is actually a tribute to the major religion of that time and area, its creation myth being that man was born when a divine being molded him from clay," said Zee. He was about to continue his explanation when Amadeus tapped on the stack of metal sheets, holding out his hand for the next piece of his growing puzzle on the floor at his feet. Looking somewhat hurt at being interrupted Zee quickly altered another sheet and passed it to the human, who then began singing again as he set his latest addition in place.

Well I was born one day when the sun didn't shine,
I picked up my shovel and I walked to the mine.
I loaded sixteen tons of number nine coal,
and the straw boss said ‘well ah bless my soul'

You load sixteen tons and what do ya get?
Another day older and a deeper in debt,
Saint Peter don't you call me cause I can't go,
I owe my soul to the company store.

"You know that first line of the second verse is appropriate to you. You were born in a city that never saw a single drop of sunlight," commented Zee as he made another plate, passing it to Amadeus.

"Eh, I don't think the author of the song ever had Shunt Cities in mind when he wrote the song," responded Amadeus, still humming the tune.

If you see me comin better, step aside,
a lot of men didn't, a lot of men died.
One fist of iron, the other of steel,
if the right one don't get you, then the left one will.

You load sixteen tons and what do ya get?
Another day older and a deeper in debt,
Saint Peter don't you call me cause I can't go,
I owe my soul to the company store.

"And that last verse, not counting the chorus, speaks of the kind of person such a life creates. Hard and strong, capable of great acts of strength and violence. Not unlike Amadeus really," said Zee, again getting himself a hurt look from Amadeus. Looking around themselves Lindesfare and Fenton were surprised to find that the box of metal plates Amadeus had been welding together was almost complete, with only a small portion of the floor left to go.

Stepping onto the finished pieces of the floor the two watched as Amadeus quickly set the last few sheets into place, completing the box. It was only then that the two noticed that they had no exit to the room now, the door being covered by metal plates, but as if in answer to their thoughts Amadeus quickly rushed to where the door had been and used his tool to carve open a small rectangle of wall, which caused the room to go dark as the circuit was broken and ceased to glow.

Pulling at the newly made door Amadeus opened it wide so that he let light from the hall into the new room and then did a few things with his tool that Fenton and Lindesfare couldn't see, though they were nearly blinded as the circuits around them suddenly flared into life again, bright enough now to provide what looked like sunlight into the enclosed world around them. Walking up to one of the circuits Lindesfare ran her hand over it and followed the small band of a light as well as she could in its confusing pattern over the wall.

"It's beautiful," she said to no one in particular.

"Yes, and like most things of beauty, it is quite deadly to the unprepared, so you, Fenton, and I stand to the side while I turn this thing on and put Amadeus through his paces," responded Zee, motioning for Fenton and Lindesfare to stand beside him in a corner that seemed to glow a different hue than the rest of the box. Once they had joined him he looked askance at Amadeus, who silently nodded towards his companion.

"Ok then, Tree, can you hear us?" asked Zee, looking towards the area of the wall where the speaker had been. A muffled voice called out an affirmative, and Zee touched his forearm, causing the fur and skin to melt like they had when he'd made the plates, but this time instead of merging with metal, the arm became metal, specifically a metal control pad that glowed the same color as the circuit around them.

"Then let us see how good Amadeus is. We shall try a setting of twenty gravs to start, and go as high as fifty if he looks to be doing okay," said Zee, and Lindesfare looked at him, slightly shocked by the figures he was throwing out so nonchalantly. She knew Amadeus was used to a higher gravity than any she'd known, but fifty times. Amadeus had an odd expression on his face at the two numbers as well, though his were for entirely different reasons.

"Only fifty? Come on Zee, that's baby stuff. Give me a real work out," he said to the CAP, who shook his head in response.

"Amadeus, I am still not confident of this structure's ability to withstand the pressures you are used to, so let's play it safe for now. Maybe later we can play with the training wheels off, but for now they are on no matter what you want," responded Zee, and Amadeus couldn't argue, seeing as how the CAP was holding the only control for his new work out room.

"Well then how about cleaning me off first. I haven't felt clean for days now, since Fenrir actually," said Amadeus, getting some odd looks back from his hosts, who had no idea of what he was talking about. The cleaning became explained a moment later as Zee pressed a button on his arm that cause Amadeus to lift off the ground by an inch, and hover in the air. As they looked on, impressed by the simple fact that he was flying, they watched as what looked like dirt and grim literally peeled off his skin, finally falling to the floor in a heap when the gravity around Amadeus returned to normal.

"Ah, much better. Now give me what, you've got Bit-Brain," said Amadeus to Zee, and Zee complied. Looking over his shoulder Lindesfare watched as the number on his display slowly rose from one to twenty, which caused Amadeus to jerk in surprise, before he seemed to find his balance again, bouncing from one foot to the other as he had been before, and neither Lindesfare nor Fenton could see any difference. Both took a step forward as if to test and see if anything before them had changed, and before Zee could stop them __________ crossed the safety zone into the twenty times gravity field.
11221211112122121221222112121112111.title: Construction of the Gravity Room

112212111121221212212221121211121111.content:
The quilled young woman reached the boarder between her safety zone and the zone where Amadeus was working out, causing both herself and Amadeus to cry out in shock, her falling to her knees, and Amadeus leaping up and slamming into the roof. Both Fenton and Zee went to the fallen Lindesfare, helping her to her feet after the sudden collapse, and luckily she appeared to be fine, if a little unnerved by her experience. Amadeus, without aid, picked himself up off the floor and then walked over to right before where Lindesfare was standing unsteadily on her feet with Zee and Fenton on either side.

"And that young lady, is why you should never step out the safety zone while in a grav room," he admonished her, causing Fenton to stare at him somewhat harshly, but looking up weakly Lindesfare nodded at him in agreement.

"I'll try to remember not to do that again," she promised, shaking off the two valient gentlemen, who seemed to have forgotten that while recovering from a surprising ordeal, she was quite capable of standing on her own.

"What happened anyway? I thought I was going to be crushed when I passed beyond the safety zone, but instead I felt... well like I felt when I was on the shuttle," she commented, recalling how microgravity had felt during her little jaunt into space some time before.

"Well it should have. The field is supposed to protect you, so when you passed over the line it canceled all local gravity, creating a zero g zone in my area, which affected you as well. We're actually lucky you did and not Fenton to tell the truth," commented Amadeus, not really caring about how unique it was for Lindesfare to know what zero gravity felt like. To him it was such a common thing that he didn't give it a second thought, though in the back of his mind he knew that it wasn't nearly so common for Prim Worlders like Fenton and Lindesfare.

"And why is that?" asked Fenton, somewhat insulted at te implied weakness, though in truth he knew Lindesfare was stronger than him in most senses of the word. Amadeus however, meant no insult by his comment and shook his hands in a motion that indicated Fenton should erase the last comment from his memory.

"That's not what I meant. I meant to say that since you're a flyer your sense of gravity is slightly different. If you'd been exposed to the sudden shift it would probably have thrown you for a loop, likely knocking you out for a while," he told him, and Fenton seemed to take it better that the insult was really just a trait of his kind of being rather than anything personal, though Amadeus could sense that he still wanted to prove himself, especially after Amadeus beat him in a foot vs. flying race.

"Okay, so Amadeus, do you want to keep going with your workout, or can I shut this place down for a while so we can all catch our breathes after that little scare?" asked Zee, fingering the controls on his arm. Looking around Amadeus seemed to be searching the walls for some sign, but after a quick search he didn't seem to find what he was looking for and nodded at Zee while pointing at him.

"Alright, go ahead and shut it down. It's probably getting late anyway, and I still have to ask you questions about this place where I'm going to be working tomorrow," responded Amadeus, and with a single push Zee shut off the gravity room's field, yet instead of growing dimmer, the light from panels actually grew stronger in intensity. Motioning for Lindesfare and Fenton to follow Zee walked across the room to the door to show them it was safe, and then together the four left the newly refurnished room and made their way back into Tree's living room.

"Oh my, it really is getting late," said Lindesfare when she at last got a look at the clock on the wall.

"We still have to pack up all the stuff we brought with us and then set off back for the college. Come on Fenton," and so saying she grabbed Fenton's hand and the two rushed back towards the bedrooms, this time going into the one in which they slept, leaving Zee and Amadeus alone in the living room.

"Okay, so what do you want to know Amadeus?" asked Zee as soon as he knew the two were out of ear shot.

"Well, let's start with the basics, what will I be doing, who will I be doing it to, and how much will I be making?" he asked, and so Zee launched into an explanation of what he'd been able to find out about Amadeus' duties at Herd Thinners.

"The first one is easy for you, you will be killing things, something you do anyway, so a job doing it should suit you well. As for the who you will be killing, well from what I was able to find out you are given a daily quota of pounds, and you are supposed to fill it or die trying. That third thing, well I do not know it, you will have to ask Kell. I bet she will," he said.

From there the discussion becomes more specific. Details of the office hierarchy, which Zee describes as being based off a pride of lions, with a few leaders sitting around making decisions while others carry them out. In this case the Alpha leader would be a creature called R.L., with several lower echelons below him in varying categories. From the files it appeared the Kell was actually the local top hunter, though how she fit into the rest of the company even Zee could not figure out, as most of the place was literally a mishmash of thrown together departments, most of which were still in one way or another involved in hunting and killing, though some other, like Connie's Webmaster position, were more about filing and information.

"So, will I be working under Kell, or what?" asked Amadeus.

"You will, for a while at least. From what I gather the top hunter takes newcomers to the area out into the field on their first hunt in order to both gauge them, as well as provide insight into local prey and their tactics," responded Zee.

"How hard of a time should I have with the local prey, do you think?" asked Amadeus, having spent the day gauging the ability of those around him he doubted he'd have much difficulty, but it was best to prepare just in case.

"The local prey in the wild is about average intelligence. They use no tools, instead relying on their individual attributes of camouflage and defense, most types of which you have encountered and over come before so I will not go into detail," answered Zee, but then he held up his hand as if he were remembering something half forgotten.

"There will however be one complication," he told Amadeus, giving a slight pause as if asking the human to figure out what he was going to say next. Amadeus, not one to back down from a challenge, held up his own hand to stop Zee's continuation, and after a second or two of though he snapped his fingers and pointed at the CAP in triumph.

"The eating part. I can't eat that much in the time span they want. Right?" he asked, and Zee smiled at his brother while nodding, showing off the teeth which he had in his current form.

"That is correct. Thanks to odd nature of their evolution, people on this planet are still used to eating a lot all at once, which as you know is a throw back to pre-sentient evolution when one could not count on regular meals at all times. It is not that they eat more than you, they just eat what you eat in a day in about six minutes, so we have to boost your metabolic rate, which is why I made these," said Zee, reaching into his pants pocket and pulling out a two sealed, plastic containers, each of which were wafer thin.

"Okay. So what are they?" asked Amadeus as he took the plastic containers from Zee, who motioned for him to open one. Digging his fingernails into the place where the lid and container met her pulled the two apart, to reveal that inside the containers were individual crackers, saltine to be specific, though the salt was oddly colored, with a slight violet tint to it.

"I give up, how are crackers going to help me eat that much at once?" asked Amadeus, sniffing the odd looking confection, and finding that it had only the normal odor for such a thing.

"It is not a normal cracker Amadeus. The salt contains a metabolic booster that will accelerate your digestive tract allowing you to eat many times what you should. If you notice the two are marked purple and orange. Purple makes you eat more, and orange returns you to normal. And to make it less suspicious, take this too," he said, pulling out of thin air seemingly a pack of saltine crackers.

"Cute Zee. What's next, pull a coin from behind my ear?" said Amadeus, and then reached over to Zee and did just that, pulling his personal coin, the one he'd used to choose his direction after first finding a road on his new planet, from behind Zee's ear, before returning it to his pouch, and then placing the package of crackers and the two special ones in beside it.

"So, is there anything else I should know about my new place of employment, or should do I know enough not to get myself in trouble?" asked Amadeus, having asked all the questions that he found important.

"Just one more thing. Office social policy. You are allowed to kill your coworkers at Herd Thinners, however it is frowned upon as inefficient, as well as bad manners, so please restrain that violent streak of your's and just knock fellow employees out for now. I am sure that after two or three concussions they will learn that you do not like to be bothered," warned Zee, and Amadeus started at this little bit of information, filing it away for later use. Before he could inquire anything else a shuffling noise came from somewhere down the hall that lead to the bedrooms, and out of that hall came Lindesfare and Fenton, the later holding a suitcase that was almost the size of the former.

"We're all packed, and we have to get flying if we want to make it back to Beige before sunup, so we'll see you two this weekend, alright?" asked Lindesfare as the two stepped through the livingroom towards the front door.

"Fine with me. Have a safe flight," said Amadeus as the two literally flew out the door towards a far off destination. Truly alone now except for Tree the two brothers took time to reminisce about their lives, and how they came to be where they were. At one point Zee remarked that he hoped his children were doing okay, prompting a startled sound from the local speaker, forcing Amadeus and Zee to explain that Zee's body was as real as anyone's, and had the same reproductive organs.

In truth Zee had been married nine times in his four hundred years of life, and had literally hundreds of children of which he was the mother or father, depending on which gender he happened to be in that particular relationship. This also caused Tree to ask Amadeus about his own love life, which was a bit of a conversation stopper as it turned out that unlike his ‘little' brother, Amadeus had never found a woman or man whom he loved enough to have kids with, though that was due more to his devotion to the Combine military, which had kept him busy most of his life, giving him little time to find a soul mate.

At this point the three discovered that they'd been discussing the lives of the two extraterrestrials for well over four hours, and that on the horizon the sun was just rising. Zee, who had made the travel arrangements the night before, informed Amadeus that Kell would be stopping by Tree on her way to dropping off Rudy, Fiona, and Bruno at school, but that if he wanted to he could make his way over to the Dewclaw home if he wanted to, as Zee would have to be going their now anyway to do his own job.
112212111121221212212221121211121111.title: From the middle of the night, to early morning

choices: Stay with Zee at the Dewclaw's
Follow Amadeus on his day at Herd Thinners
1122121111212212122122211212111211112.content:
"I'll come with you. I'd like to get a look at this areas morning habits anyway. Sociologically, I think the walk over will prove quite illuminating," said Amadeus, prompting Zee to roll his eyes.

"You are trying to act smart again, are you not?" asked Zee, and Amadeus smiled innocently at his brother.

"Would I do that?" he said, his tone full of sarcasm. Zee didn't bother to respond to his brother's attempt at childishness. After all, lost as they were on a planet full of non-humans, Amadeus needed every boost to his spirits he could get. Shaking his head in a manner that should his annoyance Zee turned his head towards one of the speakers as the two made for the door.

"Tree, we will be leaving now. If all goes well I will be back in a few minutes to rewire the server," Zee told the sentient plant.

"Well, have a good day," responded Tree, and Amadeus assured her it would be one to remember, no matter what happened. What he meant by this, neither Tree nor Zee knew, but Zee knew Amadeus well enough to be slightly worried about the statement. Trying his best to ignore the implications, Zee opened the front door and led the way outside into the strange new world.

Well, not too strange anymore. Both had spent the previous day about in this odd place, and the two had learned much in their own way. Amadeus' knowledge consisted of what he had learned of the culture from the odd family he'd spent the day getting to know, while Zee's consisted of actual experience out among the daily workings of the city in which they had found themselves citizens of.

Though both pieces of knowledge were different, together they gave the two enough understanding to make their way in the odd culture. Walking along the now familiar path towards the Dewclaw home Zee found the sight of the nocturnals going into sleep, and the diurnals awaking to be infinitely fascinating. Such a mixture of human and alien concepts, not unlike the Combine or any of the other multidimensional governments, and yet it still had its own unique characteristics.

"Lookie there," said Amadeus, pointing towards a lark. The bird, famous for being a musical animal, was actually clearing his throat, before chirping into the early morning sun. Amadeus, having seen the animals on other Combine worlds, was still entranced by the song it sung, though this one was probably just a bit more complex than the ones he'd heard as it was born from a sentient mind mixed with instincts, rather than instincts alone.

"Quite lovely, but I do not think you should be staring or pointing. I believe that even here that qualifies as rude, and we do not want to be rude, do we?" asked Zee, trying to remind Amadeus of incidents in the past where he'd been in a bit of trouble due to similar actions. Sentients, for the most part, did not like people singling them out as oddities, though for Amadeus, being odd was a matter of pride, so he rarely saw the problem in the action.

Still the hint was enough for even him, and the two continued down the path without further pointing, though Amadeus' eyes shot about much like a child's, finding each and every sight to be beautiful, and for an instant Zee wished he could share in that wonder, which most humans even lost by the time they wore a tenth of Amadeus' age. His brother though, never let go of that, and he always seemed to find something to brighten his eyes with wonder over every horizon.

Thinking those thoughts made the walk go a little faster than it had the previous evening, and all too soon the two extraterrestrials found themselves at the familiar driveway of their adoptive family. Well, adoptive of Zee at least, as he was now listed in the records as a real part of the odd mishmash of species that was considered the Dewclaw family. Amadeus on the other hand was just an oddity that was tagging along behind, though he still held out a bit of hope that he could make a small niche for himself in the planet's culture, at least until the Combine came and took him back home.

"Well, let's get this day started," said Amadeus dejectedly. Interested as he was in the planet and its culture he didn't really wasn't too into getting a job. Having been a military man for the majority of his life, he was no stranger to working, but even though his job would involve the excitement of a hunt, he expected it to be as mind numbingly boring as laying siege to an enemy fortress. Knocking on the door he heard the hollow booms as the knelling of a bell, and when it opened he beheld a sight that probably belonged somewhere on the tenth level of Dante's Inferno.

"Good morning Zee," said Kell, yawning as she did. Obviously having just awoken, her blue hair was slightly askew, though it did look like she had brushed it at least for a little while. She motioned for the two newcomer to enter, and found most of the household, including the grandmother wolf, Kevin, and Rudy gathered around a table eating breakfast.

"I thought Amadeus was going to wait at Tree for me to pick him up," commented Kell as she walked with the two back over to the table.

"I assumed he would, but he decided to come here with me," responded Zee as he took up position in a nearby corner, leaning against a wall. Amadeus meanwhile walked up behind Kell and withdrew her seat from the table, and then helped her to move forward once she was seated.

"I didn't want to imposition my boss on the first day, so I came to you rather than making you come to me," explained Amadeus, though that was only one of a hundred different reasons he had for coming with Zee to the Dewclaw home, another of which being to see how they ate their meals as smaller groups, rather than the large gathering of last night. It turned out manners were pretty much the same in both situations, violent in the case of predators, and slow and steady in the case of herbivores.

"Well, that's nice of you," said Kell as she tore into her food again. Amadeus, having kept his face pleasant since seeing her, did not bat an eyebrow at the sight, though it disturbed some primitive part of his mind that told him to run from the sight of flashing teeth and tearing claws. Fighting those urges he smiled in such a way that hid his teeth, which among most cultures like the one he now found himself was a sign of aggression.

"Eh, he is a nice guy, when he tries to be anyway," commented Zee, more to Amadeus than the Dewclaws, most of whom weren't listening anyway. The two brothers stared at each other across the room, each seeming to be lost in thoughts of the other. The meal, luckily, lasted only a few minutes longer, and when Kell took the dishes back into the kitchen the others dispersed to do their morning tasks.

The two newcomers, having no tasks, simply walked into the livingroom and took up positions similar to those they'd had around the table, awaiting whatever would come. They didn't have to wait long, as it was mere moments before the door opened, and together entered another group of people, this one consisting of Fiona, her parents, and stepparents, as well as Bruno and Corrie.

"Good morning," said Danielle as she noticed Amadeus and Zee standing in the living room. Amadeus nodded and mumbled something that could have been a good morning, or could have been something else entirely, in return. Whatever he said the group quickly broke up, many going to their jobs at Harelink, the home business run out of the Dewclaw home, at which Zee was now employed, while Fiona, Martha, and Danielle took seats on the couch.

"So how was your first full night on Earth, Amadeus?" asked Danielle, staring at the human, probably hoping to compare his experience to her own.

"Well, it was interesting, I'll say that. Zee and I built a gravity room inside Tree, which took a bit of the night up, then when I was trying to train Lindesfare gave us a bit of a scare when she crossed a safety field, but she wasn't hurt. After that she and Fenton went to pack their bags, and I assume they are back at their college by now," said Amadeus, summing up the evenings events as best he could. Finding little comparison between her memories and what Amadeus had just told her Danielle leaned back and nodded absentmindedly, though Fiona leaned forward, interest apparent on her face.

"What's a gravity room? I mean I think I can guess, but..." she let the thought trail off, hoping for Amadeus to fill in the blank. Chuckling at a stray thought he nodded his head.

"Yes, you probably can guess, cause it's just what it sounds like, a room where gravity is alterable at the touch of a button. It's a basic tech if you want to go at a good speed in the real universe after developing on a normal sized planet, though most Combine people mainly use the tech to train in high grav environments," explained Amadeus.

"I see. Well how high can you go up to? I mean, humans aren't really designed for high gravity, anymore than we are, right?" asked Martha, the fox woman and mother of Fiona, who lived as a human for a period of days, and still remembered how vulnerable she'd felt.

"Correct, they are not designed for it, but adaptation is something humans do well, and the gravity rooms are no exception. Amadeus has proven capable of taking gravity levels about three hundred and twelve times Earth normal, though only in an environment suit due to the fact that air compresses at that pressure into a liquid, making it unbreathable," answered Zee offhandedly, as he usually did with information that surprised his hosts, which this piece did more than slightly.

"Three hundred and twelve times Earth gravity? That's possible?" this from Danielle.

"It is for someone from our type of civilization. Heck, from what I hear, the Unified Worlds Alliance has humans that can go up to four thousand or so, though I've never actually seen them do it," said Zee.

"Wait, if he can move around at that high a gravity, shouldn't he be nearly godlike in strength," commented Fiona.

"Normally yes, I would be, but in order to prevent me from injuring myself or someone else in lower gravity environments I wear these," he said, and pulled at a piece of his suit, which was a uniform gray all over. His tug revealed that on his shoulders and hips he wore small bands that blended right into the suit when he didn't pull them away.

"They're called neural limiters, and they keep my strength at a level just below my ability to hurt myself in this gravity field," he explained to his hosts.

"So, how strong are you right now?" asked Martha.

"Well, at this time I could probably bench five hundred and sixty some odd pounds, though it would be quite a strain," said Amadeus.

"And what about at maximum, without the limiters?" queried Martha again.

"Well...I don't know. I've never had to push myself to that limit, but I assume its several tons at least, after all I weigh just over two hundred in this environment, and that means I weigh over sixty thousand pounds at my gravity limit," said Amadeus, who now wondered like Martha just what his limit was, though he could think of no safe way to test it on the prim world he now found himself on, though vowed silently that he would find out when he got back to a Combine world.

Conversation would have continued had not Kell and Rudy emerged from the back of the house, both lugging packs. Rudy's was like the one Fiona had brought, a pack designed to carry various large books, while Kell's looked more like a business bag, designed to carry papers, folders, and other odds and ends that were part of any office environment.

"Okay, well we're ready when you two are," said Kell as she entered the room, eyeing Fiona and Amadeus as well as a clock on the wall. Looking over his shoulder at the clock, Fiona started at the time, and then leaned over and kissed both Danielle and Martha on their cheeks.

"We have to go, love you both," said Fiona, as she made for the door, followed close behind by Rudy. Kell and the other women looked after the pair with that look that females usually got when seeing a display of young love, though Zee had a similar expression on his face. Unlike his brother, Amadeus had never experienced life as a woman, though he had spent a week as one on a bet with Vivan Sekot, one of his old squad mates from his days in the Arrow Squadron.

Having found the life to be odd compared to his normal he switched back the instant he could, and pocketed three hundred grams of borash jelly, a honeylike biological byproduct of Vivan's own making. Seeing that he would get little understanding out of staring at the women and his brother, Amadeus soon followed after the two young ones, which prompted Kell to do likewise, wishing those that remained behind a nice day.
1122121111212212122122211212111211112.title: First day of the rest of their lives

11221211112122121221222112121112111122.content:
Getting into the car Amadeus took the passenger side in the front section, seeing as the two younger individuals seated themselves in the rear together. Looking out the window he awaited the arrival of his hostess, whom he tried to think of as Alpha now. Oddly he looked back to find Bruno and Corrie standing in the doorway waving goodbye, yet according to his own memory of the previous day Bruno went to the same school as Fiona and Rudy, while Corrie worked with Kell at Herdthinners.

"Are they not going to be traveling with us?" asked Amadeus of the two in the rear, and Rudy shook his head, but refrained from giving any other answer to his question in explanation. Luckily Fiona seemed to sense the basis of the inquiry and was able to give Amadeus the requested information.

"No. Corrie can drive herself, thanks to a special license she got from Herdthinners, so she usually drives them. Heck a few years ago Rudy and I rode the bus, but thanks to Kell's new position as head of certain departments she has the extra time to take us in the morning," she explained to the out of town visitor, who nodded in understanding. A stray thought reminded him that without Jasmine and her games about Old Home Terra he would likely have had to ask what a bus was.

This in and of itself was not too suspicious an anomaly, as a lot of people created games set on an Earth of that type, as they were the most common Earth type you would find thanks to forces like the Progenitors and the Seeder Ships, which were constantly going about the multiverse, adding human DNA elements to base worlds. Hell, Amadeus' own Earth was likely a seeded world, though since it had been lost since long before the process of seeding was know there had been no way to confirm it.

It was however, highly suspicious that Jasmine's games had usually involved some form of anthromorphic entity in the plot. Often enough this had been the typical werewolf, or lycanthrope, with a human transforming into a beast, but many had also included creatures like his current carmates, true amalgams of human and animal DNA patterns

This could of course had been a reference to the Genesis Technologies of the Pre-Exodus era, yet their cultural fit so well with this new world that Amadeus had to wonder if Jasmine had not had some precognitive ability allowing her to see Amadeus falling into this situation. At that thought Amadeus shook his head to get the thoughts out.

Whether or not Jasmine had been aware of his current situation do to some ability was not an issue, as he had no way of contacting her or even his government. This meant that such thoughts had to take a back seat to the more important issues of survival and information gathering. After all The Vault Techs, while gone, still exerted an influence on this world, and he still had the problem of Yggdrasil to work out.

According to his knowledge of Old Home Terra history, while most of the ‘Lost Technologies', including Tempus and Genesis stuff, had been inside the Vault at Exodus, the Final Solution tech called the Yggdrasil machine was not. That meant that it could still be on the planet somewhere, or under it, or over it, waiting to emerge and rip the universe to shreds with its unimaginable pow-

"Are you okay?" said a voice breaking through his reverie, and Amadeus started, turning his head to find Kell looking at him with concern in her eyes. Shaking his head again to clear it Amadeus smiled and chuckled slightly, hoping to cast a nonchalant air on his musings, which he now realized had been quite evident in the way he'd been wringing his hands until they turned a nice bright shade of red.

"Yes, quite. I was just thinking about some things, and got lost for a moment inside my own head, thanks," he said, brushing away her concern. Luckily for Amadeus Kell thought the reason for his concern had a more mundane origin than the fate of the cosmos, and she nodded at him as she pulled the car out of the drive.

"Well don't worry. The first day at the office is the hardest. As long as you can survive that though, you're usually set for life," she told him, trying to ease his mind about his new job. At first Amadeus thought he should laugh at what he assumed was a joke, but then he remembered that a day at his new job really could end in death, something that had been decidedly uncommon in the games he'd played with Jasmine that had been set in this era.

"Then I will strive my utmost to survive it," he told hr, smiling again, and breathing an inner sigh of relief that she had not actually guessed his thoughts, at least one of the being that he should destroy the blasted planet, killing them all, and probably saving everything else.

"Good luck," came a sarcastic comment from the wolf boy in the back seat, followed swiftly by a yelp of pain as his girlfriend struck him on the shoulder. This was also followed a moment later by an chittering sound coming from inside Rudy's fur as some parasites moved around. Amadeus started slightly at the sound when he heard it, as it sounded much like the language of Vivan, who had been of insectile descent, though only on her father's side. Before he thought about it fully Amadeus made a similar clicking noise with his tongue, which solicited looks from everyone else in the car, as well as new clicks from the furs of both Fiona and Kell.

"Yeah?" he asked quizzically, his gazing going back to Fiona, who's fur erupted in a series of clicks that sounded threatening in their intonation. Amadeus then clicked twice, adding a finality that needed no translation to his speech, as everyone could hear it as a ‘bring it on' kind of phrase.

"Uh, do I even want to know who you're talking to?" asked Rudy as he looked at the human, pulling down his sunglasses to reveal his eyes.

"Well, apparently you three are infested with a kind of parasite. I was unaware of this until one of them complained about Rudy being struck again, and throwing their home askew. I commented that maybe they shouldn't live on someone without permission, and they launched into a heated discussion about me knowing they're language. I find it odd that they seem to think you don't though," he commented to his companions, who stared at him blankly for a moment before anyone could respond.

"Well, that's because we can't. No one can speak flea, at least no one I've ever heard of. People have tried of course, but most of those end up giving up halfway through because of the itching involved in such project," Fiona answered at last, and Amadeus nodded in understanding, before he let loose a flurry of clicking sounds that were soon returned by the fleas in Fiona's fur.

"Okay, well, now that I know you can't speak they're language, I've been instructed that I can't teach it to you, on the punishment of a very itchy death. I was forced to apologize for my last comment to, as I had assumed you would speak the language of a species you allow to inhabit your bodies," Amadeus said, explaining his early, harsh clicks.

"Well it's not exactly a choice. Fleas happen, and we just have to deal with them. The occasional flea dip helps though," this comment, by Rudy of course, solicited a round of furious clicking from within his fur, but Amadeus refrained from answering instead turning back to face forward after turning in his seat to stare at Rudy.

"You're on your own for that one, my tiny friends," he said, this time in English, and then what could only be the insect equivalent of a raspberry could be heard from Rudy's fur, before the car was silent again, this time because Kell was coming to a stop in front of the school. She obviously was trying her best to ignore everything she'd just been told or overheard, and turned back towards the two in her backseat.

"Now you two be good today, and try not to eat anyone we know," she said as the two got out of the car, both muttering that they would try, even as they eyed the odd human who rode in the passenger seat. When they were both out the door Kell took off again towards the end of town where Amadeus assumed the Herdthinners main office was.

"So, you really speak flea?" she asked, trying to make conversation, though also having an interest in just what else her companion could do.

"Not exactly. The language I'm speaking is ::Series of musical whistles:: a friend of mine spoke it as her father's native tongue, and being close to her I sort of picked it up during our association," explained, and Kell nodded, accepting this explanation more easily than she probably would have had she not just heard him do it with her own ears.

"How many other languages do you speak, if I may ask?" she said.

"Well, I speak about nine-hundred-twenty-three pure languages and several thousand dialects of those, would you like a tally of them, Alpha?" he asked pleasantly, and Kell was about to respond in the negative when that last word hit her like a ton of bricks.

"Wait, what did you call me?" she demanded, recovering after veering sharply to the left when she turned to face Amadeus.

"I called you my Alpha. Is that not that designation of a pack leader on this planet?" he asked, and Kell didn't respond for a moment, gathering her own thoughts on the subject before deciding what the best answer would be.

"Yes, Alpha is a pack leader, but I didn't think that humans, well Danielle never used any of those kinds of terms, and so I assumed that you wouldn't," she said, admitting her own prejudgement.

"I see. You still think of Danielle and myself as coming from the same kind of culture, which I can assure you we don't. Her's is as different from mine, as it is from your's. I do however have knowledge of culture's similar to both of your's which allows me a bit of insight into thought. And before you ask, you are not the first person I've called Alpha, as Zee's brother-in-law, a Veraxan named Krex, demanded it of me. I obliged him because of Zee, and only because of Zee. You however, being my teacher in local hunting ways, deserve at least that much respect from me," he told her, and she didn't respond.

For the rest of the drive there was a hanging silence as they made their way through the traffic of the city to the office where Kell, and now Amadeus, worked. Observing the piloting technique Amadeus was confident he would be able to control a craft like the one in which he now rode, though he knew Zee didn't want him even trying such a thing at this time, and for his brother's sake he would refrain from operating such a vehicle, except in dire circumstances.

At last they did arrive at the building that displayed the title of the company on the side, which Amadeus found slightly odd for an association of hunters, who would under normal circumstances prefer to remain anonymous, but then, he doubted they could have hidden it well anyway. Getting out of the car he slammed the door shut, and walked with Kell toward the big double doors that would allow him entry into his new life. The instant he step through the doors he was assaulted by the color white in the form of....
