12.content:
Everywhere around Amadeus was a city, like some of the ones he'd seen playing the games with Jasmine, the ones set near the last age of the old Homeworld. The landscape, familiar as it was, was populated with creatures that simply didn't fit. The things were staring at the human who had fallen from a hole in the sky, some with curiosity, and others with hatred directed at any intruder into the natural flow of their world.

"Okay, so home this isn't," commented Amadeus to himself, looking around the city and finding a large number of the local creatures to be bipedal humanoids for the most part, with two arms and legs, though various other forms including what looked like huge insects had either multiple legs or arms, or were walking on all fours. Each one stirred memories buried deep within Amadeus, memories of the games he'd played with Jasmine that had been set on Old Home Terra, and the myriad lifeforms he'd seen that had lived there. Every creature that he could see had some root of a one of those long lost species, though each one was much more human in form than anything he'd seen.

"Maybe I should try talking with them. At least see if they know what planet this is," he told himself, stepping forward, to the obvious dismay of some as they backed up. Intriguingly, he noticed that it was only those who seemed to have been based off herbivorous species who backed up when he got closer, while those who ate more than plants seemed to puff up, as f expecting him to attack at any moment.

It was then that Amadeus recalled he was wearing the fur cloak from his game with Jasmine, and looking at the blood stain on the front he had to admit he must have been an odd sight to those in front of him. Holding up his hand to indicate that he needed a moment, which surprisingly the anthromorpic population seemed to understand, Amadeus undid the belt clasp that held the cloak to him and shouldered it off before reaching up to his neck and peeling back the connector for the helmet, and then throwing both fur and metal mesh helm to the ground he stood before the throng of onlooking creatures as a human, though wearing the gray, polymer fiber suit which was common to the Combine.

"Ba Wee Grana Weep Mini Bong," he said to the crowd, holding up his hands to show he bore no ill will towards them, despite the fact that he was armed. The universal greeting, something used in first contact situations where one is at a disadvantage to the alien race, was designed to throw the new contact off while the contacter, in this case Amadeus, used the time to collect his thoughts and figure out exactly what he was going to say.

Collecting his thoughts Amadeus finally began to notice that the cars and vehicles that had probably been in motion only seconds before his arrival were now stopped dead in their tracks, and that despite the fact that the place around him looked like a city street he couldn't see a single light on in any of the nearby offices, which looked like dark foreboding tombs. Everyone else seemed as baffled by the lack of activity as he himself, though they obviously were willing to blame it all on the new comer who'd just fallen out of the sky.

Thinking about it, Amadeus could guess that his entrance to the world really had resulted in the loss of local power. After all giant holes in the sky usually caused massive EMP fields, which had probably also had something to do with his Terminal's problems before he'd been sucked in, and the field had been strong enough to send a MultiDimensional Terminal for a loop then it probably flipped every circuit on the planet.

"Okay, so my first impression is pretty bad, doesn't mean the natives won't be friendly and understanding," he said to himself quietly, just before a small explosion detonated from the crowd and a lead projectile flew right for him. Dodging the bullet which hadn't been all that well aimed in the first place Amadeus looked at the crowd to see someone emerging from it holding what looked like a small golden shield in a leather carrying case. It took him only a moment to realize that he was staring at a badge, and that the dogman holding the gun was the local constabulary.

"On the ground. Now!" shouted the creature, and Amadeus was startled to find that he understood that thing's language, which was exactly like the old American English he'd used when playing the games with Jasmine. That thought brought him back to his question of where exactly in the universe he was, and to the conclusion that he might not even be in his universe anymore.

"Now sir, I know this looks bad, but I thin if we talk this out we can come to some-Hey!" shouted Amadeus, having walked towards the dogman, whom he now could place as being of the German shepard breed of dog, he reached out his hand, only to get shot at again. Luckily the bullet had been aimed for his shoulder, and the polymer mesh of his suit caused it to bounce off, but the impact still hurt, and Amadeus saw the dogman aim the next shot for his head.

"On the ground!" ordered the dogman again, and this time Amadeus decided to forgo the attempts at contact, and took off as fast as his legs would carry him, which wasn't as fast as he would have liked thanks to the climbing boots which he still wore. The police dogman fired his entire clip at the fleeing human, but Amadeus was now wary of the bullets, turning to the side at every sound of a gunshot causing all the bullets to miss, though barely.

Running through the city proved easier than Amadeus had suspected, but that was actually due to the fact that most of the inhabitants moved away from the strange looking man who'd fallen out of their sky just after the power went out. He didn't know whether to be glad that they weren't trying to kill him, or disappointed that no one was trying to talk to him and get his side of the story. Looking back over his shoulder Amadeus saw that his dogman of a police officer had friends, and they were all chasing after him, and they were all armed with the same small pistols as the first one.

"Oh for the love of stars," swore Amadeus as he ducked into one of the alleys that stood between the buildings of the downtown area. He had thought to run into an adjacent street and try to escape into one of the buildings, but his plan came up short when he found that the alley he'd entered dead ended after turning to the right, and he was now staring at a brick wall which kept him from going forward, while at the same time he could hear the impacts of his pursuers' feet on the alley floor coming up behind him.

Trapped he had a few options that he could choose, the easiest of which was simply to give up and hope the planet he was on had some contact with the Combine that he hadn't been able to see on the street when he'd arrived.

Another was to use the climbing boots to ascend the wall before him, though he'd be a slow moving target for the guns that the dogmen held, and he wasn't entirely certain the polymer mesh of his suit would hold off a steady spray of fire as easily as it had a single bullet.

Looking about for anything else Amadeus was pleased to find a door in one of the walls before him, which he could bust down even if it wasn't unlocked. The only problem being that he'd be trapped in the building exactly as he was now, only with even few options.

The final option, and one he would not ever consider under normal circumstances, was to turn and face the police dogmen with all guns blazing. His Startec pistol was more than a match for their pathetic weapons. Of course, using his weapon was strictly forbidden by the Combine, as you were not supposed to use high tech weapons against primitives unless no other options remained. But he saw only a few other options, and they weren't exactly what he would call good ones. So what does he do?

121.content:
As Amadeus thought about his options, he realized that surrendering to the cops would be the wisest decision. 1. Even if he got away from the officers, he didn't know where he was, and if someone saw him, the hunt would just start up again. 2. While he knew that he could easily kill the officers, if he somehow managed to get home, he'd be executed for murdering a bunch of, relatively, defenceless civilians. 3. He was lost, and didn't know how to get back home.

As the officers entered the alley, he just slowly, and calmly, raised his arms and said, "I surrender." At this, one of the officers asked, "What? You figured out that it is usseless to run or something?" "Maybe it is," Amadeus said. "And maybe it isn't. I know that I can easily scale these walls with very little problem. However, that would cause you to shoot me, and while my armor could survive your projectile weapons shooting at it, all it takes is one luck shot to the head to kill someone, and also, the force behind them might be enough to cause me internal damage. Also, I could easily take you one, and maybe even kill you, but, even if I somehow survived and got away, I'd be wanted for murder, and then, even if I got home, I'd be executed for it. Of course, the final problem is this, I'm lost, and even if I got out of the city, and eluded capture for whatever reason, I'd still be lost. So, all things being concidered, surrendering seems to be the wisest choice that I could make." "Well in that case," the officer said. "Hands on your head and turn around!" "Sounds reasonable enough," Amadeus said, as he did as he was told. He felt the officer grab his wrist, and pull it to his back, and the snap of cold metal handcuffs. "I doubt you'd get out of this, alien," the officer said, as he grabbed his other wrist and cuffed it as well.

At this, Amadeus chuckled, as he pulled his wrists apart, suripticiously, straining the links on the cuffs. "Buddy, if I tried to escape," he said. "These restraints alone wouldn't prevent me from getting my hands free. After all, I trained to fight in gravity that is about three hundred times that of this planet. In fact, the one reason that I really didn't try to escape is because my armor has a limiter on how much of my strength can be used, so that I don't hurt myself or someone else by accident." "Oh really," the officer said, with sarcasim in his voice. "You don't look like much of a threat to me. You have no fangs, no claws, or anything else that you can use, especially once I take this belt off of you." "Be my guest," Amadeus said. "Just don't try to mess with my pistol. If someone other than me tries to use it, unless I say that you can, it will give the person a massive electrical shock, and can cause one to have a heart attack. Also, I'd advise you to be careful with Zee, the guy gets cranky when even I try to wake him up." "And what would this 'Zee' be?" "Well, I guess you could call him a highly advanced android, if you know what robots are," Amadeus said, as he looked at his friend, who was basically asleep, and in the shape of a PDA-like device. "And what do you use this ax for?" the officer asked. "I doubt it's for whittleing." "You're right on that," Amadeus said, as the officers started to lead him to a squad car. "But it certainally is handy for survival, especially since ones made of stone ensured my kind's early survival, and their decendants improved upon it, making it more efficiant, more durible, and more useful."

A while later, after his fingerprints and photograph had been taken, and entered into the system, he was taken to a holding cell that had...

1213.content:
In the cell that Amadeus was taken to was four grown and rough looking men, and one teenage boy, who looked like he was scared, despite trying to put on a tough act. "Must be his first time in a cell," Amadeus thought, as he looked at the other four. They apeared to be in their late twenties to early forties, and despite being of different races, Amadeus saw that they were harden criminals, who could do almost anything to the boy.

However, as the officer opened the door, all five looked at him, as the officer took the cuffs off of him. The four men each had a look that said, "Interesting looking creature. He'll be fun to, play, with." The boy's eyes, on the other hand, seemed to pop out of his head, as if he was amazed to see him. "Maybe he knows about humans," Amadeus thought, as he entered the cell, keeping an eye on the four men, and sat down on the bench that the boy was sitting at. "Hey kid, is this your first time in prison?" he asked, looking at the four rough men, watching every move they made. "Y-y-yah, but I'm innoscent," the boy said. "Let me guess, some storeclerk saw you with some candy in your pocket, or some such thing, and claims that you are a shoplifter," Amadeus said, as he carefully looked at the boy. He appeared to be about sixteen years old, looked like a humanoid wolf, had a green shirt with a hood, and a red hat on his head. "If only it was that," the boy said. "The police say that I chased one of their squad cars, but I didn't do it. I told them that it was someone else, as I had seen who did it, but when the car came back around, I was the only teenaged wolf with a green hoodie and red hat on the block." At this, Amadeus looked at the boy and said, "Well, I don't know how serious of a crime that chasing a police car is, but, I believe you kid." "Do you?" the boy asked, his eyes widening. "Yep," Amadeus said. "Why do you say that?" the kid asked. "Your eyes tell me that you speak the truth," Amadeus said. "You look into a man's eyes and you will see their whole life. For instance, I can tell that your family cares for you, and will come to pick you up soon." "How do you know that?" "No real parent would leave their child in a cell," Amadeus said, as he noticed the four grown men start to come over. "Ah, the freak is trying to cheer the puppy up," the biggest one, a tiger type creature, said. "Maybe he can help cheer us up to." At this, the other three started to chuckle evily.

However, Amadeus also started to chuckle. "What's so funny?" the leader of the men said. "Only the fact that the four of you, against me, just isn't fair," Amadeus said, as he stood up. "How about two on one, if you include the puppy?" The tiger asked, with an evil smile. "No," Amadeus said. "Just the four of you, against me." "Oh, you're a cocky one," the tiger said, as he and the other three cracked their knuckles, and threw the first punch. However, Amadeus grabbed the man's fist, and bent it backwards, breaking his wrist. He then punched the second, a wolf, like the kid, in the stomach, causing him to double over, kicked the third, a red fox, in between the legs, also causing him excruciating agony, and head-butted the forth, a rinoe like person, knocking him unconsius. He then looked at the tiger, who was clutching his wrist. "What are you?" the man asked, with agony in his voice. At this, Amadeus grabbed his chin, as if deep in thought. "Hmmm. What am I?" he asked out loud. "Oh, that's right, I'm a killer, a trained killer."

He then grabbed the man by this shirt colar, lifted him up, and said, "Look into my eyes buddy. I am Amadeus Orman, I am a soilder, trained from birth, in the art of killing. I have killed things that make most men run home crying for their mothers. Someone like you is nothing compared to some of the things I've had to face." With that, he threw the man, causing him to hit the brick wall, knocking him out. Then, he picked the four up, and set them on the bench across from him and the kid. Then, he started to slap his hands, as if ridding them of something unplesant, and sat back down next to the kid.

"How did you do that?" the boy asked, as he looked at him. "Like I told him," Amadeus said, pointing at the tiger. "I'm a trained soldier." "How did you beat them though?" "You look into someone's eyes, not only do you see their whole life, you will see every move that they will make before they even make it." "Wow! You can really do that?" "Yep, it just takes time. Now, you might want to be careful about what you say. I've got a funny feeling, one that says that someone is about to show up."

Who shows up?

At the sight of them, the wolf child rushed over to them, and the wolf gave him a hug, although when the rabbit tried to give him one, his arms couldn't quite fit between the bars, so he settled for putting his hands on the kid's shoulder.

As Keven smiled at his stepson, glad that he was okay, and no one had harmed him while he had been in the holding cell, he heard a chuckle coming from inside the cell.

When he looked up, he saw four men, two of which were groaning in pain, from injuries of some sort, and the other two seemed to have been knocked out.

Then, he noticed a fifth figure in the shadows, one that seemed to be watching them. "Um, Rudy," he said, in a low voice. "Did something happen before we showed up?"

At this, Rudy looked at the figure, who said, in a male voice, "Go ahead kid, you can tell your parents what those guiys tried to do."

However, when Rudy tried to speak, he had trouble trying to form sentances. "They, try to, attack, me. He, protected, me, from them."

"What are you saying?" Keven asked. "Did those four men try to harm you and he protected you?"

At this, Rudy nodded his head.

Keven then looked at his wife, Kell, and the two of them looked at the man. "Why would you protect my baby?" Kell asked.

"I've been in a prison cell before madam," the man said. "The more hardened criminals tend to abuse first timers, especially juviniles. I remember my first time. I'd been arested for murder, and thrown into a cell with several hardened criminals. Almost all of them, except for one, ganged up on me and started to beat me. My eyes were punched, my nose broken, shoulder dislocated, leg broken, and some of my fingers were busted, before the one who wasn't trying to harm me, finally pulled the others off of me and beat the living daylights out of them. When I asked him why he saved my life, he pointed at his throat, revealing a scar across where his voice box would of been located, which told me he couldn't speak. However, he did have a recording device, and he played a sound bite from it, which told me why he did it."

"Tell me mister," Kell said. "How can I repay you for protecting my son?"

At this, the man chuckled and said, "Let me tell you, as that man told me." With that, he cleared his throat, and said, in a clear voice, with a tune to it,

"You don't owe me a thing.
I've been there too.
But someone once, helped me out,
Just as I'm helping you.
But if you really want to pay me back,
Here's what you do.
Don't let the chain of love, go to waste."

(Don't know the artist's name, but I think the song is called "Don't let the Chain of love go to waste")

"Wow, that's beautiful," Kell said, a tear rolling down her cheak. "Is there more to it?"

"Why, yes there is," the man said, sitting up. "It's the chorus of a song. It starts with a woman parked on the side of the road, because her vehical broke down, and everyone keeps on passing her, untill this guy, in a beat-up vehical, pulls over to the side of the road, and fixes it up. When the woman tries to pay him, he tells her the chorus, that his name was Joe, and that he had also been in trouble, but someone had helped him and he was just retuirning the favor, and left. The woman, who was in shock at the man's kind act of charity, drives to a diner and orders a coffee and sandwich. However, the waitress catches her eyes, as the woman was several months pregnant, and seemed to have some sort of troubles with something. Well, when the woman was getting change for her, as she had given her a large bill, that was almost twenty times more than the price of the coffee and sandwich, she wrote a note on a napkin, what the man had told her earlier that day, and left without getting her change. The waitress was amazed at the woman's generousity, and when she got off of work, and went home, she went to her husband, who was asleep in bed, that things would be alright. Then, she said the final words of the song, 'I love you, Joe.'"

"Wait, let me get this straight," Keven said. "The man who helped the woman out was the husband of the waitress that the woman had left the money for?"

"I wouldn't know," the man said. "However, it is a fair assumption to make. Needless to say, it sort of explains why I hepled your son out. I was returning a favor of sorts, one that I owed to the man who had saved my life."

"Well, is there a real way that we can pay you back?" Keven asked.

"Well, I could use some help in getting out, leagelly of course," the man said. "Of course, it would help if I knew what I was being charged with."

"Didn't they tell you when they arrested you?" Kell asked, looking at the man who had protected her son out of the kindness of his heart. "It's in their regulations to inform one of their rights, as well as what they were being charged with."

"Well, they must think that I don't have any then," the man said, laying out on the bench, revealing that he had some weird looking paws (Amadeus's boots), and that his fur was completly covered with clothing. "After all, I'm what you would call an alien I guess."

"Mom, he's a human," Rudy whispered.

At this, Keven and Kell looked at each other.

"Didn't Aura's cousin say that the portal to the human world was blocked?" Keven asked.

"Yah, but you know about what happened with your sister's counterpart," Kell said. "There was a storm and she came through. He might of come through during the blackout, just like she did."

Then Keven looked at the man, who had stood up and walked into the light where he could be seen, revealing that he was a human, one with a strange outfit, that looked like a mixture of wolf fur and military uniform, with a large green stain on it. "Who are you?" he asked. "And how did you get here?"

"I am Amadeus Orman, a soldier in the Combine military," the man said. "As for how I got here, while I don't know exactly how I got here, I was heading home after playing some games with my buddies when there was a blackout and a portal opened up and pulled me through to your world. Needless to say, I'm kind of lost to the rest of the Combine."

"Well, we do owe you," Keven said. "And besides, unless you've been charged with a crime, the police can't hold you for more than twenty-four hours."

"And since you father is a criminal, you would know about that," Kell said, as she looked at her husband.

At this, Keven chuckled and said, "For once, my father's choice of career helps someone out."

***

Half an hour later, Amadeus was by the reclaiming booth, getting the things that the police had confiscated from him.

"Let's see," he said. "Pistol, check. Ax, check. Belt, check. Zee, triple check, can't wait until you decide to wake up buddy. About the only thing missing is my helmet." At this, a clang is heard. "We were making sure that it did come from someone's head," the officer said, as Amadeus started to walk towards the front of the station.

When he got to the front, Amadeus saw that the Dewclaws were waiting for him. Keven had told the prison officials that holding a man who was not imformed of his rights was against the law and that the man would file charges of unlawful arrest unless he was released, immediatly.

"Thanks Mr. Dewclaw," Amadeus said, as he shook the rabbit's left hand, which the man had offered. "While I know that I could of broken out on my own, I wasn't in the mood for a man hunt, as it were."

At this, Keven just chuckled and said, "Well, be lucky that you didn't. When it comes to hunting, my wife is the best."

At this, Kell said, "Oh, you always know what to say to make me happy." With that, she kissed him on the cheek.

"By the way," Amadeus said. "Do you have a place that I could stay? After all, something tells me that the motels, or hotels, or whatever, won't let me check in, nor would they accept my money."

"Well, you could use our daughter's old room," Keven said, as he scratched the back of his head. "When she's not in collage, Lindesfare is at her boyfriend's house, Tree."

"Hey, I'd settle for sleeping on the couch," Amadeus said, as the four walked to the door to find that......
12132.title: Dewclaws, meet Amadeus, Amadeus, meet the Dewclaws

121322.content:
"Oh crud," Amadeus said, as he looked out the window on the door of the police station.

"What's the matter?" Keven asked.

"Oh, not much," Amadeus said. "Except for the fact that there is a ton of reporters and cameramen out there, all waiting for me to show my face. While I don't know what they are like here, where I am from, everytime something happens, they swarm like, now what did my friend say that those birds that ate carion were called, oh yah, vultures."

"Actually, they are worse than that," Kell said. "After all, Herdthinners employs several of them to clean up what the hunters miss during their hunts. In fact, I'm friends with a few of them."

"Well either way, I am not showing my face, at least not like this," Amadeus said, as he guestured towards the green stain on his uniform, and his furless face, and his hands, which had no claws to speak of. "Of course, I can just clean my outfit, put my helmat on, and put my hands in my pockets, and walk out, without attracting much attention, I hope."

"Why are you worried about your face and fur?" Rudy asked. "You could just beat them like you did those four men."

"Kid, being able to do something and doing it are two different things," Amadeus said, as he shook his head, looking at the boy. "For one thing, I could of easily killed those four men, but I didn't. I held back on purpose, because I do not want to just kill someone who stood no chance against me. Those reporters are the same, I can't just beat them up, because they are not a threat to me. However, I've got to limit my exposer on this world, and that means disguising my appearance to a degree, because there are certain rules that I have to follow in situations like this. 1. Limit interferance in a society's culture as much as possible. 2. Don't kill anyone, unless they are a threat to your life. 3. Try to make contact with Combine forces. 4. If contact with Combine is impossible, assimilate into the culture as best as you can. 5. Don't give out top secret information about the Combine to anyone, not even those you trust. 6. Avoid using technology that is beyond the culture's capability to produce, unless it is something that they could possibly make. 7. Stay near where you arrived, unless the area is too dangerous to remain near, for any reason."

"Whow, so many rules," Rudy said, as he looked at the human.

"Actually, those are the basic ones kid," Amadeus said. "In any case, I best clean myself off, put my helmat on, and hope for the best."

****

"This is Katty Blackfur reporting for Channle Two News," said a female black cat. "Various sources say that during the blackout some sort of portal opened in the heart of the city of Domain. Some of these sources claim that an alien came through the portal and tried to talk to them before the police arrived and fired at the creature. Eyewitnesses claim that the police chased the creature to an alleyway, where it is said that the creature gave itself up without a fight and was taken to the station. Needless to say, the police can only confirm that they arrested a suspicious looking man who had fled the area. Other than that, they are not saying a word."

Suddenly, the door opens, but just as the reporters start to rush forward, all that comes out is a wolf with his hands in his pockets, and a disheveled uniform. "Hey mister," Katty Blackfur said, as she brought the mike near the man. "Given that you just came out of the police station, perhaps you can answer a few questions."

"Well, what do you want to know?" the man asked, with a slight slur.

"Can you confirm if the police have an alien in their custady?" Katty asked.

"No, I can not confim that miss," the man said, as he walked past her, keeping his head low, and walking with a bit of a drunken stuper, and bumping into a few of the reporters and cameramen.

***

A while later, the Dewclaws come out, after telling Rudy to keep quiet about Amadeus. When the reporters asked Keven and Kell what they had seen, they said that they had seen nothing unusual, which meant nothing, especially since a rabbit marrying a wolf was unusual enough. However, one of the reporters asked Rudy if he'd seen anything unusual.

Question, does Rudy keep his mouth shut, or does he say something?
121322.title: There is a sea of reporters and cameras

choices: "No, someone else did it, and my name was cleared."
"Yes, I killed a man, but I had my reasons for doing it."
1213221.content:
As Rudy heard the question that the reporter asked him, he looked at Amadeus, who was acting like a drunken soldier, who'd been arrested for being drunk in public, and disturbing the peace or some such thing. The man's act was very convincing, and even his breath smelled like he'd been drinking, due to a jell filled capsule that he'd put in his mouth and caused to burst, after he'd cleaned his outfit of the green bloodlike stain on his outfit.

"Um, Mom, Keven, can we go home," he said. "I don't feel so good."

As Kell looked at her son, she noticed that he was indead pale, as if he was sick. However, she knew that he was nervous, both because he'd just been in a holding cell, and because he didn't want to betray the trust of the man who'd saved his life and give him away.

"Yah, we better get you home," she said, as she pick her son up, and started carrying him to the car, an easy task concidering she'd taken down things larger than her son while hunting at work.

Keven then looked at Amadeus, who had just stumbled into yet another cameraman. If he didn't know better, he would of thought that the man really was drunk.

"Hey sir," he said, walking up to him. "Would you like a lift? You look like you could use one."

"Whyssh, thankshhh," Amadeus said, as he seemed to look at the rabbit, getting ready to fall upon his feet again. "Your a nicssshe, Sholdier."

With that, Keven put one of the man's arms around his neck and started to carry him.

"Arn't you going a little far with the drunken soldier act?" he asked.

"One could," Amadeus said, in a low voice that was barely audible, even to Keven's sensitive ears. "However, I've had to deal with some of my comrades when they got drunk, and this is how they tended to act when they were sobering up."

"Yah well, you better do something about you breath," Keven said, turning his head away to a degree. "Most people tend to have very sensitive noses around here, including my wife and stepson."

"Oh, I wouldn't worry about that," Amadeus said, as he leaned on the man's shoulder. "I've got a couple of capsules that will make my breath smell like peppermint or spearmint, or some type of mint at any rate. Very useful when there is a lovely woman some place and I had forgotten to brush my teeth that day. After all, one wants to leave the ladies with a good first impression, so they will ask you out in the future."

At this, Keven chuckled and said, "Your right on that. I remember when I first met Kell. She didn't know if she wanted to have me for dinner, or FOR DINNER, if you catch my drift."

"Don't they all," Amadeus said, with a chuckle of his own. "While I've never been at risk of being put on the menue, as it were, I dated a woman who was either a nice person to chat with, or someone who makes a murderer look like saint in comparison, because she was two people in one, seriously."

***

A while later, when Keven opened up the door to the back of his car and helped the man get in, and start to drive away, Amadeus reached pulled his one hand out of his pocket and put a capsule in his mouth and bit down, causing his breath to smell like mint.

"Much better," he said. "The scent of alcohol gives me a bit of a headache, especially given the fact that I've got this helmat on."

"Well, why don't you take it off now?" Keven asked, looking in the mirror. "I doubt that anyone would get a clear shot of you at this distance."

"I guess you are right," Amadeus said, as he looked behind them. "I'd just prefer to be on the safe side until we reach your home. After all, sometimes the moment that you let your guard down, turns into the last moment of your life."

"Personal experiance I take," Keven said.

"Yah," Amadeus said, with a slow nod. "I remember one night when me and some of my comrades were sitting around a campfire, swapping stories, when next thing I knew, a sniper's bullit took the lives of the guy next to me, and the fella across from him. I tell you, being that close to death makes you aprectate life, even when you think you are having the worst day of your life, because you could of been killed instead."

"Is your whole species like that?" Rudy asked, his eyes widening when he heard what the man who had saved his life had said. "Killing each other that is?"

"Depends on who you ask," Amadeus said. "Some say that we are a peaceful race, who only fight when necesary, and others argue that we are the most violent race in existance, who take great pleasure in killing each other, and others."

"Well, here's a question," Kell said, looking at him. "When you said that you'd been arrested for murder when you were first taken to jail, did you do it?"

At this, Amadeus says.....
1213221.title: Rudy keeps quiet.

choices: "I wonder if they'll have a room avalible for the night."
"I'll stay here for the night, and check them out tomarrow
12132212.content:
"Yah, I killed a man," Amadeus said. "However, I had my reasons for doing so."

"And what would those be?" Keven asked, concerned about what the man had just said, especially concidering that the man was righ behind him, and could easily reach his arm around the headrest and try to choke him to death, or cause them to have an accident at any rate.

"The man killed my sister," he said.

"Oh, you have my sympathes," Keven said. "One of my own sisters was killed to."

"Yah, but was she raped by the person who had killed her, and beaten within an inch of her life?" Amadeus asked.

"No," Keven said, as a tear came to his eyes. "She was killed when we took down a group of extreamly radical rabbits that tried to kidnap my and Kell's daughter, Coney. It was just when she and George were destroying the group's computer files that George accidently triggered a trap and Danielle pushed him out of the way and-"

At this, Keven pulls the car over to the side of the road and starts to cry, remembering what happened that awful night. He had just finished taking out the remaining members of the group when Gerorge walked out of a room, carrying the body of his sister. She'd given her life for the fennic fox, whom she had had something of a close friendship with.

"I understand," Amadeus said, as he put a hand on the rabbit's shoulder. "I felt the same way when my sister was murdered. However, I got my revenge, and beat the man to within an inch of his life."

"Why didn't you let the athourities take care of it?" Kell asked, as she comforted her husband.

"The athourities would not of been able to do a thing, not even if he did it in front of the whole police department," Amadeus said, with a sigh. "The man was the son of an ambassador, and as a result, he had diplomatic immunity from the law. But, as her brother, he had no such immunity from me."

"What did you do to him?" Rudy asked, wondering about the man who had just caused his stepfather to cry like the day his step-aunt died, saving the life of his girlfriend's, Fiona, father.

"Back then, I was a miner, digging out rocks that held important metels or stones that were valuable to the right people, as well as a construction worker, building houses for the miners and their families near the mines," Amadeus said. "As a result, I was stronger than the average person who lived in the cities. This man, he'd never worked a day in his life. He'd had it all, money, servants, expensive, and massive, mansions, everything. Well that day, I made him work for his life. He thought that weight lifting and martial arts training would make him strong enough to beat a man, who'd been a miner and construction worker, who had nothing left to lose. Well, he was wrong. I broke every bone in his body with my hands, everything from his toes on up to his skull, and left him to die, just as he left my sister to die. After my sister's funeral, the police, who were decent enough to wait, arrested me."

"Well, how did you get out of prison?" Rudy asked.

"After about a month in jail, a recruitment officer showed up, and looked at the evidance against me, which was obvious, because everyone knew that I was the one who did it, and told me that I had two choices, life in prison, or life in the service of the Combine military forces. I chose the military option, and I haven't looked back since," Amadeus said, as he turned his head to look out the window, to look up at the sky, where his home was, someplace way out there in space. "That was about four hundred of your planet's years back, back when I was about twenty of this planet's years old."

"Wait, how old did you say you were?" Kell asked, as she and Keven, who had dried his tears by this time, turned to look at him.

"Well, that would depend on which planet I'm on," Amadeus said, still looking up at the sky, trying to locate where his home was. "On some planets I'm over a thousand years old, on some I'm less than ten years old. On this planet, if my calculations are correct, I'm about four hundred and twenty years old, if I'm judging the distance this planet is from your sun correctly, and how far the horizian is, to mesure the curviture of this planet, and calculate both its size and the length of its day. If I am correct, it takes about twenty-four hours for this planet to make a revolution, and about three hundred sixty-five of its days for it to compleate one orbit around the sun, am I right?"

"Y-y-yes," Kell said, nervously.

"Then that means that I'm about four hundred twenty years old on this planet," Amadeus said. "Of course, I've got a funny feeling about this planet, a very funny feeling."

"And what would this feeling be?" Rudy asked, as he knew that the man had been on the ball every time he'd said something.

"That for the first time in my life, I feel like I'm home," Amadeus said, as he looked at the wolf cub. "And that is a feeling that I've never had."

"Well, in that case," Rudy said. "That must mean that your planet must be like Earth then."

"Wait, did you just say that this planet is Earth?" Amadeus said, his eyes growing under his helmat.

"Yyyah," Rudy said. "What's so important about that?"

At this, Amadeus started to laugh. "No wonder I feel like I'm home, I am home," he said, still laughing.

"What do you mean?" Keven asked, looking at the human that was disguised as a wolf.

"Only humans will call a planet Earth," Amadeus said. "Especially when they resemble the legandary home planet of humankind, a planet that had a surface that was about seventy percent water, and thirty percent land, had a yellow sun, with an atmosphere that was about seventy percent nitrigian, twenty-nine percent carbon-dioxide, and one percent trace amounts of other elements, had twenty-four hours in a day, and three hundred sixty-five days in a year."

"Well if it was so important to your kind, why did you leave it?" Rudy asked.

"Well, if there is any thing about humans being the most destructive race out there, there is a grain of truth to that," Amadeus said. "We ruined it, ruined it beyond recovery, or so we thought, until I came here."

"Well, if what Danielle says is true," Rudy said, looking at the man. "There is a parralel Earth out there, inhabited by humans, who live lives similar to our own."

"Wait, didn't Keven just say that Danielle died?" Amadeus asked.

"I did," Keven said, as he started the car back up, and got back on the road. "But about a month later, she showed up, claiming that she was really a human that had been turned into a rabbit. At first we thought that it was just because of the shock of coming back from the dead or something, until her wedding to George, when we learned that she, and my stepdaughter, Lindesfare, really were humans from another world. Needless to say, it was a bit of a shock but, well, they are still family where it counts."

"Arn't they always," Amadeus said, with a smile under his helmat. "Me and my comrads tend to call each other brothers and sisters, especially since we've been through the worst battles we've ever fought, survived things no one else has, and shed blood for each other. If that isn't a family, I don't know what is."

****

About thirty minutes later, they pulled up at the Dewclaws' place, which was a large tree.

"Well, here we are," Keven said, as he opened up the door to let Amadeus out.

"It's not quite what I was expecting to see," the man said, as he looked at the tree, which had several windows carved into it.

Then, he pointed over towards a mansion, which was across from an identical one, a short distance away from the first, and said, "I was kind of expecting something more like that place over there, although a little smaller perhaps."

"Well that's Fiona's place," Rudy said. "She owns both of them, living in one, and using the other as a bording house."

At this, Amadeus says...
12132212.title: "Yes, I killed a man, but I had my reasons ...

choices: Cigar, which the man lights, revealing him to be a rabbit looking a bit like Kev
Knife, which the man tries to stab him with, forcing Amadeus to fire the gun
121322122.content:
"Well, I guess that I could check them out tomarrow," Amadeus said. "After all, it is late, and I know that I would hate it if someone woke me up this late at night, if it weren't for the fact that I've learned to sleep at any chance that I can get, however brief."

"What do you mean by that?" Rudy asked, as he had once concidered joining the military a few years back.

"Imagine trying to go through an entire week of seven days, or one hundred forty eight hours, on only four hours of sleep, and the rest of the time someone is shooting at you," Amadeus said, as he looked at the kid. "Even in the best of conditions it is not easy to do that, as you will start to become tired, and become more tired as the longer you go without sleep. In combat though, you are moving, shooting, ducking, punching, kicking, stabbing, biting, scratching, and whatnot, trying to kill your enemy before he kills you, and losing energy the whole time."

"So, how do you do it?" Rudy asked.

"You either stay awake, and live, or die in your sleep," Amadeus said, as Keven unlocked the door to the house.

***

As Amadeus entered the house, uh, tree, Kell said, "You must be hungry Mr. Orman. If you want, there is some leftover venison in the fridge if you want something to eat."

At this, Amadeus stopped, and asked, "I'd hate to ask, but did it come from another person?"

"Well, technecally, yah, it did come from another person," Kell said.

"Well, while I'm not going to change your life style, but, unless they died of natural causes, such as sickness or old age, or were going to die anyways, or I was starving to death, I can't just eat the flesh of another sentiant being," Amadeus said. "It's nothing against you or anything, it's a law, and regulation, that was created when the Combine allowed races that were not human to join the military, and some of them came from worlds where canibalism was practiced. So, I hope that you are not offended if I said no thanks."

"I understand, Mr. Orman," Kell said. "Of course we do have fruits and vegtables in the fridge, and in cans in the cuboards, as well as tofu."

"That will be alright," Amadeus said, as he took his helmat off. "And please, either call me Amadeus, or Deus. The last person to actually say my last name was the man who raped and murdered my sister when I showed up at his house armed with a pickax handle and a length 4by4, that I'd made a hand grip for, that was about three feet long, both of which I used to take out his guards, before I killed him with my own two hands. After that, no one called me by my last name, unless it was for formalities, and I always asked them to not say my last name around me after that. That part of me died when my sister died."

"Oh, I'm sorry," Kell said. "I hope that I didn't offend you when I called you that."

"Oh I don't take offence at that," Amadeus said. "Now being called a cocky glory-hog though, now them's fighting words in my book." Then, he started to laugh, which caused the others to chuckle, and smiled. Even if he was indeed lost to the rest of the Combine, at least he had a few friends, and was truely home, on the original home world.

****

Later that night, after a late supper, where Amadeus met Kell's mother, Elanor, and Keven and Kell's daughter, Coney, who looked like a rabbit, like her father, but she seemed to take after her mother, in terms of her diet, Amadeus was in a room, that had more that a few boxes, and a bed that had a few quills, trying to sleep, but his mind was wide awake. He, Amadeus Orman, had found the perverbial holy grail, the REAL EARTH. If nothing else, even if the Combine never found him, it was still something to be proud of.

Suddenly, he had one of his funny feelings, grabbed his pistol, and, after setting it to stun, started to walk around the hallways, looking for the thing that had disturbed his rest.

Then, he saw someone enter through the window. The person was about a head shorter than him, and had his back to him, and had something in his hand, which he put into his pocket.

Amadeus then walked up to him, and stuck the muzzle of the gun in the person's back, and said, "Take your hand from your pocket, and whatever you have it, slowly."

The man slowly pulled the object from his pocket, revealing it to be a.....
121322122.title: "I'll stay here for the night, and chec...

choices: Elanor, Kell's mother (No need to worry about disguise around her)
another woman. (Kell has friends over, disguise needed, now!)
1213221221.content:
"It's just a cigar buddy," the man said, with something of a low deep voice, as he pulled the object out of his pocket, with his back still facing Amadeus. "I hope that you don't mind if I smoke, concidering that this is my son's place."

"Be my guest," Amadeus said. "Of course, don't think that I am a compleate fool, so keep your hands where I can see them."

"No problem buddy," the man said, who was a rabbit, which Amadeus realized when the moonlight came through the window. "My lighter is in my other pocket. Can you get it for me?"

"Yah," Amadeus said. "I can do that. Just don't try anything foolish. I was trained by the best when it comes to close-quarters combat, and I can kill someone without trying, which means that I've got to be careful about how much strength I use if I want to take someone alive."

With this, the rabbit seemed to chuckle. "Were you in the army or some such thing?" he asked.

"I guess you could say that," Amadeus said, as he got the man's lighter out of his pocket. "Oh course, you could say that I'm on an extream version of shore leave."

Then, he carefully lit the cigar, which the man put in his mouth, and started to smoke.

"Well, can I turn around?" the man asked. "After all, when I saw my son pull up to the driveway, with a third wolf in his car, one that I did not know, I came to check out my son's guest, and see who he was."

"Go right ahead," Amadeus said, as he put his pistol in his holster. "After all, if it weren't for the fact that I haven't been able to see my kids in years, I'd want to know who was in the house with them myself."

***

However, when Bentley Kindle (*Note* I got the name for Kevin's father off of wikipedia, under the part for Kevin and Kell) turned around, to look at what he had thought was a large wolf, he was shocked, and besides almost having a heart attack, he almost dropped his cigar.

"Damn," he said, as he repositioned his cigar. "You were not what I was expecting."

"Don't worry about it," Amadeus said, with a bit of a chuckle. "When most people hear of me, they assume that I'm some tall ass giant."

"Oh, why is that?" Pa Kindle, as he was also called, asked.

"You wouldn't understand it even if I told you," Amadeus said, with a chuckle. "But, I have taken on some rather hard to defeat beings and won."

"Well, I know this much," the rabbit said. "Anyone who can sneak up behind me, without me noticing them, has my respect. I'll tell you what, don't tell my son that I was here in his house, and smoking at that, and I won't say a word about you."

"I'd aprectate that," Amadeus said, as he offered his hand out. "Let's shake on it."

"Sure thing," Bentley said, as he shook the offered hairless paw.

After that, when he left out the window, he put his hand in his pocket, and found, instead of the pistol that he thought that he had taken from the creature, his own lighter.

"Damn," he thought, as he looked back at the strange creature, who just twirled the pistol in front of him. "He's good."

"And just where would that be?" Katty asked.

"The only place that I wouldn't stand out at," Amadeus said. "The Dewclaws."

"I know that place," Katty said. "I'll be there."

"I'll have to ask the Dewclaws of course," Amadeus said. "After all, it doesn't pay to invite an unwanted person to the home of one's host."

"Alright," Katty said, getting a card out. "Call me if you get premission."

"Sure thing. Of course, we best get going. Those guys might wake up soon."

"Guess so," Katty said as she turned to her cameraman. "Hey Robert, do you know a shortcut back to town through the Rabbit Warren?"

"Yeah," said the cameraman. "But I'd have to blindfold you guys. Warren rules."
1213221221221122222222.title: Aranging Interview

choices: An anthromophic wolf, male presumably, and young
A quilled creature, probably female, anthromorphic
A large canine, anthromorphic, probably the dumps owner
13.content:
Everywhere around Amadeus stood what looked like old style land vehicles he had driven in various Games, as well as one some of the Prim worlds he'd been the visitor on. These though didn't look like they were in any condition to run as some lacked wheels and seats, others engines, and still others were just empty chassises sitting in the dirt rusting away peacefully.

In the distance a large sun, yellow and thus most likely H-class, burning hydrogen rather than any of the heavier gas elements. Sniffing at the air Amadeus was surprised by the lack of fumes that normally were associated with the industry required to create and run the vehicles around him, but inspection of one of the few engines showed him why.

The motors of the transports that still had them were designed to burn ethanol rather than a petroleum extract that was the usual mode of combustion in such engines. Taking a look at the interiors of the vehicles provided him with a clue as to the average size of the native population by gauging how much space the seats provided. He guessed them to be about hominid medium size, same as his own homo sapien race, which seemed about right as the planet's gravity felt to be about one grav, and that was a usual indication of the local biosphere's proportions.

"Well at least I don't have to deal with fifty foot monsters," said the extraterrestrial to himself, slamming his palm onto one of the derelicts before walking off into the rest of the yard. Oddly it looked like something recent had caused a shift in the piles of various debris, many still having small avalanches of car parts and other garbage rolling down their side.

As he walked Amadeus took stock of his situation by running his hand over his belt. Pulling at the Startec pistol he discovered the weapon to still be in working order, or at least the gun thought itself to be. Whether it was or not he didn't want to test as he was pretty confident that the magnetic stream caused by the guns firing would rip a few of the errant metal objects out of place and possibly bury him in the cast offs of whatever civilization held sway on this planet.

His next order of business was to grip the pouch on the other side of the belt, ripping it open and staring inside. Luckily most of his personal possessions seemed to have survived their trip through whatever it was that had drawn him into the sky intact, though the flute looked like it had gotten scratched in his rough landing.

"I can buff that out later," he commented, replacing the top of the pouch before putting his hands behind his back and withdrawing what looked to be a small PDA. Obviously the odd display of bits and pieces of various images was not what Amadeus had wanted to see as he swore violently in his native tongue smashing his palm into the side of the device.

"Zee, you don't want to leave me here alone do you? Come on and pull yourself together," he ordered the device, and was answered by a series of whining pulses and beeps that ended in a steady high pitched tone. The screen then went blank for a moment before a timer appeared displaying that it would be a couple of cycles before the unit's logic string recovered from whatever it was that had thrown it for a loop.

"You're never there when I need you, you know that?" he told the device, getting only silence in answer as the timer continued to count down. Looking up at the sun and estimating the planet's rotation to be somewhere around sixteen cycles, though probably a little less. That time struck him as odd as it was the same rotation as Old Home Terra, the legendary home planet of humans, or at least it was according to the Games Jasmine designed.

"Heh, she really believes it exists too," said Amadeus, remembering all the arguments he'd had with Jasmine about it. He was of the opinion that the planet was a myth, something dreamed up to give the people something to search for always. After all expeditions that were searching for the lost homeworld were launched everyday, and it always filled the people with hope that maybe they would find it this time, though they never did. After all you can't find something that isn't real.

Lost in his thoughts Amadeus nearly missed the sound of footsteps as the approached. Not wanting to cause a panic just yet among the locals Amadeus decided quickly it would be best to hide, and so dove into one of the derelict vehicle frames, rolling into the back seat so that he could stare out of one of the rusted holes in the back door. Looking over at the direction from which the footfalls were coming Amadeus stared in anticipation as the figure rounded a corner and came into his view. It was a shocking view too as the figure turned out to be...
13.title: Down in the Dumps

131.content:
Amadeus stifled a gasp as the creature rounded the corner and he was staring at a huge lizard thing. No stranger to alien worlds and their inhabitants Amadeus was still struck by the creature's appearance, which reminded him of some of the monsters he'd faced in various wars on untold planets. The creature stood almost three meters in height, towering over the vehicle relics around it, and it's triangular head whip about, scanning the surroundings for something with both its eyes and nose as it sniffed the air.

Walking on two legs the creature looked quite capable of running on all four to increase its top speed, though likely at the expense of agility. Other striking features included the claws which tipped its three fingered hands and feet. Almost a third of a meter in length the things looked more than capable of ripping through the metal bodies around the creature, and when it ran the tip of one claw over a vehicle chassis it left a small streak of yellow, presumably some kind of poison.

The most starling feature though was the tail, which looked to be only a meter long at most when Amadeus first glimpsed it, but proved itself to be on a kind of catch spring, able to shoot out at high speed growing to nearly five meters and adding force to the blow. On the tip of the tail was a hooked claw, and it looked even stronger than the claws on the creature's hands and feet.

With a violence that seemed sudden the tail whipped out slammed into a nearby vehicle, smashing through the side before the creature retracted it, ripping off the door and sending it sailing through the air. The creature then pulled at a belt which Amadeus had not noticed before and pulled off a strange device which the Combine soldier recognized a primitive radio communicator, probably made for short range communication with a receiver held by another nearby agent.

"I don't see anything. Are you sure this is the arrival point?" demanded the creature of whoever was on the other end. Surprisingly the thing was speaking English, a language Amadeus knew through the Games he'd played set on Earth. The language had been for a time the closest thing to a universal dialect the planet had, had, at least according to those who believed in it.

Oddly the device only crackled and sparked at the creature, emitting tones and pulses similar to those that Zee had been when Amadeus had tried to wake the CAP. Obviously Amadeus was not the only one having trouble, though the creature took the devices failure to respond much more harshly that Amadeus had Zee's. Swearing and cursing the thing beat on the small transmitter with its hand before the device finally gave under its strength, shattering into dozens of pieces, which solicited a whole new round of profanities from the creature.

Amadeus, still unsure of what exactly the creature was looking for, though he assumed he was the target, was faced with a decision. He could reveal himself to it, and hope that despite appearances the creature proved friendly, or at least benign. And then of course there was the ever faithful Plan QRITOD, which stood for Quickly Run Away In The Opposite Direction, his favorite fall back plan if he could think of nothing else.
131.title: Meet Mr. Lizard

1311.content:
Amadeus, after only a few seconds thought decided to try and approach the creature. If he was indeed the target then finding out why the thing wanted him was a priority. Besides if the thing was evolved to exist in only the one grav that the planet had then he would be able to at least fight on its level. He was after all a trained soldier, and had taken on much bigger foes, though usually with backup waiting in the wings.

"Excuse me, would you happen to be looking for me?" he asked the creature as he climbed out of the derelict vehicle's remains. The creature, surprised by the new voice, jumped up onto one of the piles of chassises. The thing looked nothing if not like a cat waiting to pounce on a mouse that had suddenly emerged from its hole. Amadeus though recognized a fighter when he saw one, and knew that unlike the cat, this thing wasn't likely to give up if he ran back into his hole.

"Now, let's not be hasty here. I'm sure two gentlemen like ourselves can come to an accord without resorting to violence," he said, fingering his pistol. Hopefully the creature recognized the tiny thing as a weapon of immense power. If it didn't then Amadeus might actually have to fire the thing, with results he didn't think he could predict.

For a moment the creature eyed the weapon before grabbing something from the pile that Amadeus believed was called a hubcap, though this one was razor thing and looked almost as sharp as the creature's own claws. After a second of worrying that thing might throw the hubcap as a weapon Amadeus relaxed as the creature's attention seemed focused on the object, and he began to hope that maybe he hadn't been the object the thing sought at all.

Then without any sign or warning the creature threw the hubcap straight at Amadeus. Unable to react in time Amadeus believed he was dead for a moment, before observing that the projectile's flight path just barely intersected the spot where he stood. Before he could use that information though the human cried out in pain as the sharp disk bit into his hip, and then he felt the weight of his belt fall away.

About to go for the weapon that was still in the belt Amadeus was stopped when the lizard creature landed nearly on top of him, having used the spring like back legs to vault into the air, leaping a dozen meters high before coming down right on top of Amadeus. Rolling to one side to avoid a sweeping slash of the things poisoned claws Amadeus took the only immediate action that seemed appropriate and ran into the junkyard away from the belt and the creature.

His hope was that maybe the thing would try and use his weapon against him, kicking in the devices safeties which allowed only Amadeus himself to wield it giving a stunning shock to anyone else who dared try and raise it against anyone. Unfortunately either the creature knew about that particular defense or simply did not wish to wield the unknown weapon, bounding after Amadeus on all fours.

Knowing instantly that he could not outdistance the creature, who's top speed was almost twice his own even in the light planetary gravity, Amadeus knew he needed a new plan, and fast or he'd become a scratching post for the odd creature. Looking around provided him with dozens of ideas that ranged from using a car part as a weapon to trying to push a stack of cars over on the creature, but he doubted the thing would be hurt by anything Amadeus could wield directly, and that it wouldn't stay still long enough to get crushed.

Then out of the corner of his eye Amadeus glimpsed one of the larger stacks of derelicts and an idea formed in his head, though it would involve a bit of gymnastics that he wasn't sure he could pull off. Still with nothing else presenting itself Amadeus switched his course, and proved his guess about the creature's limited mobility while running on all fours. The thing had to almost stop to change direction, or it would literally topple head over heels in the direction it had been moving.

That fact against a non-sentient or even just a beast-type mindset would have given Amadeus the chance to get away by running in a zigzag pattern, but he doubted seriously that the creature would fall for such a trick, especially if Amadeus really was his target, a fact which seriously did not doubt now, but wasn't going to let go until the creature confirmed it himself.

Arriving at his target Amadeus leaped up in a manner similar to a cat, coiling his body like a spring before releasing every erg of his energy upward. The force of the leap carried Amadeus up a good five yards before he felt his momentum slacken and Amadeus grabbed one of the vehicles that made up the pile before him. Not resting for a second the human began to climb as fast as he could up the precariously rocking tower of metal, which seemed almost ready to tip over.

Sensing a trap the creature slid to a halt just out of range of the tower's fall. Arriving at the top Amadeus observed this fact with some consternation as his plan relied on the creature getting closer to the tower. Looking over the hood of the top derelict of the pile Amadeus stared down at the creature which stared back with bloodthirsty eyes, and he knew that if he fell off his perch the creature was likely to charge in an go for the quick kill.

That thought did not help when Amadeus suddenly found the ground under his feet titling, and looked back to find the vehicle he was standing on leaning forward towards the edge of the tower. Falling to his knees he tried to grasp the hood of transport, but found that the smooth metal of the hood provided no traction. Swearing profusely the human slipped those last few centimeters and in a mimic of his earlier dive fell to the ground below, though this time he landed on his butt rather than his face.

"Well, better than another face plant," he commented to himself, springing to his feet. Before him the creature sensed a chance to take down his prey, and rushed forward with reckless abandon. Amadeus, seeing the look in the things eyes, began to run away, but found his path blocked by the tower of derelicts that had moments ago been his salvation, but now spelled his doom. The creature, jaws wide and claws dripping poison rushed forward, and Amadeus turned to meet him. At that moment a new sound overtakes the dump. It is the sound of...
1311.title: Friendly, he ain't

choices: Try and get to his belt
13112.content:
Smiling to himself at the sound Amadeus leapt backwards just as the creature sprang forward, landing right in the spot where Amadeus had been standing a moment before. The creature, focused as it was on its target, did not hear the sound of scraping metal, and the first clue it had that anything bad was going to happen to it was the sudden darkness that overtook the area where it had stopped. Looking up it had no time to react as the top vehicle of the stack fell straight towards it, smashing into the creatures with a thunderous crash, kicking up a cloud of dust that obscured the scene for meters around.

When the sound of the various small bits falling atop the crashed car finally ceased the dust began to settle and Amadeus was rewarded for his plan with the sight of the lizard creature stuck under the chassis, the bottom half of it's body crushed under the derelict and a mound of other small metal pieces that had fallen with the derelict from the pile. The creature at first seemed dead, and Amadeus was afraid that he might have overestimated the creature's resilience, but after a second or two the thing began to thrash and jerk, trying to pull itself out from under the junk which buried it.

Amadeus sighed in relief when the creature stopped its struggles, mostly because he was half certain that the thing might be able to move the junk off itself, but luckily the pile proved to great, and the creature stopped at stared at its captor. His smile vanishing in a single instant Amadeus reached under the fur cloak he wore and withdrew the axe which he probably could have used to slay the creature before, but had not used because he needed information, and corpses had the annoying habit of keeping what they knew to themselves most of the time.

"Ok, now that I have your attention, how about you explain why you're looking for me, and maybe how I got here," he suggested to the creature, fingering the edge of the axe before holding it high over his head and slicing into one of the derelicts at the bottom of the pile. In a flash the axe was again at Amadeus' side and neither he nor the creature could see a flaw in the metal of the chassis, but an errant shift in the wind tugged at the thing, and a moment later the front hood of the transport fell to the ground, having been cleanly chopped off by the blade's sharp edge and the wielder's prodigious strength.

"Or do I need to use some of those fine interrogation techniques that you can learn in any starport dive if you watch long enough," he said, wondering if the creature could be intimidated by the show of strength. He doubted it, but it was worth a shot. Walking forward he stood right before the creature so that it had to crane its neck and look up at him before lowering himself to his heels and staring the thing in the face. The creature, stuck under the derelict said nothing in response to the threat, but rather began to struggle again, at least wriggle one arm free from under the pile of debris.

Amadeus, fearful of what the poison in the thing's claws could do to him, sprang backwards, and just in time too as the now free appendage swiped at him. With the attack failed the creature went back to trying to work its way free of the rubble under which it was buried, and Amadeus knew he had to attack before the thing could do that, as he might never be able to trap it again. Thinking fast Amadeus leapt forward again, surprising the creature with his dexterity and agility as he lightly swung his axe at the monster, who braced for a fatal blow. When it opened its eyes though it was still alive, if now minus a hand.

"How about you take my threats seriously from now on?" Amadeus asked the trapped lizard, kicking the severed hand which he had just lopped off the creature's arm closer to its former owner. Oddly the creature took greater interest in the hand then it did in the one who was threatening it, trying to hit it with the stump of an arm it now had. Unfortunately for it Amadeus' swing had sent the appendage a few centimeters away, and even his kick had not moved it back into range, but to prevent the creature from reaching the hand he slammed the iron heel of his climbing boot atop the flailing arm, sticking it to the ground.

"Hey, I'm talking to you!" complained Amadeus, holding his axe right in the creature's face. Surprisingly instead of balking at the nearness of the weapon the creature instead lunged for it with its head, turning it so that its mouth was parallel to the blade's edge. Biting into the weapon its teeth found a grip, and Amadeus was thrown back in surprise as the axe was ripped from his hand, and by the fact that the venom in the creature's fangs seemed to be dissolving the metal of the weapon's construction. Something that should have been impossible.

Expecting an attack Amadeus lowered into a fighting stance ready to deflect the weapon when the creature tossed it at him, but he was stunned into silence when instead of attacking him the thing spit the blade out at its own severed hand, causing the sickening sound of crushing bone and liquefying flesh to echo over the dump. Oddly Amadeus could swear he heard a metallic crunch as well, but he couldn't see from where until a new sound came over the area, this one a high pitched whine he recognized without any hesitation, as he had a similar device built into one of his teeth.

Leaping back again Amadeus watched from twelve meters away as the creature's body began to shine with an inner radiance hat nearly blinded him as he stared into it. Slowly points of light blossomed under the lizard like scales, moving about inside the creature towards a single shining dot inside the things head. With each droplet of light that dot grew stronger and stronger until at last Amadeus could no longer stand to look at it and was forced to turn away as the light and whining sound reached their crescendo together.

When at last the sound had died down Amadeus looked back to see the last vestiges of the plasma reaction fading. Where the monster, derelict, and various bits of junk had stood their was now a crater that was about six meters wide and almost that deep. Amadeus swore as he walked up and inspected the crater, both because his only lead on how he'd get back home had just committed suicide, and because the blast radius had included his axe, meaning that when he got back he'd have to make a whole new one, which meant at least three weeks of hard work for him.

"Damn it all. You know Jasmine made that for me, you scaly jerk. How am I supposed to tell her I got her gift vaporized on some unknown planet?" he complained at the crater, before kicking a bit of debris into it in frustration. With that act done Amadeus decided not to dwell on his anger, and instead focus his mind on how to get home, which would require help from his brother, who was still probably still a bit scrambled by their arrival on this new world. Thinking about how he'd explain the loss of her gift to Jasmine, Amadeus started back towards the place where his belt lay when he heard the sound of other voices just around the corner.

"Where is he?" demanded one, which sounded an awfully lot like the voice of the lizard thing when he'd been speaking into the small radio transmitter.

"Why are you asking me, genetic filth. He's your brother not mine," responded another, this one of an entirely different accent, though still speaking English. Staring towards the pile between him and the two voice Amadeus realized he would have to get past them to get at his belt, Zee, and his weapon, not a prospect he delighted in as he didn't think he could take one of the lizards unarmed, let alone one of them and something else.

Looking around he was surprised to find that the crater left by the first lizard had opened a hole in the rear fence of the junkyard, providing him with a view of the forest beyond. Turning back towards the direction of his things he realized that once again he was faced with a choice of paths. He could attempt to face the two who were speaking and get to his belt, or he could run into the woods and wait for Zee to come to him, as the CAP was sure to activate and come after him when he'd sorted himself out. Staring up into the fast darkening sky above Amadeus as last decided to...
13112.title: Interrogation

choices: went back to the stream and continued farther up it.
131121.content:
"You better stay alive Zee," said Amadeus at the pile of debris between him and the CAP before turning towards the gap in the nearby fence and taking off into the twilight. Overhead the primary star was beginning to descended towards the horizon, and because of the darkness that was fast over taking the opposite side of the sky Amadeus assumed that the system had only a single sun, unlike his current home of Dedros which was a binary system with a bright primary and a smaller secondary that caused the planet to have only an cycle or two of darkness before one or the other rose into the sky.

Thinking of the home from which he'd been ripped Amadeus was over taken by an urge to go back and bust the heads of the two who had been speaking earlier, as he was quite certain now that his presence on the planet was due in part to the lizard humanoid who had attacked him, and he was just as certain that whomever the two voices belonged to had at least some relation to the lizard thing. After all one of them had talked about the fact that someone who was missing was the other's brother.

He fought the urge though, as he was still not sure if he could take one of the lizards unarmed. Oh he was confident he could kill one if he had to. Probably more than one, but his goal was not to terminate the lizard things, but rather to capture one, and force it to tell him where he was, why he was there, and most importantly how he would get his butt back home so he could finish the Game with Jasmine, probably getting killed by the Midgard Dragon again.

With the information he required out of reach Amadeus had to fall back on what the Combine military advised in situations like his. Sit tight, keep yourself alive, and wait for pick up. Though nebulous in nature those orders had kept him going on at least three occasions that resembled his current one, though in all three instances he'd never had anyone actively hunting him. Usually he was just lost on some planet with no way off. Those times he'd just laid low and waited for help to come. This time though he had a feeling help wasn't coming, and he would have to try and figure everything out on his own.

Still sitting and waiting for Zee to pull his circuits together sounded like a good idea for the moment. Even if those two back in the junkyard did find the belt it was doubtful they would be able to identify the CAP, and even if they were able to ID the device there was no way they could hurt it. CAPs came equipped with self-defense programs to protect the storage module even if the CAP themselves were for some reason rendered helpless.

Running through the hole in the fence Amadeus ran as fast as he could in the climbing boots he was wearing into the woods, which proved harder to navigate because of his footwear. Every step he took seemed to get the spiked toes caught in a root or branch, but with a single-mindedness that only a true soldier could demonstrate he continued running, ripping the woods apart as he did so. He was well aware that he was leaving an obvious trail to follow, but he had hope that maybe the two at the dump would not take notice of his escape when they learned of the death of their fellow lizard thing.

Even if they didn't, Amadeus was still making pretty good time as he made his way through the foliage, and he was sure that the air had a hint of water in it. Once he was able to find a river or stream he could follow it for a ways, throwing off any would be pursuers and buying himself all the time Zee would need to repair himself and then come and get him. Once they were together again Amadeus was confident that he and Zee could figure out what the hazmat was going on and then get themselves back to where they belonged.

Making his way quickly through the branches and leaves Amadeus' first sight of the river was just as he broke through a curtain of vegetation and then fell off the bank into the cold water. Landing with a hard splash Amadeus panicked for a moment as the water rose over his head and he felt the weight of his cloak and helmet drag him to the river bed, with the strong current trying to rip both items off his body. His struggles tore at the water, sending it flying in all directions, though it was eerily quiet as Amadeus did not once scream out for help for fear that he might be being followed.

Feeling stupider than he had in most of his twenty Combine Standard Years of life Amadeus realized with a start that he was scraping the bottom of the ‘river' with his hands while thrashing. Stopping his thrashing about Amadeus put his hands on the soft mud underneath the water and hauled himself to his feet, discovering that the stream he was standing in was quite deep for its size, having only about three feet width, but coming up to his knees when he stood in it.

"Okay, when I tell Zee about this later, I am so leaving this part out," he told himself, beginning his march up stream. His boots, which had proved a hindrance in the woods, were even worse in the water, as it felt like he had to tug them loose from the mud with each step. His pace slowed to less than a snail's crawl Amadeus had time to listen to the woods around him, and was startled to realize that he had yet to hear a single animal sound, although that might not be odd. Several worlds were silent to him because the native lifeforms used alternate forms of communication or used sounds who's pitches were too high or low for him to hear.

Still even on those worlds forested areas had at least some indication of life, yet stretching his senses to the their utmost he could feel nothing anywhere nearby, either following him or just going about their daily business. Disturbed by the lack of activity Amadeus searched the banks on either side for signs of some passage, but found only a few trails that led into the woods, most seeming to have been abandoned for at least weeks, which usually meant there was something wrong with the local area that caused natives to avoid it. Possibly something to do with the lizards, if they weren't the locals themselves, which, though he didn't have any evidence of it, he doubted.

Something about the one he'd fought in the junkyard had seemed out of place. After all the majority of the vehicle derelicts had been designed for something about Amadeus' size, roughly one to two and half meters, while the lizard thing had been nearly three in height, with the tail adding at least another meter if not more to it's overall length. Such a thing would have never found transports of that nature comfortable, indicating that they were not among the most numerous species on the planet. Besides, if they were the dominate race of the planet than they should have been able to track him much more easily than they seemed to, as he'd only encountered three in the junkyard, two of which might have had no relation to his assailant.
