Finding a bank of the stream that was only slightly difficult to climb, being neither the steep bank he'd found when first coming upon the stream, nor the banks that sloped into the river creating a way to just walk out, Amadeus made his way out of the river, grabbing a branch for a hand hold and ripping it off as he ascended the slope. Walking into the woods he found a trail and made sure to leave a set of footprints on it that walked off into the woods more wild section before stepping backwards exactly in his own footprints and returning to the water to continue on.

Now he could find a place a little farther upstream to get off at and try to find a clearing where he could make camp as any followers were likely to see the easily visible signs of his leaving the river and make their way into the woods, traveling downstream and away from where it was Amadeus would eventually get off. Hist footsteps coming easier thanks to the knowledge that he had done all he could to protect himself Amadeus was surprised when he reached an area of the river where the water shallowed out to be less than an inch deep.

Deciding that this might be a good place Amadeus made his way into the woods, and was again surprised when his path brought him almost instantly to a clearing that was a good twenty feet wide. It seemed like the perfect place to bunker down for the coming nighttime. Maybe a little too perfect really. Looking around Amadeus half expected to find some kind of duckblind setup, but everywhere around there seemed to be only trees and woods. Amadeus, after a moment or two of consideration...
131121.title: He who fights and runs away...

choices: deer, not wearing clothes, but with an intelligence in it's gaze
1311212.content:
Walking to the edge of the clearing Amadeus found the branches of the local trees to be just about the right length for use in building a camp site that would be adequate for at least a few days. Knowing that ripping the branches off living wood might be considered bad taste on this world as it was on others Amadeus made a quick search of the ground, finding deadwood almost everywhere he looked, most of it in at least useable condition.

Making his way into the brush Amadeus began to pick up random sticks, pulling at their sides and seeing if they snapped or broke. Any branch that did instantly found itself tossed back towards the clearing, for use as fire wood, while those that stood up to his assault were placed under one arm, for use either as more kindling or for more important roles which he would determine when he had found as much as he could.

Considering himself to be either quite lucky Amadeus walked back into the clearing with a bundle of sticks under his arm, dumping them into roughly the center of the open area. Looking down at his prizes he was confident that he could survive on the planet, for at least one or two nights, though if he found a good source of food he knew that he would be able to live here indefinitely, though he still hoped that Zee or someone would come and take him away.

Pulling at the cloak on his back he lightly set the fur on the ground beside the sticks and began to lay each pieces of wood beside the garment, measuring with his eyes to see if any of the sticks would do as poles for a lean-to. Finding two such pieces of wood in the stack he set them on the ground and rotated them in such a manner as to cause them to drill into the dirt, until at last about 15 cm of their ends were buried in the ground.

Nodding at he work Amadeus then grabbed the cloak off the ground and set two of its corners on the poles and tugged, making sure the lean-to would be able to hold up if the wind began pulling at the cloak. He was gratified to find that the sticks he'd chosen did indeed have the necessary strength to service his needs, and pulling at the free end of the cloak again he buried it under several centimeters of dirt to brace it, forcing the cloak to stretch out ward forming a basic three sided shelter.

Moving around the small hut he'd made in only a few minutes Amadeus felt confident that it would suit his needs as a temporary dwelling place, as, if Zee or no one showed up in the night, he planned on moving on, and hopefully finding out a bit more about his new planet. Making one last circuit around the temporary dwelling Amadeus nodded again, satisfied with his handiwork, and hoping that the wind didn't pick up too much in the night, as if it did that usually indicated rain in a nitrogen rich atmosphere, which he believed this planet's to be.

With the dwelling set up Amadeus turned to more important matters, namely provisions. Since his belt had contained his pouch Amadeus had no tools or items from his own civilization. His gun had been the only truly useful thing on the belt besides Zee, but Amadeus still would have liked to have the pouch, in which he knew were a few nutrient cubes, that, though they tasted terrible, would have filled his stomach for the night at least.

Not one to dwell on such wishful thinking, no matter how much he wanted to, Amadeus set about constructing a campfire area, placing a few of the stronger sticks into positions similar to those of his lean-to poles, burying their ends in the ground so that they stood straight up. With that done he then pulled at their ends, ripping the sticks in half through the sheer strength of his arms, creating makeshift prongs that would be able to hold up a third stick.

The next part came to be a bit more difficult as Amadeus pulled off his lupine shaped helm and then had to find a stick that would fit into the jaw hole that held the faceplate to the rest of the head covering, yet was strong enough to support the metal helm as it hung between the two sticks he'd just buried. Luckily for Amadeus one of the sticks he'd picked up proved perfect for the task, and after leaving it up for a minute he felt it would suit his purposes.

Taking the helm with the stick stuck through it, Amadeus marched back to the river, and using the helm as a pot he got as much water as he could in it before making his way back to camp. As he looked down at the large amount of water in the bottom of his pot, Amadeus thought of all the times Corrin and Vivian, his old squadmates, had commented on his large head, compared to their's. Now though that big head was coming in handy as it made the helm into a decent sized pot.

Laughing at the memory of his friends, whom he hadn't seen in at least a year, Amadeus set the full pot/helm atop the two stick that would hold it over the fire. He waited for three minutes this time as he watched the pot sway in the light breeze, fearing with every swing that he would hear the shuddering sound of a crack as the stick broke apart under the combined weight of the helm and the water, but despite the thinness of the branch it held, and Amadeus smiled as he moved some of the extra wood he'd gathered under it.

With the fire setup complete Amadeus was again forced to venture into the woods to find stones and dry brush. The stones to use as both an ignition source, and to ring the fire to prevent it from spreading, and the dry brush to use to help the initial spark take hold. Again the abandoned nature of his surroundings worked to his favor, as both items were readily at hand, though he would have liked the stones to be a little bigger.

Still, beggars had no right to be choosers, and he made due with those stones he located along the river bank, carefully placing each one next to the other until they formed a complete circle around the edge of where he intended to spark his fire. With that done Amadeus then threw the bits of dry brush into the small pile of sticks, making it look like a tree had suddenly fallen in on itself and then he'd set his makeshift pot over it.

Clapping his hands together to get off the excess wood chips and dirt Amadeus then set about the harder work of ripping the grass out of the area around his fire, tossing any good looking handfuls into the place where the flames would blaze, while throwing most outward towards the edges of the clearing. When he was done he got to his feet and again clapped his hands against each other, finding the half meter of dirt around his circle of stones to be a testament to his survival skill.

Sighing, not from exhaustion, but from the sheer amount of work he knew lay ahead, Amadeus picked up the two roughest rocks he'd found by the river. Taking them back towards the flowing water he tested their edges against each other, making sure that they would suit the purpose to which he intended on putting them. He was rewarded for his effort with a slight flash of sparks as the two stones rubbed against each other.

Smiling to himself, and looking up at the sky, Amadeus was startled to find the sky was already a deep purple hue, with the sun vanished some time ago over the horizon. Amadeus stared up into the velvet sky, seeing the first hint of starlight he'd seen in a long time. Oddly he thought he recognized some of the star patterns in the sky overhead, but he couldn't place any of them. It seemed to him that he'd looked up at the stars many times, but that should be impossible, as Dedros was the first planet he'd ever lived on by choice, and most of the ones he'd ended up by on accident or because of orders had been V-class, meaning their atmosphere prevent one from seeing the stars.

Shaking off the feeling of familiarity, he wandered back into his camp and stood in front of his fire pit. Clicking the two stones together as hard as he could solicited sparks from them, ones which fell on the dry grass and brush, causing light smoke to begin to rise. Putting aside the rocks Amadeus stared into the brush, trying to will the fire to come out. When that failed he did the next best thing and began blowing on the brush, causing the smoke to rise faster and harder before it suddenly burst into a bright inferno before him.

With the fire burning steadily Amadeus leaned back against a nearby tree and stared into its blaze. He lost himself for a time in the dance of light and smoke which he knew had captivated the hearts of many humans before him. Some would lose themselves in the light for hours at time, finding their chaotic fury calming. For him though their chaos was not calm. In the crackle of the fire he heard the shots fired from weapons he held, and the hiss of the air reminded him of screams as people fell.

When in the Games, or being a soldier he had to steel himself against the images, just to keep on going, but at times like these he couldn't do that. The Warrior in him would not come out to protect the Child from the things they had done. Instead the Child was laid low, forced to endure the horrors it had seen others commit before it, and worse still those horrors done by its own hands, though at the time those hands had belonged to another, or so it had seemed.

It took Amadeus a moment to feel the wetness in his right palm, and he knew that he'd again started squeezing that hand. At first he thought he might had cut it open with his fingernails again, but looking down he saw that he'd been digging that hand into the dirt without knowing it, and had found a small tuber buried just below the surface, and he'd squeezed some of the juice out of it. Pulling his hand close to his face Amadeus sucked off a bit of the juice and found that it tasted bitter, though he noted that just after it had passed down his throat he felt a little weary. Probably it had a sedating effect on him, but light enough that he would be able to eat it.

Digging on purpose this time Amadeus unearthed a dozen or so of the small green root-like things, and then walked up to his fire, over which the pot was already beginning to boil. Wiping the dirt off as best he could Amadeus dumped a small handful of the tubers into his water, and watched as the juice began to flow out of them, mixing in the bubbling water into something that resembled a witch's brew, though he hoped it tasted better than tongue of frog and eye of newt.

He gave the concoction another few minutes to boil as he made his way over the camp, choosing at last one of the longer, yet thinner sticks to serve as a poker for his fire. Walking over to the stream and dipping it in before making his way back to the fire, which had grown low as he'd stared into it earlier. A quick jab with the damp would, though, caused the fire to redouble its blaze, and few extra sticks were added to the mound of kindling to keep it going for a while longer.

Feeling satisfied that he'd given it enough time Amadeus gripped the ends of the stick which held his helm/pot and carried it to the stream, lowering it into it so that the bottom touched it. He heard the satisfying sound as the water under the pot flash boiled, becoming a small cloud of steam which quickly vanished in the slightly chill night air. Holding it for a few extra moment Amadeus could actually feel as the helm came down to a temperature he could hold in his hand without burning it.

At last done with that Amadeus walked back into the camp, and sat under the lean-to which stared straight into his fire. Picking up the helm in his palm he lightly tilted it, taking a testing sip of his brew. Surprisingly the taste of the liquid was not nearly as bitter as the raw tuber juice had been, and in fact it had an almost sweet after taste that he would have enjoyed under different circumstances, though the current situation made enjoying it a bit difficult.

With the tasting of the liquid out of the way Amadeus decided to see what the plants themselves tasted like, and reached his hand into the mixture, pulling out one of the tubers that shined in the firelight. Biting off one end he was again struck by a bitter taste, and wondered for a moment what was in the water that would so alter the flavor of the juice, but his stomach didn't really care. According to it any food at the moment was good food, no matter the taste, and after a few more mouthfuls Amadeus found he was in complete agreement.

It didn't take Amadeus long to eat his simple meal, throwing away the bits of plant which he'd found to be inedible, as well as washing out the helm in river water before setting it over the fire again to dry. Finding nothing more to take his mind off the situation he was in Amadeus decided that sleep was his next priority, and that if Zee, who he knew had by know corrected whatever problem he'd had, had not yet contacted him by morning, he would go searching for the CAP as well as for a way off the planet.

Laying under his lean-to Amadeus could see only a ragged edge of the stars that were nearly invisible in the firelight, but just at the side of his eyes he caught a glimpse of something he recognized right away, mostly because he'd seen it a dozen times in Games he'd played with Jasmine. There, sitting in the sky as if it belonged, was a huge silver sphere, the planetary satellite, but it had to be huge compared to the planet if it was visible so easily, and only one planet he knew had one that big compared to itself.

The legendary homeworld, a world he himself had tried to prove mythological at least a dozen times during his sessions with the commanders of the Third Fleet, who insisted on wasting resource searching for it. Not fully able to process what his sleep deprived mind was telling him Amadeus began to drift away from the impossible scene before his eyes into the darkness of his dreams. Oddly as he did so his eyes did not close, but remained wide open, just unfocused as his mind entered its unconscious phase.

There he remained for many hours, without any thoughts of huge satellites or mythical homeworlds, or even of Zee and his own lost status. Instead his dreams were filled with images of fire-breathing monsters, both those of the real and Game variety. Neither type were doing pleasant things to him in those dreams, but he endured their flames, both because he felt he deserved their hot kiss, and because he knew of no way to fight them.

The dreams ended suddenly when the sound of a snapping twig brought Amadeus back to reality, bolting from his slumber to fully awake in less than a second, a result of his training, of which the eye open sleep was a side effect. Looking around Amadeus was assaulted by the sound of something crashing through the woods nearby. Poking the dim flame into brightness he looked towards the source of the noise, and was startled when a new form burst into his clearing, one of a...
1311212.title: A night in the woods

13112121.content:
The deer and Amadeus stared at each other across the clearing. In the eyes of the creature Amadeus could see the focus of a mind that knew the concept of I, and thus was sentient, though the thing wore no clothes and said not a word to him, the surest signs of intelligence. Silently the two figures stood as they studied each other in the failing light of Amadeus' campfire, which must have been burning for many hours and now stood in the spectral place between life and death, for a fire anyway.

"I would run if I were you," said the deer at last in English, prompting Amadeus to stand up straighter and set his foot on the end of his wooden poker, bringing it to hand. Before he could inquire as to why the deer felt flight was necessary, or why it spoke English, the creature took off across the clearing to crash through the brush on the other side and begin bounding off into the woods again towards an unknown destination. Or more likely away from some unknown assailant.

Walking calmly over to his campfire Amadeus drove the end of his stick into the ember's glow, causing a small spark of life to reveal itself to him. Reaching down, but never getting off his feet, Amadeus picked up one of the sticks he had kept as extra fuel and tossed it along with a handful of dry grass into the small tongue of flame, which lapped up the wood and plants with a hunger that caused it to crackle as it burned brightly against the darkened woods.

Stretching his senses to their utmost again Amadeus could hear the sounds of the deer's hooves as it made its way through the woods. Elsewhere he now sensed the movement of other beings. Two seemed smaller, and lighter than their companions, at least one of which had a step like a lummox or an elephant. The other, though lighter on its feet than the lummox, still made more noise as it moved through the woods, obviously bigger as he could hear more branches break with its passing.

As he listened the large sounding creature made its way in an almost straight path towards him, and Amadeus realized that the deer must have been fleeing the creature. Why it would be hunted in such a primitive fashion when it was clearly a sentient Amadeus did not know, but he didn't have time to care that much either as the creature crashed through the small barrier of shrubs that surrounded the clearing, landing right inside his shadow as it leapt into sight, crouching on all fours and growling like a beast.

The creature had claws obviously made for ripping into flesh, as even in the low light of his fire Amadeus could see the glint off the sharp, long nails. The things eyes and face were a reminder of a race he'd encountered called the Veraxan, though it was obvious by the stance the creature took in battle it had never ever heard of that species, for if it had it would have assumed a much more defensive stance, for which the Veraxan were famous, called the Vera Cone, which forced all hand to hand combatants to fight the Veraxan head on.

Oddly, despite the look of the claws and even the shape of the thing's mouth Amadeus could tell that its teeth were as flat as a cows, designed for grinding rather than ripping, and would have only limited use in any combat that the creature partook in. Studying it still farther Amadeus noted the drawn out look it had when standing on all fours as it did now, a look like a spring that had been coiled and was ready to pop forward at any time. A stance which would have been useful against a non-sentient opponent, but against Amadeus, who had fought things that the creature could not even conceive of, the stance was thing to laugh at, though he did not do so just then.

As he predicted, the creature leapt forward, coming straight on like a wild animal rather than thinking through the attack like a true warrior. Depressed at the lack of challenge Amadeus merely spun out of the way of the leaping attack, bring the stick in close like a fencing blade and then slashing it down as the form of the lupine creature jetted by him, slamming the wooden weapon into the thing's left leg and soliciting a pain filled yelp from it.

The creature landed hard, rolling across the clearing after trying to come down on the injured limb. Amadeus, now spinning his weapon before him like a shield, ran after the creature, and as it once again tried to get to its feet, still growling and probably still planning on doing battle, Amadeus whacked it across the temple with the stick, causing it to fly a few feet across the clearing before sliding to a stop almost right next to his campfire, and revealing two new facts about the creature.

The first, and probably something he should have noticed before, was that the creature was wearing clothes. Specifically it appeared to be wearing a jacket, which indicated not only sentience, but that it was part of a civilization. The other thing was that the jacket had writing on it. Writing in the same ancient language that the lizard and deer had been speaking. One word in particular caught his attention as it was an indicator of the creature's age. The word school.

"Oh slag. I just knocked out a kid. I am in so much trouble," said Amadeus gripping the back of his head in frustration as he looked over at the still form of the lupine child. Even though he was about the same size as the creature Amadeus' close inspection of the feature's told him that the thing was indeed still a child, as the head didn't look quite the right size for the body, being just a bit too big, a good indication of the age of carbon based lifeforms.

Considering his situation Amadeus actively thought about chasing after the deer and maybe hiding out with it. After all the creature and its friends were probably not going to be too happy with him when it was revealed that Amadeus had injured one of them. Flight, as the deer had suggested, seemed like a good option. But could Amadeus really leave the thing unconscious in the middle of clearing, in a forest that could contain dozens of species that might well make a meal out of him while he was helpless?
13112121.title: Meeting the locals

choices: Tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth
131121212.content:
"Okay then kid, guess I get to be you're nursemaid, at least until you wake up or one of your friends comes and tries to bite my face off," said Amadeus to the slumbering form of the lupine child. Well slumbering was probably not the right word as the creature continued to paw at the ground, as if Amadeus had caused some damage to the poor thing's mind when he'd struck it. Unwilling to entertain thoughts of that bleak nature Amadeus went to the creature's side, and began to take stock of it.

Having already observed the jacket that had the word school on it, which indicated the jackets owner was in some form of educational system, Amadeus took stock of other clothes, noting that outside the jacket the youth wore an odd fur cloak, not unlike his own, but this one made of hair from another animal. The horns atop the head and fluffy white nature of the hair indicated to Amadeus an animal that was called a sheep, bringing to mind an old axiom about a wolf in sheep's clothing.

Taking off the cloak Amadeus placed it over the lean-to constructed from his own and set about checking the creature's body, both to see if it had sustained injury and to confirm its gender. A quick glance told Amadeus he was dealing with a male, which indicated to him that the society on the planet would probably have matriarchal overtones, as the stronger genders were usually those that stayed at home, rather than going out and hunting. Though many had tried to dissuade Amadeus of that fact, his own research had proven it true in ninety-seven out of one-hundred cases, which was proof enough to him.

The next thing he checked was the creature's... no the boy's leg, making sure it was still whole, if bruised. A few pokes gained him pain filled whines from the still unconscious thing. He noted, however, that he felt only whole bone, which at least meant that he hadn't broken anything in his assault, a good thing considering it was likely Amadeus would be helping the creature back to wherever it came from and he didn't really feel like dragging it there.

Amadeus then tried to look for other injuries, but found his search complicated by the small mat of fur that obscured the boy's skin. Not used to having to look through a screen of fur for injuries Amadeus at last gave up his search, hoping that the creature's only wounds were those two bumps that he himself had inflicted upon it. If so then all he'd have to deal with when the creature awoke was a headache and really sore leg, both things he could help with.

Putting all the clothes back on the boy Amadeus decided to leave the cloak off, not knowing how the creature had kept it on while running through the woods, the cloak having no ties or clips which would bind it to either the creature or his garments. Leaving the sheep cloak hanging on his lean-to Amadeus placed the boy as gently as he could before the fire, hoping the warmth would in some way ease the pain which the boy was likely to waken in.

Seeing that he was comfortable Amadeus then set about the task of digging in the dirt at the edge of the clearing again, searching for more of the tubers he had discovered by accident. The juice from the tubers, when he'd ingested it raw, had a sedating effect on him, and seeing that he was able to survive on the planet's surface unaided, as was the boy, Amadeus had a hope that the chemical would have a similar effect on him. It usually worked that way, as most lifeforms throughout the cosmos followed some basic pattern, so that chemicals would effect them in similar ways, though not always the exact same ones.

He prayed silently that the tuber juice wasn't some form of narcotic for the young boy, otherwise he might well cause the creature to gain a drug habit, something frowned upon by most cultures, being considered a weakness. Having succumb to such pleasures only twice in his life Amadeus knew the thrall they held, and he did not truly wish to give such a crutch to the boy, but the tubers might at least ease the pain he would feel upon waking, and Amadeus needed him focused on something other than that pain, which he had caused.

Gathering as many of the tubers as he could Amadeus walked back over to the fire where the wolf boy still lay in the land of dreams. Nudging the creature with his fire poker solicited a small whimper and another bout of scampering in the air with his legs and arms, but nothing further. Thinking that maybe he'd hit the boy harder than he'd though Amadeus walked around him and grabbed the helm which lay near the fire, having been placed there to dry after his meal earlier.

Placing the helm between his legs, Amadeus began to squeeze the tubers in his fists, causing small streams of liquid to pour through his clenched fingers into the makeshift bowl. He repeated the process until he at last ran out of the green root-like things, and was disappointed to find that he had only half filled the helm. Looking around he at first thought that he might dig up some more, but decided that he'd make due with what he'd already gotten, as it was at this moment that the creature at last began to stir out of his sleep.

Groaning in pain, and moving his hand to grip his head to keep it from moving too much the creature rose to his knees and took stock of the local surroundings. Amadeus was quite surprised by the action considering the reckless abandon with which the creature had acted when breaking into the clearing before. Now, with the bloodlust drained from him by a few minutes of pain induced sleep, the boy was in control of himself again. Walking forward Amadeus stepped in front of the young one and held out the helm to him.

"Here. I think this will help the pain," he offered, admitting to the creature that he didn't know if it really would help or not, but the boy didn't seem to care, grabbing the helm and draining it in a few short gulps. Tossing the metal aside the boy faced Amadeus with fire in his eyes, though he swayed in the light breeze, meaning he was in no real condition to do battle, but that he was willing to try all the same.

"Are you okay?" asked Amadeus, wondering if the spoken language of the creature was the same as the deer and the lizard, and the same as the words written on his jacket. It was always possible that the boy spoke a different tongue than those around him, which would complicate matters for a few seconds, though Amadeus was still wearing his transcollar, which meant with a flick of a switch he could understand any language as long as it was based in a recognized thought pattern.

"Can you understand me?" asked Amadeus, this time tapping that side of his head near his ear to accentuate the words. The boy repeated the gesture, not knowing why his captor chose to make it, but hoping that if he kept it talking long enough his friends would show up.

"No and yes," said the boy and last.

"So you're not okay? What hurts?" asked Amadeus, hoping that he could keep the boy talking. He still needed information about where he was, the lizard having proved uncooperative in that area, choosing self-destruction over giving Amadeus any clue as to where he was, or why he'd been brought here.

"Everything. My head is throbbing, and my leg feels like you shattered the bone," responded the boy, gripping that leg and trying to stand for a moment, but failing miserably and falling back to the dirt with another pain filled yelp.

"Don't try to stand. Your legs not broken, but I did hit it pretty hard I'm afraid," said Amadeus, hoping that admitting he had caused the hurt would at least get the boy to not think of him as an uncaring enemy.

"Well, that's good news at least. Why are you out here anyway? This is the hunting ground for our school. No ones supposed to be here but players, judges, and prey," said the boy, sitting upright again as he pushed himself off the ground.

"A hunting ground? That explains the seldom used trails. And to answer your question I'm not from around here, so I had no idea what this place was. I just needed some place to set up camp tonight and came upon this clearing. When you attacked me I defended myself, and you're quite lucky I didn't kill you," said Amadeus, not trying to impress the boy that he'd been spared, but instead stating a simple fact.

"I can see you aren't from around here. I've never smelled anything like you before, and I've never seen anyone do with a stick what you did," admitted the boy, staring at the human with unshielded respect at the power he'd seen him display in taking him down.

"It's just something I've picked up in my travels, lupine child. I can teach it to you if you want, but first how about telling me where I am," offered Amadeus. The wolf boy mulled over the offer and the request for a few moments before at last staring into the man's eyes once more.

"You go first. I'll tell you who I am and where we are, but before that I want to know where you're from and who you are," countered the boy at last, and Amadeus knew he had to respond. He could of course lie and claim to be a native of the planet from far away, as he wasn't sure that the wolf boy might be in league with the lizard thing that had attacked him. Of course if his lie was discovered it wouldn't help his matters any, especially if it turned out the wolf boy was an enemy of the lizard thing.
131121212.title: Helping the injured pup

choices: a red lupine creature with large ears
a small pink bunny with shades, that was holding a drum
1311212121.content:
"Okay, if that's the way you want it. My name is Amadeus Orman, I'm a homo sapien. My homeworld, well I don't have one. I was born in a hyperspace shunt city that existed between the worlds of Armanos and Verax. At the current time my place of residence is in an unnamed city on the southern landmass of the planet Dedros in the Halika system of the Sarnok galaxy. The sector is Foxtrot Hotel India, or FHI," he said, giving as much information as he could about himself, hoping that something he said might get a reaction out of the child, but unfortunately the lupine boy sat facing him, and did not react as if the names sparked any memories within him.

"You mean, you're from another planet?" asked the kid in disbelief, and forced Amadeus to consider the possibility that he was on a prim world, something he'd guessed at by the types of vehicles in the junkyard, but had attempted to ignore. Now faced with the child's stare of wonder Amadeus couldn't lie to himself, and was forced to admit that getting a ride home wasn't going to be possible. At least not until he understood what brought him to this place.

"Yes, I'm from another planet. Now that that's established, what planet is this, and do you have any form of interstellar travel?" he asked, hoping that maybe he was wrong, and that this child was just less traveled, and simply had never met someone from another world, despite a culture that could travel the stars.

"Well, the planet we're on now is called Earth, but as to interstellar travel...well the farthest we've been is the moon. Are you really from another world?" asked the wolf boy again, staring at Amadeus with a look that asked plainly if he was lying. Sighing Amadeus shook his head and stared into the fire, silently bemoaning the loss of his belt, the contents of which would have proven his claim with ease, either through his gun, or better yet Zee.

"Listen, you can believe me or not, that's you're choice, as I lost the stuff I have that could prove my origin without a doubt. Still, doesn't my appearance look odd enough to suggest an extraterrestrial birth?" he asked, waving his hand over his own body and standing fully in the light of the fire so that the wolf boy got a clear view of him. For many long moments Amadeus stood nervously as he was studied, though he realized quickly that it was his scent that was under scrutiny more so than his appearance, which suggested many things about the wolf boy and the culture from which he came.

"You do smell odd, but I could swear I've smelled something similar," commented the wolf boy, more to himself than to Amadeus, but Amadeus leaped up as if the lupine child had been yelling at him, facing him across the fire with blazing light shining in his eyes. Leaping over the flames he looked down at the wolf boy and grabbed his forearm, not roughly, but enough to get the child's attention.

"Where did you smell something like me? It could be my people are hiding somewhere on this world, observing you. Please, try and remember, maybe they were called something else. My people are also known as humans, though I'd be surprised if they..." Amadeus' voice trailed off as he stared into the wolf boy's eyes, because in those eyes he saw a spark of recognition at the word ‘human', something that truly startled him as few in his own government would dare to call themselves human, most being half-breeds or even more.

"Humans then. So where is it you remember humans from?" demanded Amadeus, not needing the wolf boy to answer his previous question in words.

"Well, I've never met one before, not while they were human anyway, but according to Kevin's sister, Danielle, she used to be a human," he responded, and Amadeus was again forced to stare at the boy, before releasing the wolf boy's arm, and turning away in defeat. He had no idea what the child was talking about, though from his tone Amadeus doubted seriously that he would find anyone from the Combine on this world. He did have some hope that maybe this Danielle was from the Unified Worlds Alliance or the Grand Imperium, but that hope was faint at best as someone from either of those governments were as likely to kill him as help him.

"I'm sorry if I scared you, but I'd really like to go home, and any human you've met could be my ticket back," he apologized to the child as he walked back across the fire.

"However you've only answered one of my questions to you, while I answered both of your's," he said, and the wolf boy stared at him, not comprehending what he was saying.

"You're name. I gave you my name and home, but you only told me where I am, not who you are," he said.

"Oh, that. My name is Bruno. It is a pleasure to meet you Amadeus," said the wolf boy, which caused Amadeus to snick slightly, soliciting a hurt look from Bruno.

"It would probably be a greater pleasure if we hadn't tried to kill each other at first sight. Still I've formed friendships under worse circumstances," said Amadeus, getting up from where he sat and walking over to his lean-to, tossing Bruno's cloak to him.

"How about we go find your friends, or maybe a real medic to help with that leg of your's?" offered Amadeus as he stepped up to the fire and threw a few hand fulls of dirt on it, casting the clearing into darkness. His eyes slowly adjusted to the dim light that filtered out of the skies, watching as the silhouette of Bruno struggled into the sheep...or rather ram skin, and then stood on his good leg. Grabbing his poker to use as both walking stick and weapon if need be Amadeus walked up beside Bruno and offered the lupine child a shoulder.

"So where are we going?" asked Amadeus pointing back towards the direction where he seemed to remember the wolf boy coming. Bruno shook his head at the suggested direction and pointed a few degrees farther to the left. Without speaking the two set off in the direction Bruno had indicated. It soon became apparent to both that they would not have much time for conversing on the walk to wherever Bruno was taking them as their attention had to be focused on the forest floor, which acted almost like it was alive, with roots and branches constantly pulling at the two as they made their way farther away from the clearing.

Oddly Amadeus did not feel remorse at leaving either helm or cloak behind. Having shared his origin with Bruno he did not feel it would be necessary to hide who he was to others. In fact the more he thought about it the more believed that announcing who he was might draw the lizard thing's friends to him, something he desired as they were his only clue as to how he got where he was, and thus his only clue on how to get home.

So focused was he on his internal thoughts that Amadeus almost ran into the thing which crossed their path. It emerged from the brush, low to the ground and silent as it moved over the forest floor, it feet barely making any noise at all. Drawing his stick in closer he prepared to defend himself against the unknown being which then made its way into a small shaft of light that poured down through the branches and was revealed to be...
1311212121.title: Getting to know each other

13112121212.content:
The rabbit didn't react to the two figures it nearly hit on its way through the forest, and the reason for this became evident when one noticed the battery on the things back, and the wheels upon which it was
mounted. For whatever reason someone appeared to have created a small foot tall rabbit mechanoid that was making its way through the forest, banging on a drum, and after a moment it stopped, spun one of its sticks in the air and moved in a circle for a second before moving on, running into a glowing circle of blue that Amadeus knew hadn't been there a moment ago, and vanishing in a flash of light.

"Is that a usual example of this planet's fauna?" asked Amadeus of Bruno, pointing at the spot where the rabbit bot had disappeared.

"No, I've never seen anything like it before," commented Bruno, looking as astounded as Amadeus by the creature's sudden appearance and disappearance. For a moment he looked like he was going to continue, but then he stopped as Amadeus started snapping his fingers and getting a thoughtful expression on his face.

"What?" asked Bruno, wondering what the human could be thinking about.

"I don't know. It just feels like I've seen that bunny somewhe-Wait, I've got it. If I'm right then he should be here in 5-4-3-2-1" he said, pointing towards the spot where the rabbit came from. When the count reached zero everything in the woods seemed to grow still, and Bruno looked on in anticipation, but after several seconds nothing happened, and he looked back over at Amadeus, about to say something, when a new crashing sound caught his attention and he looked over to find a new form come stumbling out of the woods behind the rabbit.

"Always slow," said Amadeus softly as he looked over at the figure. The man, for indeed it was a human, wore a suit not unlike Amadeus' own, except his was white all over rather than gray, and at the shoulders, hips, and waist there were odd gold colored rings that didn't look like they served any purpose other than decoration. The newcomer, not yet aware of the two staring at him, gripped a rope in one hand and looked around frantically for something.

"Where are you, you stupid rabbit," he complained, his eyes darting everywhere. They briefly passed over Bruno and Amadeus, but he didn't notice them at first, instead doing a double take a moment later and falling over backwards in fright.

"What the hell!" he swore, pointing at what to him would be the outline of a huge creature as Amadeus and Bruno were leaning on each other, causing their shapes to blur together.

"What the hell indeed, Mr. Wilco," said Amadeus, amusement evident in his voice as he chuckled at the sight of the man on the ground. Walking over he helped Bruno against a tree before holding out his hand to help the unknown human to his feet. The man didn't seem keen on taking the offered appendage, until he took a close look at the face of Amadeus in the dim light, and then his own face brightened considerably.

"Amadeus, is that you?" he asked in astonishment while Amadeus pulled him up.

"Yes it is. And you're still Roger Wilco, right?" responded Amadeus, and the two walked over to the tree where Bruno was leaning.

"That's me. So, how'd you get ahead of me? I left you four portals back," commented Roger, to the obvious bewilderment of Bruno.

"You probably did, but if you remember, you're traveling through dimensions, meaning time moves differently. To you it's been a few minutes, to me about three years have passed," said Amadeus.

"My years or your years?" asked Roger.

"Mine, which makes it about twenty-one of your's. Oh and this here is Bruno, a native of this planet. Bruno this is Roger Wilco, a friend of mine from back during my days with an old military unit. From what I remember you got in a bar fight and ended up hoping portals between dimensions chasing a mechanical rabbit, is that right?" asked Amadeus, and Roger nodded.

"Yeah. If I can catch that thing it'll take me home, at least that's what I was told. By the way, you wouldn't happen to have seen it anywhere, would you?" asked Roger.

"Yeah, it went into a portal over that way," said Amadeus, nodding in the direction the bunny had gone in before vanishing into the now invisible ring of light.

"Thanks," said Roger simply, quickly getting up to pursue his prey. The portal appeared again as he got close and with only a second's hesitation he leaped into it, taking it with him as he vanished in another flash of light. When the human was gone Amadeus let Bruno lean on his shoulder again, and the two set off once more in silence, though Bruno's face indicated that he had a question or two on his mind.

"Uh, why didn't you go with him?" asked Bruno at last, hoping the reason wasn't that Amadeus had stayed to help him. Amadeus, surprised by the question, stopped in mid stride before turning his face towards the wolf boy.

"Well I want to get home, Bruno, not killed, and in truth Roger's more lost than I am. At least here on this planet I know there's someone who can help me, if he ever comes online that is," said Amadeus, and then the two set off on their way again. Bruno didn't know who this person who could help the human was, but he didn't think he wanted to know, all things considered. Hopefully Danielle or one of the other adults would know what to do.

It took a few more minutes of hiking for the pair to burst through the tree line into a well kept, and oddly well lit field at the edge of the woods. The state of the place was actually something akin to the sporting events Amadeus had seen, though the cheering quickly hushed when they noticed the particulars of the figures that emerged from the woods. Amadeus wondered exactly what it was Bruno had been doing, but kept his question silent in favor of the more immediate problem.

"Medic!" he shouted as loud as he could, and several figures broke away from the crowd in the stands. One had the unmistakable red cross on a hat, though the form was that of a snake. Amadeus was struck again by the red plus sign being a near universal sign of a medic, though he shook off that bit of trivia as the person wearing the hat got closer.

"I think he's got a hair line fracture in his leg caused by the application of focused local pressure. I don't feel any bone chips, but I'm not familiar with his details, so the damage might be more severe than I can diagnose," he told the serpentine, who slithered over to the duo as Amadeus aid Bruno gently on the ground. The snake didn't appear to have any tools, but put the tip of its tail on Bruno's leg and pressed several times before turning towards Amadeus.

"Your observation was correct. I'll have to take him back to the hospital for a full check up but I think he'll be fine. Lucky for him you were in the woods," commented the snake.

"Actually I'm the one who hit him, after he tried to eat me," admitted Amadeus, just in time for a few of the other figures, namely a sheep girl, to enter hearing range.

"You hit Bruno?" she said, outrage evident in her voice.

"Yes. I defended myself from his attack. If you wish some form of satisfaction from this you may have it later, but for now I think getting Bruno to the hospital would be our best course of action," responded Amadeus, not trying to change the subject, but rather stating fact.

"He's right Corrie. Let's get Bruno to an ambulance, and then we can find out the details of how he was hurt. Kevin, if you would?" asked the snake doctor as a large rabbit humanoid stepped forward, Together he and Amadeus lifted Bruno off the ground, and they as well as an oddly mixed group of followers started making their way towards the stands.

No one seemed to have noticed Amadeus' details yet, or that he was human, but two of the figures in the group, a rabbit female and a hedgehog female, were eyeing him. Before the group could get to the stands though a shout and several cries could be heard as the veritable sea of bodies parted, allowing a new form to pass through. As it came into view Amadeus was once more face to face with...
13112121212.title: Meeting an old friend on a new world

131121212122.content:
"Run," he told the group around him, as he set Bruno down. He leaped through the gathering of people, and made his way towards the stands where the lizard creature was already being joined by two of it's kin, all almost three meters tall, with wicked spiked tails, and claws foot long claws on the ends of their fingers and toes, each spike appeared to drip something that caused the metal of the stands to smoke.

"Where is he?" asked the largest of the creatures, looking around for someone. In answer one of the large of the people there to see the game stepped forward and stood in the lizard things way.

"Now I don't know who you're looking for, but we've got a situation here, so please let these people pass, and then maybe you can search for this person," he told the lizard thing, which eyed him. Without comment or word the lizard thing simply reached over, picking up the anthromorphic humanoid at his waist, and tossed him into the crowd, which began to run away from the trio of terror which roared and hissed at anyone who got close.

"I'll ask again, where is the human?" said the largest one, and his question was answered a second later as Amadeus stepped forward through a bit of the crowd that had rushed onto the field in panic. Unafraid he faced down the large reptiles, spinning his walking stick at his side in a show of skill before slamming it into the ground beside him.

"So, you guys wouldn't happen to be related to that thing in the junkyard this afternoon, would you? If so I have some questions to ask you that he didn't have time to answer before he went boom," said Amadeus, hoping to get some reaction out of the things. One of the smaller ones appeared to be about to charge forward, but the leader stuck out his arm and blocked the overanxious one.

"No, our father's ally wants this one alive, remember? So, Amadeus Orman, position Arrow Two, callsign Amadeus Ex Machina. We've been waiting for you," said the leader, and it was Amadeus' turn to react. Obviously despite his lack of information regarding the lizards they knew a lot about him.

"So, you've done your homework about me, but I seem to have misplaced my notes about you guys. How about you give me a review before the big test?" he said mockingly towards the large lizard thing.

"Oh, of course. Where are my manners? I have no name, as we don't use them, but others call our species the Grendal. You may have heard of us," responded the large lizard.

"Yeah, didn't some old warrior kill one a long time ago," said Amadeus.

"Beowulf in legend slew the thing after which we are named, yes. But believe me, no mere human could beat us. Allow me to demonstrate!" the last was a shout as the creature lunged at Amadeus, claws forward. Amadeus, unable to back up enough to avoid the strike, instead ducked under it, and then rolled to the side, bringing his legs around in an arc to hit the legs of the Grendal.

The Grendal, seeing the hit coming, leaped out of the way, and before Amadeus could rise to his feet he attacked again, leaping forward and forcing Amadeus to raise his walking stick in defense, only to have the inch thick piece of wood broken in half by the attack. Not pausing the Grendal lashed out with it's tail, trying to pin Amadeus to the ground, but Amadeus rolled again, and before the Grendal could recover he now faced a standing Amadeus, who twirled the two halves of his stick like batons in his hands.

"Cute. Let's see if you can take as well as dish out though," said Amadeus, this time rushing forward to the attack. The Grendal, who hadn't expected the maneuver, struck blindly in a horizontal slash with its claws, missing with both swings and leaving Amadeus to pop up in the area between the two arms. Before the Grendal could react Amadeus drove both sticks into the things eyes, not stopping until they hit the back of the thing's skull with a dull thunk, and knocking the huge lizard over backward.

The entire scene went silent at this point. The two remaining Grendals didn't look like they really grasped what had just happened, and the rest of the crowd, seeing how easily the large Grendal had dealt with the much more intimidating man in the crowd was awed by the skill the human had shown in taking down the huge lizard. Unfortunately, one of the Grendals recovered quickly as it noticed that Amadeus was unarmed now, and drove into the attack with a roar.

Amadeus, not caring about his lack of weaponry, repeated what he'd done to the first Grendal, ducking under the strikes of the large lizard, and rolling out of the way is it's tail came down on him. Unlike the first one though he spun back around before the Grendal could recover from its attack, and then with an unusual stance he drove his foot into the side of the Grendal's tail spike, causing a loud crack to echo over the field, followed quickly by a howl of pain from the beast.

Leaping forward he grabbed the spike and rolled to a stop a few meters in front of the Grendal, brandishing the spike he'd just stolen as his own weapon. The Grendal, blinded by pain and rage didn't hesitate to strike forward, pointing it's claws at Amadeus and diving at him. Amadeus, seeing the attack coming easily rolled under it, and came up under the thing's chin, driving the stolen spike into it's lower jaw, and causing it to fall over dead right in front of the larger one he'd killed a moment ago.

This time the reaction was much different from the crowd, as many cheered the human on, and the remaining Grendal looked at the small puny thing in disbelief. It couldn't understand how the other two had been beaten by the thing, but quickly determined that Amadeus needed some kind of weapon in order to take him down. With that thought in hand the final Grendal shot forward, slashing with it's hands, but not allowing the tail spike anywhere near the human.

Amadeus, seeing that the Grendal would not be obliging in offering its own weapon for him to use against it. Still he'd been unarmed against bigger creatures than the Grendal, and won every battle he'd been in. Dodging the attacks of the smallest of the three Grendal he found that this one was actually quite skilled at hand to hand, artfully altering the course of its blows when he avoided them, forcing him to take ever more extreme angles in his stance edging him closer to falling over.

Never one to give up without at least one attack he noticed that like the other Grendal this one had a gap in its stance right under its chin. Even after seeing him exploit this hole twice the thing apparently not learned to cover it, probably thinking Amadeus didn't have the ability to deal any damage to it without some form of weapon. Throwing all his weight forward Amadeus aimed to prove the creature wrong, falling right into that small hole in the creature's defenses.

Looking up he stared right into the soulless eyes of the Grendal, and he found no compassion there. The thing fought not to avenge the fallen comrades it had seen killed before its own eyes, but simply to prove that it could succeed where they had failed. Seeing that in the eyes of the creature made Amadeus that much more willing to kill the thing, and he shot upwards, leaping with his hands held up, palms flat so that they smacked the Grendal's head so it was looking straight up.

His arc of ascent peaking in from of the Grendal's head Amadeus threw his foot out, using all his weight to start himself spinning, and bringing his other foot to connect with the Grendal's head. Turning he heard rather than saw the Grendal's neck snap, and when he again had his feet on the ground he looked over his shoulder to find himself staring at the top of the lizard thing's head rather than its chin, its head having done a complete one-hundred-and-eighty-degree turn.

This time the lizard fell forward, and Amadeus was forced to leap out of the way as the now dead body of the Grendal slammed into the dirt at his feet. Sweating after the battle he wiped his brow as he got to his feet and looked around. Before anyone could cheer this time though, the sound of clapping and a dry chuckle came from the direction of the now empty stands, and out of the shadows from which the Grendal had first appeared a new form stepped. This one...
131121212122.title: When Grendal Attack

1311212121222.content:
"Impressive Amadeus. Truly impressive," says the figure as it steps from behind the bleachers into the stadium lights. The figure, clad in an oddly shaded blue robe, was lightly clapping his hands still, and from somewhere hidden in the hood of his garment he was chuckling in what could only be considered an evil tone. Slowly the figure made his way down the steps to the field, and the crowd which had begun to gather around the human, parted to allow his passage.

"I would never have expected you to beat one of the Grendal, let alone three of them in a row. Even knowing the things you've done in the past weren't really enough to do you justice," said the figure, his tone almost friendly with Amadeus, as if the two were familiar with each other, and meeting again after years apart. Amadeus' own expression remained guarded though, showing that even if the figure knew him, he didn't know it. One in the crowd did though, and turned to another to ask a question.

"Isn't that one of the Rabbit Council?" asked Danielle of Kevin, her voice a hushed whisper, and he did a double take, looking first at her, and then at the figure, and then back at her again. When he looked to her the second time he was shaking his head no, but one look at his face would show anyone who knew him that he wasn't really confident of it.

"It can't be. The Council doesn't leave the warren. Maybe he just copied the robes," suggested Kevin to his cousin in the same voice, but he looked at the figure with new eyes, and before anyone spoke again the figure turned to face Kevin.

"Oh no, my dear traitor. Our otherworldly cousin is quite correct. I am indeed a member of the World Council," proclaimed the figure, pulling back his hood to reveal that his words were in some part true, as he was a rabbit, though whether he was a member of the Council or not was still not completely confirmed.

"So I have to fight the Easter Bunny now? This day just keeps getting weirder and weirder," said Amadeus, and again many eyes were drawn to him, including the exposed rabbit anthro who chuckled again at this latest verbal shot.

"You have just gotten you're first strike Amadeus, as I am just a humble rabbit, and never got to play that particular role. The traitor has though, so if you want to fight the Easter Bunny I suggest you fight him," said the figure, pointing his thumb at Kevin. Amadeus, though, would not be distracted, and continued to stare at the one before him.

"I don't really care for titles that much friend, but since you seem to know as much about me as the Grendal did, how about you give me the same courtesy they did and tell me your name?" asked Amadeus, and the figure stared at him a moment before resuming that evil chuckle of his.

"Well, well, you really don't waste any time with the verbal stuff, do you. Straight to the point. Very well then, my name, if you must know, is Daemon Veris, or at least it is now. I had another name before my involvement with a very interesting group a few years back, but after the traitor's cousin betrayed us even more so than he did, we fell apart and I had to distance myself from them," said Daemon Veris, staring angrily over his shoulder at Kevin, but oddly did not include Danielle in his piercing gaze.

"Of course, that one died fighting us, so she got her's in the end, and then this little whelp came from the other world to take her place," Daemon said, turning his back to Amadeus, and walking towards Danielle. The rabbit cupped his hand and grabbed Danielle's chin in his strong grasp, causing a fox to leap forward, hoping to block him, but when the rabbit's other hand shot up in a choking gesture. George, the fox and Danielle's husband, stopped in mid-stride and began clawing at his neck as if he really was being choked, despite the distance between him and Daemon.

"Stay out of this, murderer. This particular discussion is between me, Kevin, your lovely bride from another world, and of course our visitor from the stars," declared Daemon, making a sharp slapping gesture, sending George reeling backwards. An instant later Daemon released Danielle, who stared at him a moment before running to the side of the fallen fox.

"Of course, my business with them can wait. Right now all I'm supposed to be interested in is you, and how to bring you back to my master alive," said Daemon, staring at Amadeus, who again found himself looking into the eyes of someone who wanted to use him. Not really a new thing for a four hundred year old soldier, but this was the first time such a stare came from someone who looked like a rabbit in Jedi robes.

"So, I'm guessing you and the Grendal are in cahoots then?" asked Amadeus, hoping for an affirmative answer.

"Yes unfortunately, they are among my associates, though I try to avoid them and those like them, whenever possible," said Daemon, and Amadeus smiled.

"Then that means you'd know about my little altercation in the junkyard this afternoon, correct?" Amadeus asked, and Daemon nodded, his expression saying plainly that he had no idea where the human was going with this particular line of questioning.

"Ok, so how about you tell me where my little brother is. Then maybe we can talk about me going with you," Amadeus told him, and again Daemon's expression was one of clear puzzlement, until he suddenly snapped his figures and pointed at the human.

"Oh, you mean the digital form? Well, like you, he has a part to play, so my master took the opportunity you provided to acquire him. Of course I'm sure if you join him he'd be happy to give the bit-brain back to you. Heck he'd even be glad to send you home after you've fulfilled his request," offered Daemon, and Amadeus looked at him questioningly.

"Am I to assume then, that it was these masters of your's who brought me to this world?" asked Amadeus, and Daemon shook is head.

"I'm afraid not. As powerful as he is, my master can't reach across the universe. Other hands brought you here, but my master was quick to take advantage of it," explained Daemon, and Amadeus nodded.

"Alright then, I have one last question then. Exactly who is this master of your's, and what is it he wants from me?" he asked point blank.

"What my master wants from you I really don't know. After all I'm second generation, if that, and in an example you would grasp, an ensign does not know what is on an admirals mind," he said, and Amadeus nodded again, understanding the metaphor quite well.

"As for who he is, I don't know that either, as we are all told to call him Emperor, but I think you'd be interested to know that he's the Emperor of a very special group called the Ap-Gara," said Daemon with his usual chuckle, though the change on Amadeus' face showed that whatever this Ap-Gara was it could scare the hell out of him, as he went slightly pale at the mention of the name.

"So Amadeus, since you recognize the name, how about you just come with me, and you can meet my master. That would be the easy way, or you could try and oppose us, but if you remember your history, those who opposed the Ap-Gara previously met with some rather violent deaths," said Daemon, and Amadeus again nodded, remembering images from history tapes that showed the devastation wrought on Earth just before Exodus by the creatures, self proclaimed gods, who called themselves the Ap-Gara.

In the depths of his mind he began to sort everything into place, listing to himself all the odds of his choices. It was in fact quite likely that the Ap-Garan Emperor could get him home, and would even give him back Zee if he gave him what he wanted. The problem was he would likely be sacrificing the entire planet and several others in the deal. After a long pause he finally stared into the eyes of Daemon and said...
1311212121222.title: The plot becomes even more confusing

choices: Punched himself in the stomach hard
Turned and made for the woods
13112121212222.content:
"I was afraid that would be your answer. Unfortunately for you, if you don't come with me by choice I've got orders to press the issue. Also for the record, that is strike two on your part," said Daemon before throwing his hand out. No one saw any other movement but Amadeus stumbled backwards as if struck, and they realized quickly he was using the same mental powers he'd used on George but moments ago, and many in the stands who had been frozen up until this point became unfrozen quite quickly and made for the exit.

After only a few moments had passed only the tight group standing around the fallen wolf boy and the fox man remained, this included a few rabbits, some other wolves, and the serpentine doctor, all of which looked at Daemon with fury, but stood aside, knowing full well the rabbit would kill them without any effort at all, in the same way he'd nearly killed George. This left Amadeus to rise to his feet on his own, using the back of his hand to wipe away a small squirt of blood on his chin and look at the rabbit with a glint of amusement in his eye.

"I just took out three creatures that probably could have ripped those antique vehicles from the junkyard apart with their bare hands, and now you send a psychic punch at me and expect me to stay down. Boy do you have a lot to learn about humans, bunny boy," said Amadeus.

"Hmm? Well then perhaps you'd educate me. Say tell me what it would take for you to join our little party. My master, the Emperor of the Ap-Gara could literally offer you anything your heart desires," responded Daemon Veris, meeting Amadeus with his own smile, though this one having a much different look.

"Well, let's see. First off you can stop being evil, second you can give me back my brother, and last you can get you master to take a nice long stroll in the event horizon of the nearest black hole. Do those three things and I think we can come to some arrangement," offered Amadeus in mock seriousness, causing Daemon to chuckle at him a bit, before throwing a second mental punch, though this one didn't even seem to make the human flinch as Amadeus just stood his ground, smiling at the anthromorph.

"You wanna know something, my friend? You make a lousy first impression. First you take my brother, then you interrupt me after a really fun fight and threaten me, and now you hit me. That's three strikes against you, and that means you get only one warning. The more that hit you, the more that will," said Amadeus, his tone getting slightly cryptic on the last phrase, which seemed disconnected from the rest.

Then before anyone could breath the human reached to the ground and hurled a stone at the rabbit, forcing Daemon to raise his hand and cast the stone aside with a mental shove, but before he could even blink two more stones flew through the air at him. He pushed these aside, and yet more began to fill the air as Amadeus dipped and leaped, grabbing any stray piece of hard material that he could find and hurling it at Daemon, who realized instantly that he was doomed. Amadeus was on the offensive, and he was on the defensive, the human wouldn't let up now, at least not until his target was down.

Thus did they battle, Amadeus even reusing previous projectiles as he spun around the rabbit in a circle, constantly tossing things at him. It soon back apparent to Daemon that Amadeus was a brilliant tactician, as the number of projectiles began to increase, because Amadeus was now gathering clumps of dirt and compressing them before tossing, and until he touched them Daemon couldn't tell which attacks were the stone, and which were imply dirt.

And then all at once it was over, as Amadeus broke Veris' guard with a dirt clump striking him on the right shoulder. As innocent as this sounds Daemon's guard faltered, and suddenly two more clods collided with him, throwing him off even more as stones with the force of a pitcher's arm connected with his knee, sending him to the ground with the sound of breaking bone and screams of pain. After that three more stone were flung in quick succession, and suddenly Daemon Veris was crippled as both his knees and elbows had been broken.

"I told you," reprimanded Amadeus as he stepped towards the rabbit man, his breath coming out in ragged gasps. As useful as the tactic had been, Amadeus' condition spoke of the cost it took from his body, and he literally collapsed to the ground beside the rabbit.

"So then, are you gonna talk now?" asked Amadeus of his prisoner, who continued to cry with the pain of his injuries, but was able to respond through clenched teeth with a swear that caused the younger of the two wolf women to cover the ears of what looked to be her son, the wolf boy wearing shades.

"Oh, now that's too bad, cause if you know me like you say you do, you know I don't take prisoners who don't wanna talk," said the human, picking up several rocks that were sitting nearby. He juggled them for a moment before tossing all but one aside, and then raised this one above his own head. It took the group, and Daemon Veris a moment to realize that Amadeus was telling the truth, and that Veris' life was about to be taken in cold blood.

"Don't do it!" shouted someone from inside the group, and out of it stepped a shorter, but obviously older rabbit woman than Danielle. The female looked at Amadeus with a matron's eyes, demanding that he not walk down this road, a road who's end was covered with blood, both innocent and guilty, though in truth the human had lived on that same road most of his life.

"And why shouldn't I? He was willing to kill the fox man, George, I think is the name the rabbit woman called out," responded Amadeus, never taking his eyes off Daemon Veris, who's face, when his death had seemed imminent, was now twisted in pain. As willing as he had been to kill, it was obvious Veris had no desire to die. In Amadeus' opinion that made him a lousy soldier, and lousy soldiers existed only to die.

"Yes he was, but that doesn't mean you have to kill him. Look at him, he's helpless now. He can't even move," she told him, as if that somehow erased his past crimes.

"That merely makes him an easier target, as any true soldier would tell you," responded Amadeus, raising the rock above his head once again.

"I'm not a soldier, so I wouldn't know, but I know when someone's beat, and he is. Why don't you try asking him your questions again?" she purposed to him, and Amadeus sighed. He knew the instant he'd paused his hand that the rabbit woman would not allow him to kill Daemon, and her argument made sense, but Amadeus hated prisoners, as they were so hard to keep locked away. Corpses on the other hand usually stayed exactly where it was you left them, unless some fool necromancer, deathwalker, or whatnot raised them up.

"Fine then," he said to the rabbit woman, letting the stone fall to his side.

"Tell me where your bosses are, and maybe I'll let you live," asked the human of the rabbit, but before anyone could respond or do anything the sound of snapping fingers echoed over the nearly empty stadium, and suddenly a shot of flames, black as night, fell onto the field in which the group stood, and it struck Daemon with a fury that none there could understand save Amadeus, and turning to the stands everyone looked upon a human form, like Amadeus', but this one was wreathed in flame as black as those that had consumed Veris.

"Well why didn't you just ask, Amadeus? I could have just said ‘right here' and saved you that whole fight sequence," said the figure, as he slowly walked onto the field. Despite his fiery appearance, none looking at him could feel the flames, and the grass remained unburnt as his feet passed over it, but when they looked back at Veris, or rather where Veris had been, only a small pile of ash remained, the rest being consumed by the flames that burned so hot they even consumed light, yet the man who wielded them did so with such control that he could grasp a snowflake in his palm and it would not melt.

"So, Veris wasn't lying, he really does work with the mutants and freaks of the Last World War. Pyro, isn't it, one of the Four Elementals?" asked Amadeus.

"Why yes, that is what people called me. Master of the Black Flame, and second only to the Emperor himself," said the figure within the fire, and surprisingly Amadeus began to laugh at his statement.

"Ha! Yeah right. The History I read says you were the lowest of the original Nine Ap-Garans. And if anything the Four Horsemen were above you and the Elementals, with their leader, Kinetic, being the second in command of your little terrorist group," responded Amadeus getting to his feet, which seemed to cause Pyro's flames to grow around him, as if that little statement were enough to fuel his flames, but a moment later he calmed down, and then Amadeus did something no one would have expected.
13112121212222.title: Daemon Veris Gets Fired

choices: They were able to free Amadeus
The batteries die and the large reptile is able to concentrate
131122.content:
Amadeus needed to get to his belt, it was of the upmost importants to get that belt because it might be the only way of getting him back home. Even if who ever was after him was not able to use the belt, who (or what) could easily destroy the belt in frustration potentialy leaving Amadeus stranded. It was also very possible that even if Amadeus did leave and wait for the CAP to come to him, who ever was hunting him could easily follow the CAP and find him.

Deciding that it was worth the risk, Amadeus crawled as quietly as he could passed the unknown enemy. Unfortunatly, it only took a few sniffs of the reptilian's nose to spot Amadeus. This new attacker looked exactly like the previous one, but even more angery as it snarled at Amadeus. Amadeus tried to dodge but was pinned under the beast's claw in a matter of seconds.

In a distance, three figures were mumbling to each other, one was holding a rectangular box over it's shoulder.
"So, the guy is pinned down and is about to be eaten or whatever they are about to do to him." the first one with the rectangular box.
"Alright, alright, I get the point, you were right the first time," the second one replied "just find that frequency you beat boxing fool."

It looked like the end for Amadeus, untill somthing very intresting happened. Everything became quiet and the giant lizard began to cringe in pain. It was then that Amadeus noticed an autible whining, like that of a dog whistle being played through an amplifire.
That was when the source came out, a human like Amadeus but was wearing clothes that looked like they came frome thousands of years ago, like a T-shirt and blue jeans. He also wore large head phones and sunglasses. Holding on his shoulder was a rectangular metal box with two speakers, Amadeus remembered that it was called a boombox. There was also a dragon wearing a lab coat and what looked like an android with a keytar and covered in a flexable neon material.
"Dude, we need to get out of here before the batteries in my boomer box die and big and scaily wakes up" replied the human "Spark, get the guy from under the claw, and Rave-N, look out for any more unwelcome guests."
The dragon then began to pull Amadeus out while the android scanned the area.

info.brief_description: A tale of survival on a strange world. Additions, Ratings, and Reviews Welcome
info.description:
Set on a world full of anthromorphic animals this is the adventure(Probably last) of Amadeus Orman, formally Amadeus Ex Machina, number two man of the Arrow squadron, the Combine's top starfighter pilots. The character comes from the Mirrored Emperor stories written by this author under the pen name Simon Sez. The world comes from the comic strip Kevin and Kell about a wolf married to a rabbit.

The Kevin and Kell comic strip can be read at herdthinners.com.

The Mirrored Emperor stories are avalible upon e-mail request to this author

Suggestions, requests, or any other input is welcome.

Cast of Characters

Amadeus Orman(Human, Male)
Age: 26 CSY(Combine Standard Years, roughly equals 420 Earth Years)
Equipment: Standard Combine Survival Belt which includes a Startec 32K Pistol, a pouch for carrying various knickknack such as an old flute, and a coin. On the back of his belt is clipped his Cyber Assistant Program, or CAP, an EI(Emergent Intelligence) which he calls Zee, contained in what resembles a small PDA, though it can create a physical shell that resembles anything Zee wants it to if necessary.

Kevin Dewclaw(Rabbit, Male)
Married to Kell and adoptive father of Lindesfare.

Kell Dewclaw(Wolf, Female)
Married to Kevin and mother to Rudy

Lindesfare Dewclaw(Hedgehog[Formally a human], Female)
Adoptive daughter of Kevin, from his first marriage

Rudy Dewclaw(Wolf, Male)
Son of Kell, from her first marriage

Danielle Kendall/Kindle(Rabbit[Formally a human], Female)
Interdimensional traveler through one of the gates created by the time machines used by the avians, now posing as Kevin's deceased sister and married to a Fox named George Fennec, who happened to have been in love with the original Danielle Kindle before her death.

George Fennec(Fox, Male)
Married to Danielle and copartner of Kevin's business called HareLink

Okay rules for additions
1) There is no set chapter length. If you want to add it can be as short or as long as you like, however it has to be understandable. If I can't figure out what you said, it get's deleted.
2) This story is told in the third person, though the perspective can change if you want.
3) Try to have fun with this, if you want to do something completely insane like have an energizer bunny suddenly roll across the area where the star is, go ahead, but always remember rule number 1, I don't get it, and it goes away.

::UPDATES::
Rules for Additions
4) You are allowed to play with the backstory of Amadeus or any other character as long as it does not conflict with the chapters prior to your addition.

Remember you add/review me, and I'll do the same to you. Or if you prefer I could give you GP instead.
